158865258.review:
[Update after 70+ hours and hitting endgame. TL;DR - the great potential fun of the game is obscured by 1) an unfun grind the further you progress, 2) weak and convoluted systems/mechanics, and 3) a bland endgame with yet more repetition, and bad design for multiplayer PUGs and loot.]

In its current state, I'd entirely skip Nightingale. It's not a buggy mess, it's not wildly devoid of any content, it doesn't have a bad premise or a terrible dynamic or is otherwise a trash heap. So what's the issue?

Lemme start with the good. It's a BEAUTIFUL game. The novel mechanic this game brings is RAD; procedural worlds (via cards) can be customized in terms of biome, intensity (gear score), difficulty (easy - extreme), public/private, and even further with minor cards (less damage but more resources, better crafting, harder enemies but more treasure, etc.). The combination of ranged, melee, and magic is good. Finally, the intense customization of all craftables (depending on the stats of the resources you're investing) gives great control over everything from gear to food to buildings.

All of that should really make for a good game, which is exactly why I'm so disappointed. Those good qualities of Nightingale, and all the fun they should bring, are buried beneath a pile of sometimes innumerable rough edges or, in many cases, outright terrible design. As one of MANY examples, y'know that interesting gear customization I mentioned? Completely dulled by hours of resource grinding to craft one or two items, clunky and disjointed crafting sequences, and a bizarrely convoluted 'crafting bench buffing' system that can end up requiring you to make multiples of each crafting bench or literally rearranging your workshop just so a recipe will show up on a crafting bench. And, after all that, your gear might only be marginally better than the Twitch drops (some of which I'm still using). With an absence of any kind of meaningful 'builds,' the stats don't even seem to really matter much more than just making you generically more powerful than before.

The endgame and multiplayer feels weak at best or bad at worst. Vaults (endgame dungeons) are essentially tougher repeats of all the encounters you've had a hundred times leading up to endgame, followed by a boss (which you probably already fought). In these vaults, you're likely to get paired up with other random players, which is out of your hands. And then, there's no in-game communication (that I've found) other than emoting; good luck coordinating anything. Resources in vaults are free-for-all, so if you happen to be playing with a loot-goblin rando, you're coming out of it with very few resources for so much time investment. Aside from vaults, you'll get the ability to craft higher tier cards to go back through the same three biomes you've been playing all along and repeat the same gameplay loop laboriously with the same enemies until, once again, you get enough essence to get the blueprints you need to craft better gear to hopefully run vaults faster for more essence.

And still, the single biggest flaw of the game is, in my opinion, it's overwhelming lack of information. A game needs one of two things - intuitive design or detailed info. If you've got intuitive design, great joy can be found through the act of discovery and learning the game simply by playing and figuring it out. But that ain't Nightingale. Chances are great that you'll struggle AGAINST the game to try and make it fun, to try and learn how some basic feature works, ultimately wasting hours thinking a mechanic functions one way only to learn agonizingly that it's nothing like how you thought, doesn't work how it should, or actually doesn't even work at all. My biggest pro-tip for this is to google everything you're wondering, or watch some guide videos, or pop into a Twitch chat to ask all your questions. Personally, I think games that require that kind of out-of-game searching so constantly are just poorly designed and need to do much better.

I gave 70 hours in the hopes that, if I could just get to that next tier or understand those couple of mechanics or make a better set of gear or tough it out to endgame, I'd finally find the fun that all the mess was leading up to. I'm finally concluding that the fun just isn't there right now. All in all, I ABSOLUTELY think Nightingale has some great potential and will probably be exceptional in a year or two after some serious refinement.

OK, I've got 50 hours in Nightingale now.  My initial obsession began to dwindle around hour 30. 

The environments go from breathtaking to meh. The first time you visit each of the 3 basic realm types, your mesmerized, and seeing how these are Fae realms, excited and nervous of what creatures, aggressive and passive, lurk just beyond the view on the portal. 

Creature designs are fantastic, no pun intended, and each new species is unique. We go from boars, wolves and deer, just normal animals, to Desert Elephants like something out of Lord of the Rings, terrifying Harpies, and what resemble Falmor, if they were armed by Mordor, The Bound. 

Combat isn't bad, but it's not very complex either. It reminds me very much of Oblivion or Fallout 3, for better or worse. Actions depend on weapon type: large weapons like picks and axes are slow and wide sweeping, with blocking as alt-fire. Knives and climbing picks much faster, offering a dash I used in traversal more than in combat. Firearms are clunky, with long reloads, which is accurate to the time in which this game takes place. Hits on weak points are where firearms gain their utility, with much larger critical bonus damage. 

The crafting system is intense if you're not used to material systems like Nightingales. The shear number of material types and tiers, each offering different bonuses to the gear they are used to craft, is daunting, but exciting if you're into that sort of thing, allowing you to really take your time and pick the specific material bonuses you want for your play style, or go hunt for new and rare materials. Collectors will have tons to do.

The equipment system needs work, as does the system for crafting equipment and improving gear score. While it can be fun to try lots of different material combinations to find just the axe or firearm you want, the results are lackluster. I noticed very little difference in the materials used on the same tool type. An axe of tin or copper feels identical to an axe of iron or even something as rare (and cool sounding) as Pursuit metal. Some material usage will effect how parts of your gear might look, which is a great touch, but ended with most of my character the first 40 hours just covered in leopard print and looking rediculous.

The "leveling" system is not great. Gear score doesn't slowly ciimb, allowing you to survive stronger realms and dungeons, as much as it jumps every 10-15 hours. The idea is trying new materials you find as you explore to make your equipment, but score is effected so little, you just use what you first craft upon obtaining the next tier of crafting benches. From 20s, to 70s, then upgrading rarity of your equipment jumps to 120ish and 200s. The different in material types for equipment needs to have more and less effect on gear score. Easier prey and ores with less addition to gear score, and new/rarer materials and tougher mods giving mats with more effect. The difference currently has very little effect.

As crafting is what you'll be spending a lot of time doing, the system needs a lot of work and balancing/buffing.

I have a lot of criticism for this game, but I actually really enjoyed the first 30 hours, maybe even loved them. It's early access so it has a lot of work to do, but the foundation here is phenomenal, and the potential to be up with the greats.

I recommend this game to those who love survival crafting games, and understand it isn't a finished product. Enjoy it for 20 or so hours, then check back in after a large update, I know I will be

159253147.review:
Victorian Fantasy Survival Craft game with exceptional UI, great 1st person combat, awesome procedurally generated islands and an overall great presentation. Suffers greatly  from performance issues and also from some archaic design decisions like overly complex crafting pathways and not being able to pull materials from storage in the vicinity on-demand. Biomes, building blocks, and progression systems are still rather limited.

I'd rate it a 7/10 (I do not hand out free points just for being in early access, so I expect this score to increase over time). A lot of the negative reviews (pulling down the overall rating) seem to be only concerned with the fact that the game requires an internet connection. Make of that what you will.

More in-depth feedback:

UI: God-Tier
-> clear visual hierarchy, sparse and tasteful usage of fancy fonts, important info is never unreadable, HUD is generally not intrusive or immersion breaking

Combat: S-Tier
-> great hit feedback (hitstop, camera shake, sound effects), aim-based crit system, fast-paced fights where enemies generally die in 2-3 hits, you have to manage stamina and positioning in group fights; simple animations for repetitive actions (i.e. basic attacks)
PS I do think the combat is objectively speaking at least "good", but taste differs greatly when it comes to combat. For some, it might not be flashy enough

Concept: God-Tier / Implementation: A-Tier
-> You travel through procedurally generated realms. On your adventures you collect 3 types of realm cards,: biome, major and minor. With biome + major card you create a new realm, with minor cards you can alter the rules within a realm. The results of the procedural generation are breathtaking. For now, the amount of biomes is very limited and I'd like to see more dungeons rather than just random shrines where you kill of 3-4 enemies.

Gathering: A-Tier
-> When hitting a tree with your axe, it busts a wedge into the trunk. This is very satisfying. Unfortunately, once the tree starts falling, it has very wonky physics, sometimes leading to breakdance, because little branches have the same rigidity as the stem (imo the branches should just not collide with the ground to fix this). Also the tree goes "poof" once it's felled, turning into small bundles of wood ready to pick up. This is nice, but often the tree goes poof before even hitting the ground, which is annoying. The mining is very enjoyable. With each hit you carve out a big chunk from an ore vein.
You can hold down the E key to AoE collect materials.

Progression: B-Tier
-> You progress your character by visiting new islands and crafting new gear and making better foods. I would like to see a talent tree, and also "learning-by-doing" skills like woodcutting, mining, etc.

Crafting / Building: C-Tier
-> Building blocks are very basic, e.g. there are only 2x2m wall blocks, nothing in between. You cannot build or craft from storage, which is an outright sin in the current day and age, especially in a game with such a limited inventory. In the early progression you have to craft a lot of random stuff with multiple dependencies where it's not always clear if you are even able to make it or not.

Performance / Graphics: C-Tier
-> For me the games becomes slower the longer I play. After an hour or so I hit <20 fps, at which point I have to restart the game. I have read that lowering "Lumen" in the graphics options increases performance a lot. That is true, however it does not really fix the performance issues and also, it makes the game look incredibly bad. For me, lowering Lumen beyong "high" makes all shadows disappear, all the colors change and it looks like a game from 2009. When Lumen is enabled the graphics and ambience look amazing, but the game becomes almost unplayable. Take Cyberpunk as a counter example: There I also get performance issues when enabling RayTracing (on my RTX 3070), but when I disable Raytracing the game doesn't suddenly look like hot garbage without any lighting/shadows at all - the reflections are just less accurate. They absolutely need to fix the lighting without Lumen

158902473.review:
I knew there was going to be issues after being a part of the closed beta on this game. Conceptually, this one hit right on the mark for me. A strange, victorian-era fantasy game with unabashed gestures toward lore and wildly strange creatures. It seemed inspiring, different, and in some ways familiar by combining survival/craft mechanics with a fresh new look on Unreal's freshest engine. But it all fell short—and in some ways—flat on its face.

The closed beta felt stiff in ways that were hard to quantify. The world was pretty, but it wasn't alive. The building options were well-textured, but limited in architectural fluency. The enemies looked wild, fantastic, dark, but they stumbled aimlessly and their AI was poor. In the distance, I saw hulking, meandering creatures, one-of-a-kind, only to see them stumble on basic topography, and cheese out to uselessness. The menus were overly complex, the combat didn't pack a punch, none of the many complex systems, all filled with the same potential, delivered. And that's what's most frustrating: This game offered hoards of potential and it seemed to fail on account of every single opportunity to shine.

I'm sure that even those rating this game positively will realize, sooner rather than later, that this game needed more play testing, a later release date (even in Early Access, which has granted it so much grace due to this), and more consideration. It needed stronger developers, people who understand these systems better, are more organized, and can implement them in ways that feel fluid. The tutorial, the first introduction to the game, is convoluted, confusing, and fails to do what tutorials should: teach players, in process, how to play and enjoy the game. Instead, it teaches them what they will actually experience: cumbersome mechanics stumbled through with uncertainty.

I understand people wanting to hope for this game. I did, which is why I invested in it so early in the development process. But, as is with so many games these days, they jumped the gun, and drove a knife right into the back of all of their work, spending their hype currency way too early, and likely losing everything they worked hard to build. If this game comes out of Early Access, I will eat crow. I don't suspect I have much to worry about.

158822082.review:
Nightingale is what you get if you transmute Valheim, Enshrouded, a teaspoon of gunpowder, a sprinkling of fairy dust, and a picture of Mary Poppins inside a Horadric Cube.

So if you're in the mood for a highly immersive true survival game set in a fantasy fae universe that actually has both first and third person perspective, you'd be scamming yourself by not trying out Nightingale.

[spoiler]Day 1 purchase and no regrets.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]As far as always online goes, by the time servers are ready to be sunset, Nightingale 2 will be out and offline play will be an option.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]
[h2]Initial Observations[/h2]
Melee combat is actually quite satisfying in Nightingale because you can swing your weapon while moving to make for a much more agile experience.  Hitting enemies in melee can also knock them around a bit giving it a more impactful feeling.  In addition, if you are blocking, you can press the attack button while holding a block in order to shove an enemy.  This can sometimes knock them down making subsequent hits deal more damage.

The art of the cards is quite charming and a bit of a nice change from usual survival game UIs.

The ability to get significantly more essence from processed or crafted raw materials is a nice incentive to craft.  For example, 30 crude quality rocks can be turned into marble stones for more than 6x the essence of just extracting the crude rocks.

The fishing mini-game is probably the best I've seen in a while.  Essentially you just reel in and slowly deplete the fish's "health bar" and keep slack in the line by keeping the fishing rod tip pointed at the fish as it moves around.  Once caught the fish drops in range so you can just hold down the loot button to pick it up.

The ability to pretty much repair your gear at any time by using Essence Dust is a great feature.  Upgrading gear by simply applying the next tier of essence is also very nice instead of traditionally having to grind a new tier of raw materials to craft a new set of weapons/gear.

Perhaps there's a tool later in the game, but it's a little odd that you can't use a sickle to get a harvesting bonus on wild flowers and other plants that provide a consumable instead of just plant fibre.

[h2]Observations after 30 Hours[/h2]
Nightingale certainly has a slow burn at the start when it comes to gear and weapon progression, gated largely by the combination of a main questline and equipment rating.  On top of that, the crafting formula and the needed materials to make items has more in common with what you'd expect from a factory building game than your typical open world crafting survival game.

Personally however, I'm fine with the approach as it's a reasonable price to pay for the flexibility of having such control over the stats of the final product of crafting.  Though, as a consequence, the amount of inventory management and space real estate required to comfortably manage this approach can appear a bit more than you'd expect.  This mixed with no means if "crafting from container" just yet, can make for a frustrating or uncomfortably time consuming experience for some players.

[h2]Observations after 40 Hours[/h2]
Enemy variety and combat options are opening up:
[list]
[*]Spiders in the Gloom have ranged and melee attacks and they will engage in melee with you for only a few hits before they retreat and try and hit you with a ranged poison attack.
[*]Other ground creatures continue with the charge behavior or up close melee.  Some having a poison component to their attacks.
[*]The assassin and the other bound that dual wields should spawn more often at the combat POIs.  The darkweaver (or whichever one drops the Petrified Ichor) seems to be rated at a high value because whenever it spawns it drastically reduces the total number of bound that show up even though they are fairly easy to kill (not very mobile and have low HP).
[*]Can start to make a variety of enchantments ranging from AoE melee attacks to fire enchanted attacks to healing over time.
[*]Can make more charms and infusions as well as being able to upgrade to rare with the option of having multiple on weapons/armor.
[/list]

Now that I'm cooking with the "refined" crafting station it's certainly worth it to take the time to use specific ingredients.  The difference between Mixed Plants vs. Salad is very significant and worth the time to craft.  Same goes for Roasted Meat vs. Tender Steak.

Same dynamic with crafting higher tier tools and then upgrading them to rare.  Starting to be worth it to make a "refined" tool then upgrade it to uncommon > rare rather than just taking the previous "simple" uncommon tool and making it rare.  Plus it gives the player a chance to use new higher grade materials.  i.e. simple tools are wood/stone/straps, refined is lumber/ingot.  What continues to be nice is how you can get lumber/ingots as loot from killing the bound and minor automaton enemies.  So you might be able to make 2-3 items without even setting up the production chain for the item(s).

Fae Towers are different in Gloom vs Herbarium (and the other lower level Major Cards).  Personally they are my least favorite POI so far.  Traps and mazes just aren't as engaging and satisfying as combat and jumping/memory puzzles.

The POIs in general are getting more involved.  The memory and traversal ones require additional navigation and mazing to complete (some including breaking walls).  Have had quite a few traversal POIs where I had to climb to the highest structure and then jump off it to use the climbing picks to get to the top of a narrow tower object.

The "boss" fights at sites of power seem to now have two automatons instead of one.  Each is a different variant.  [b]NOTE[/b] - The sprint-jump-hit "jousting" approach (using a 2h Maul) seems to work well for dealing damage and evading damage (especially for the ones with the laser beam or melee dash attack).

161814317.review:
I want to really like this game--my wife had been looking forward to it for some time, and I haven't had anything to play with her in several years.  So I really want it to be good.

It just isn't.

Don't get me wrong--I don't hate the game and it's not a bad game; it just isn't very good. 

It's a survival and crafting game with some combat and story.  But it doesn't do any of those 4 things well.  The survival is very light, and I appreciate that because I'm not a huge fan of the genre, just a small one; but all you do is occasionally cook a few mushrooms and eat once or twice a day, plus sit on your bed once in the middle of the day to restore the rest bar.  Truthfully, you could remove the survival mechanics altogether and no one would notice.

The harvesting portion of the crafting is terrible.  It has a floaty feel that I just can't get into.  You can hack at a tree for 5 minutes and make no progress, then change your aim point up or down by about 3 pixels and suddenly the tree falls over.  But the wood doesn't go to your inventory--you have to go pick up each separate log.  Rocks you hit once and a couple of bundles of stone pop out, but you can't see them because of the animated large chunks of rock obscuring your vision that you have to wait until they clear.  You have a hireling who can go harvest wood or stone, and they will chop at trees or rocks...but then they don't pick up any of the logs or stone, so you still have to get those yourself.  And then they weigh so much, you can barely move, so you talk to your hireling and learn they can carry so much more than you can--just give them everything that they wouldn't pick up.  Crafting on the other hand requires the use of several different stations, and several different ingredients.  But the ingredients are made from things that are made from things.  The game doesn't tell you how to get the ingredients you need, you have to look at each of the crafting stations and work out "I make this over here, then I move the output over there, then that gets me the piece I need."

Combat feels like someone once described combat to someone else and that someone else tried to approximate it.  Click your mouse to swing that weapon!  Don't worry, the animation will eventually start!  Your enemy has probably hit you twice by the time it does, but it'll go eventually!  Fire that sling bow!  Yep, you pissed off a wolf, now it and its 2-4 buddies will run up to you and jump on you!  Don't worry about not having a reload button--just press the fire button again and we'll start the reloading animation.  I'm sure you'll be fine while you wait!

And then there's the story.  I love games with stories in them--my favorite studio is BioWare.  But I just couldn't make myself care enough to read all the pages and pages of lore dumping.  And what happened to NPCs with voices?  I get that games with real acting cost more to make, but I sure miss having NPCs speak to me rather than hand me a piece of paper with their dialogue written on it.  Except for your narrator, Puck.  While I do enjoy the flowery language as a piece of the setting, and while the actor does a good job with delivery, I can't help but wish you could put that on 2x speed because it takes so long.

So I really want to like this game; and maybe these systems will be improved by the time they get to full release.  But 12.9 hours in, I finally had to pull the plug and go play another survival game named for a guy who flew too close to the sun to wash out the taste of bad harvesting.

I really, really wanted to enjoy Nightingale. The premise is alluring and the environment/world building is probably some of the best I've seen in recent surv/crafters. Everything else about it seems to take a backseat. 

For example, most crafting games now a days will either pull resources from your chests when crafting, or offer ways for this mechanic to be introduced if not given to you immediately. There is no such functionality in Nightingale. Combined with the inability to rapidly move items from your chest to inventory or vice versa and having to fight with the unintuitive interface, it compounds the amount of time you already spend fishing through chests and the like.

Another example being the basic tier 1 house building. These items such as windows and platforms require multiple resources themselves, wood, fibre and stone, but also require multiples of these individual items for each piece you set down. Building a simple house goes from a 2-5 minute affair to a 20 minute job. 

Because of these issues, you tend to start noticing other problems as you try and break from the monotony of the grind, ie. the combat is lackluster. The initial impact of fighting begins to wade quickly as the game tosses swarms of low level enemies with very basic attack patterns; lunge, swipe, repeat. During my initial couple of hours with the game, this pattern repeated constantly, and from what I hear, it doesn't get any better. 

This game has potential, it's just unfortunate that some design choices are severely hampering what should be an enjoyable trek through alien lands.

I like the premise, but the actual gameplay is full of systems that work against each other.

Your progression is gated based on gear score but gear score doesn't determine an item's effectiveness. I've reviewed many games over the years. Some good, some bad. Some AAA games, some by 1 man in a basement. This game leaves me perplexed. On one hand I want to write a bad review. I feel like this game deserves it, on the other, its so impressive and multifaceted I want to sing its praise. In the end though, I think I'll have to obstain and just state the facts. So keep these things in mind if you're planning to buy Nightingale.
1) The Learning Curve: It wasn't until about 35 hrs in before I realized how intricate and tricky the crafting system is. Materials have more info on them than a 4E D&D Beholders stat block. Material bonuses only apply when used in gear that has the bonus to begin with. But the gear doesn't show you which of the 15+ stat modifiers it has. Boots that give +speed+stamina gain nothing for using epic level leather for +sneak. You won't know that until after you craft it and wonder why your stats are missing. Finding these materials and understanding how to harvest them can be just as tricky. If you don't pay attention, you'll never unlock ANY new gear anyway, because its only thru specific traders in specific realms. You can check that in the "Trader tab" but the game never mentions this. I could write an entire novel just explaining all the ways this game hides important information integral to progression.
2)Difficulty Curve: This one perplexes me. On one hand, normal mode feels super easy. With a little grinding you can far outpace the realms you visit. On the other, if you start in extreme difficulty like me, the game becomes impossible to progress. Gear Score is locked behind materials, locked behind realm cards, locked behind dungeons to unlock those realm cards, locked behind the very gear score you can't achieve, See the circular logic here? Extreme difficulty set my t1 realm card dungeons GS requirement to 85. Completely unachievable in the starting world. Thru some jank, I fixed this, but normal difficulty was such a breeze it made no sense. I had lv60 enemies in my T1 extreme world, and lv 60s in my t5 normal world. With no increased loot rewards, interactions, or unlocks in the extreme version, there really isn't a point or reward to do so.
3)Building: The main feature of a survival world. Nightingale does it beautifully. Streamlining base building with an easy blueprint placing system. It also expects you to build MASSIVE bases if you want to add all the crafting stations, and all the augments. A cannon is a fun choice for unlocking military gear. Notably a rifle. It takes up more than a whole foundation of space, and needs to be close to 4 different crafting benches. Cool decoration, far to crowded. Otherwise I quite enjoy these feature.
4)Leveling/ GearScore: I touched on this earlier, but there is no leveling in Nightingale. You are jane/john doe and not special. But your gear can be. Craft it, enchant it, augment it, put a charm on it, and upgrade it. What annoys me is the sheer lack of options. Let me list all the weapons in the first 40 hrs of gameplay: Stone cudgel, hammer, pick, wood axe, knife, pistol, rifle.... Thats it. besides the better versions of each, thats about all you get. Same with armor. I JUST unlocked my 3rd set of armor, and it doesn't come with pants. I remember when gearscore became a thing in WoW nearly 15 years ago. I hated it then, I hated it now. Especially when the gear has hidden stats, and only 5 options thru most of the game. Even worse when compounded by every single unlock having the classic tv toy set *accessories not included* meaning your unlock is not unlocked, until you unlock it, by unlocking the thing that unlocks it.
5)Exploration POI: This game is beautiful, and terrifying. Just like the Fae. Several famous stories and myths walk around in flesh and blood, Unique takes on ancient evils like the Harpy and Grendal. Some fae want to be left alone, others may give you a gift, and yet more still may seem docile only to rip your spine out or melt your fact at earliest convenience.
6)Bugs/Glitches/Crashes: Sadly, even a week after release there are far to many issues with the game for me to simply write it off as early access. It would be one thing if it was a simple graphical bug or a few naughty surfaces fixable with the unstick menu. But these are serious, and NEED addressing. Getting stuck zoomed into a spyglass, a DOT that never ends, NPCs that won't spawn or talk to you, dungeons that lock you out and block progression forever, Resource counts for essence not updating when you get more, but updating when you spend, UI that won't show you gear stats, unlocks, blueprints, or objectives. This game feels so incredibly close to being fantastic that it's frustrating to see how much is missing.
It is currently in Early Access and has only been out for 1 day at the time of this review.

[h1]TL;DR: Wait for more updates before buying.[/h1]

While I am very excited to see more, I've also been following this game since it was first revealed.
I'm willing to take the risk that this game never develops further, because I adore the potential behind it so much.
[u]I do not recommend doing this to the average player.[/u]

[h2]First Warning:[/h2]
[b]The game is always online and run through their private servers.[/b]

The reasons for this being a bad design choice is obvious.
[olist]
    [*]It means the Single-player tag on the Steam page is a flat out lie. There is no personal single-player save you can have fun on. You are [b]always[/b] online and thus, never truly a single player.
    [*]If there is even a tiny hotfix update, no one can play. You just have to eat the hour or more downtime, which for some people, means half or their entire availability to play.
    [*]You don't have the freedom to make the game how you want it. Like in ARK:SE. You want faster harvesting? Change the setting. Do you want your game experience to move a little faster/slower? Change the setting. [b]You can't do that in Nightingale. You have no control over your game.[/b]
[/olist]

[h2]Second Warning:[/h2]
[b]There is no way to travel quickly.[/b]

There are no mounts, no vehicles: nothing. So a lot of the game just feels like walking simulator. An absolute slog to travel from one place to the next with next to nothing interesting to explore.
A few places piqued my interest to look into, but the time it takes to travel to those places makes the game feel pretty dull.

[h2]Third Warning:[/h2]
[b]Building is extremely and abnormally restrictive.[/b]

If you're buying this game because you like base building survival games, like myself, I do suggest not buying this game yet.
While there is some promise to the future, it's just not anywhere near offering a good, seamless base building experience. Of course not, it's in Early Access so there are bound to be limitations like that, right?

Well, not to this unusual extent...
You can't place walls on second floors without there being a wall directly below it.
So if you want to have a bedroom that's sectioned off on the second story, but an open plan on your ground floor: [b]You can't.[/b]
A wall can [i]only[/i] be placed if there is a wall below it.
This is, very possibly, the most insane and ridiculous building restriction I've ever seen.
I understand having a limitation on how far you can build floating floors without proper support, but this level of restriction is so egregious you can't help but think the devs were being purposefully malicious with the design.
It feels like the game doesn't want you to build anything other than a square box and it's [b]miserable.[/b]

The building pieces are very limited as well, but that's more excusable as it is Early Access.
[i]However, other games have released into [i]very[/i] Early Access with far, far better building systems...[/i]
[b]Valheim, Enshrouded, V Rising, ARK; to name a few.[/b]

[h2]Fourth Warning:[/h2]
[b]Combat is boring.[/b]

There are other reviews explaining it better, but the combat in this game is very bland.
Currently, AI is just [i]attack, pause, attack, pause.[/i] There's very little to it which is both frustrating and has lead me to avoid fighting anything because it's just not fun.
This is one of those things that is somewhat common in Early Access games. Mediocre AI, something that can be improved in time.

[h1]Overall: Do not buy unless you're willing to take a leap of faith that this game will develop into something amazing.[/h1]

Overall First Impressions:

159142304.review:
I'm normally quite optimistic with Early Access games, happy to weigh potential and forgive rough edges to give a positive review even in an early state. However in this instance, and in fairness, only the first week of Early Access, I have to give this a thumbs down in light of there being no mid-thumb on Steam.

[b]TLDR[/b]
Some glaring design flaws right out the gate. Which could be addressed but you have to consider that the people fixing those flaws were happy with them all the way up to Early Access release.

[b]Review[/b]
Given my limited playtime I'll just focus on what I've encountered so far. 

[i]Online only[/i]
The immediate issue is, of course, the fact the game relies on servers regardless of whether you are playing solo or co-op. While this is being billed as "online required", which is an issue in itself for some. The major problem here is that, if you're looking at solo play, you're being weighed down with all the sacrifices of online infrastructure with no benefits. In my very short time playing so far I've seen consistent "Waiting on server" messages when entering the game or changing realms, I've also been repeatedly disconnected from the game and pushed to the main menu for "Inactivity". Why can't I idle in my base? Well because it's wasting server resources. See my point about the sacrifices for no benefits.

While it hasn't impacted me yet, server updates and resulting downtime mean you simply can't play at all. There is also the very common end game of these servers being shut down if the game isn't a commercial and sustainable success (read that as short lifespan and probably paid DLC aplenty).

In the Dev's defence, they have acknowledged this and said they're looking at it as a priority. Depending on when and how this is addressed I'll happily come back to this review.

[i]Procedural Content[/i]
So that chonker aside. The game itself. Well, here is the rub. The game has a solid foundation but much like the online, it seems those foundations are built on unstable ground and it's going to be a question of whether the developer can fix that.

The procedural realms suffer from the classic procedural issue. Grand structures, touches of flair, stunning landscapes. All cut and pasted from a pool. Many are just aesthetic in nature with no function or, by necessity, when you can interact with them the loot at the end is low value to maintain a gated levelling curve. Ultimately, the sheen wears off fast and that feeling of awe and discovery soon becomes devalued.

[i]Twitch Drops[/i]
While I'm moaning. Have they seriously locked content behind an 8 hour twitch idle? So I buy the game and can't have a pet dog? I can't idle in the game for 20 minutes but running a twitch stream on mute for 8 hours is just fine? The lack of content and hypocrisy isn't the biggest issue here. It's again that the developer has made a decision to penalise and restrict the player to the detriment of the game itself. In this case, clearly for a financial benefit. It begs the question of what other design decisions have and will be made using this logic?

[i]NO PAUSE[/i]
I'm seriously tired of developers failing to address this very basic QOL accessibility feature. If a game offers single player then it should offer an immediate pause feature. Phones ring, kids shout, pets piddle, doors are knocked. It's further compounded in Nightingale where you can't even risk perching yourself somewhere "safe" or teleporting back to your base, as stats still tick down and environmental debuffs apply. And of course even if you do that you'll be kicked for inactivty anyway. Even quitting to the main menu is a multiple button and click process.

We have a arachnophobia mode right out the gate but nothing to address that real life exists.

[i]Content[/i]
I'm only a little way in but I'll say that there does seem to be considerable effort put into the 'tech tree' progress. Many (too many?) workstations exist, materials of many types, items to craft, upgrade and enhance. Building is a thing but is somewhat outshone by Enshrouded's system. The story/mission structure seems sound so far, pushing you in the right direction without too much of a heavy hand. I can't speak too much on gating/grind or a repetitious nature of missions but the dev clearly seems to have focused on this predominantly for their EA release.

[i]Character vs Environment[/i]
Just a small point but I find the player/npc models very jarring against that of the environment. It's like they're very low definition and made more so against the detailed and rich environments. It's very distracting and made somewhat worse by janky animation and pathing issues. 

[i]The summary, summary[/i]
There's enough here for me to continue playing more despite these issues, I'm eager to get further into the content and tech tree side of things. I've bought the game after all. That said, I feel there are some red flags in here that may mean this never reaches a level that is more than an average game. They can turn this around, look at No Man's Sky, but that is more the exception than the rule.

Buyer beware. Pick it up cheap and in the knowledge of its flaws or wait a few months and see what direction it goes.

159286253.review:
I'm aware this game is in Early Access, but while playing I find one terrible design decision after another. It's like they plucked a random person who never played a survival game off the street and told them to design one. There are things in game that shouldn't have made it past the alpha stage.

- Building: You're given the impression you can build to your heart's content. You cannot. The building limits are realm wide for all buildings in that realm INCLUDING the ones the game generated. That limit is incredibly low. Check the forums if you want specifics. In short: forget about building a giant castle, not going to happen.

- Crafting: inventory bloat. They made so many versions of resources that you're always struggling with storage space. It feels as if at some point the game was supposed to have been an mmo where they sell inventory slots in a cash shop.

- Clothing: unless you got the Twitch drops you're going to be stuck in yellow hobo gear with turban for a large part of the game. This clothing has nothing to do with the victorian setting you're supposed to be in.

- Character face presets: please provide paper bag.

- AI, or better said Artificial Stupidity. You get a helper NPC who can cut down trees near your house that destroy the walls should they drop on them. The resulting wood he stuffs in your forge/cooking fires even when you don't want him to. Or he puts it in some random house plan of an NPC quest when you didn't start that quest yet. That is if he picks up those resources in the first place. Most of the time he doesn't.

- Realm design: yes, the realms look pretty. But there's only a few types and it's only surface deep. You keep getting similar points of interest in them just at different locations. It gets repetitive. Yes, I know how to reset realms.

- Fishing: counts as inactivity. I've had to get 16 fish for the MAIN quest (which is a cardinal sin in my book, fishing should be a side quest at worst, abolished at best) only to get disconnected at fish #15.

- Tests of Agility: just no. Burn with fire, then bury the ashes, then pee on the ashes. That at least would give some satisfaction.

- Augment stations: I'm so frustrated with the augment system that I'm going to take a break playing. This is the most sadistic crafting system I have ever seen. Range is too short, recipes get unusable if there are too many augment stations for your crafting benches, you have to put a CANNON, a plough and a rainbarrel inside your house. I won't have room to move around anymore. AND it takes away from the building limits, this while my main reason for buying this game is being able to build something huge. 

- There's more, just check the forums.

Look, I've played a lot of early access games and I'm aware the game is not finished. I cut most EA games some slack because of this. I'd not write a review yet if I think that game will be salvageable in a reasonable amount of time. I've 50 hours played so I really tried to give the game a chance. But some of the above are simply inexcusable design decisions. Hopefully it will be changed eventually, but since the game is only going to be about a year in EA I don't think release is going to be able to fix all that. It was not ready for EA yet, and in one year I highly doubt it will be ready for an 1.0 release.

First off, if you're susceptible to motion sickness, don't buy this game. I have never experienced it worse than with this game, and while 3rd person does help, it's janky as all hell.

Second, the story progression is pretty slow and, so far, boring. Since it seems like character progression is locked behind story progression (which is a really weird decision for a game of this type), you're limited to basic equipment for a long while. I want to jump into an exciting world, fight new enemies with interesting weapons and build cool buildings with new and exotic materials. I do not want to be railroaded by a little guy in a mask with my best weapon being a stone axe. 

Third, always online. While their reasoning for it makes sense, the implementation of it is just stupid. Let people set up a server if they want to, don't force them to.

Fourth, the building system is pretty bad. Grinding resources is a massive pain, and navigating the menus is a nightmare. The actual building is also pretty janky compared to similar titles. I haven't yet progressed to a point where I can build with more interesting resources than basic stone and wood though, so I can't comment on whether or not it becomes better. So far though, the building system is thoroughly unimpressive and frustrating.

All in all, Nightingale seems to have great potential with an interesting and unique setting, but interacting with the world as a player is not entertaining. The combat is boring, the resource gathering is boring, the building is boring, the crafting is boring, the progression is boring, and traversing the world is boring. I really want this game to be good, but as it stands, the only good thing I actually have to say about it is that the concept is awesome. Hopefully they can fix all the issues holding it back, but as it stands I can not recommend this game to anyone.

TLDR: boring, do not buy.

159003320.review:
I usually don't write reviews, but I feel like I'm obligated to with this game if for no other reason than to push back on a torrent of what I find to be genuinely just bad faith, curmudgeonly reviews. There seem to be a lot of superficial, honestly downright *weird* criticisms of this game that have little to no grounding in what the game actually is, at least given my experience with it. 

Straight out of the box, there seems to be a ton of knee-jerk detraction surrounding the always-online foundation of this game, which I think has been blown entirely out of proportion. I dislike always-online as much as anyone else, I feel like it's almost always a bad decision and there's really very few games that actually necessitate this sort of "feature." That said, when always online IS necessary, and it's done properly, there's literally no issue with it. The game was flagged by my firewall initially, I don't know if all of these people with problems just missed that on their end and they don't know how to remedy the issue once the OS prompt goes away, but I've had zero issues with the connectivity at all. No issues getting in to the game, no laggardly loading screens, hell, I don't even feel any latency. So, from my perspective at least, the extraordinary amount of backlash regarding "another always online game" ruining the experience is fundamentally baseless.

Secondly, I've seen a lot of people complaining about...character creation? They say the characters are ugly as sin. I genuinely don't understand this angle at all. This game has an insanely robust character creation system, with you being able to pull genetic traits from your lineage (selected from up to 14 of the preset faces) in order to get a very particular face blend to start working with, BEFORE you begin tinkering with all of the nuanced options they offer. Not to be that guy, but if your character is the ugliest thing you've ever seen in a game then I have to say it's literally a skill issue.

The world building is lovely. Now, I find "survival-crafting" to be an EXTREMELY tired genre, with an absolute deluge of the same game being churned out and completely saturating the market year after year. That's not to say that the genre is devoid of its gems, however, and I think that the key really lies in how a game situates us in order to give us circumstances that would rationally lead to a survival-crafting system. I really appreciate when games give us world building and lore that contextualize and rationalize the building-from-nothing progression, like Valheim or V Rising (each remarkable in their own right), and I find that Nightingale executes on that remarkably. Playing cards at gateways as an in-universe justification for drastically varied procedural generation, portal-hopping through fae worlds and dimensions? Lovely. An absolutely novel concept and it really does just elevate the vibe of the game. 

Graphically, the game could use a bit of work, but it's miles above what I've come to expect from any Early Access title, and I'm sure they're going to be improving this as time goes on. The lighting and edge sharpening specifically seem pretty "graphics engine default" to me, I'm not sure really how to explain it. The way light plays through grasses and shrubs, for instance, is kind of rough, but overall I find the visuals to be unexpectedly captivating for this type of release. 

There seems to be a great deal of depth in the actual mechanics of the game, that I've not yet scratched the surface of, but my initial thoughts are that it's... good? There's a lot of information and different systems at play, but the developers have given us an extremely robust and intuitive UI that makes parsing all of this information a breeze. I, again, do not understand all of the criticism I've seen leveled at the gathering/building/crafting components of the game.

The combat, I suppose, is the one area where I'm closest to understanding complaints I've seen about this title; but not nearly to the extent I've seen some individuals caterwauling about. The combat itself is actually quite satisfying from what I've experienced so far, it's behaves quite similarly to Vermintide 2 combat (which, if you've not experienced it for yourself, is the single most satisfying, well-honed combat system I've seen in any game where you're contending with more than one assailant at a time). That said, enemy AI is rudimentary and could use a decent amount of tuning. To which I say: this game is Early Access? This game is, at time of writing, TWO DAYS Early Access and literally everything is going to continue getting touched up on as development continues, and people have been lambasting the game over this. Such complaints don't really hold water in my opinion.

So, in summary, a vast majority of the criticisms and negativity surrounding this game seem to be really....disingenuous to me? This is an exceptionally solid foundation for the developers to build on, and even this very first build of early access is something quite special that I look forward to sinking my teeth in to further. I'll update this review if my disposition changes, but I don't reckon it will, and I just wanted to put this up so that it might give any undecided buyers pause for thought after seeing so many negative reviews that are in my opinion extremely unfair and bad faith.

160464981.review:
After sinking 180 hours into the game, I can't really recommend it in this state. I think it has great potential, the core feature of procedurally generated biomes based on a combination of cards is a really interesting concept, however much of the game's aesthetics and systems are at odds with its turn of the century "gaslamp" fantasy.

I had an initially resistant response based on early crafting systems and menus being unusual and the tutorial/information being very unhelpful, but for a while the more I played the more fun I had. After reaching the end of progression, the more I play the more the game breaks and the more disappointed I become.

[h3]The Good:[/h3]
[b]The Realm System[/b] -  Really interesting. It harkens back to gaming fantasy like .hack/sign games, which used keywords to create worlds to explore. Nightingale's the only game I've experienced that has touched that concept in any meaningful way. The worlds it generates are interesting and full of discoverability at first glance, but become quite mundane after seeing the same landmarks and resource clusters expressed over and over. The second card played at this time seems to be a story progression card, rather than something that actually influences the biome. I could see this becoming a very dynamic and engaging system in the future, but at this time it's not developed enough.

[h3]The Mixed:[/h3]
[b]Crafting[/b] - The system is overly complex, every resource you collect and use influences the products it creates, however it also creates unique and distinct items because of this. Even when the stats on an item are lost in refinement, or don't produce any meaningful difference, the item carries forward a unique indicator based on its origin materials. Realm cards, for example, do not carry forward any stats and there doesn't appear to be a difference between crafted cards and found cards, however crafted cards carry (wood) and take up an additional inventory slot.

[b]Crafting Gear[/b] - The materials you use to craft equipment changes the look of the equipment crafted, in addition to modifying the stats the gear has. This is an interesting feature, however without some form of glamour or transmog, I could see this being a pretty big point of contention for players in an online community. I could see aesthetic materials and statistic materials being separated in the future, if the developers don't want to implement a glamour/costume/transmog system.

[b]Gear Score[/b] - As you progress, there's an item level/gear score system that's very ambiguous. When crafting, recipes don't indicate a tier or base item level, materials also don't display a tier, only showing a prospective item level when materials are added, but not indicating tier. Materials affect only the listed stats on a piece of gear, so while lots of materials contain varied stats, you can't add poison resistance to boots, for example, because boots don't have a poison resistance stat. Materials also influence the total item level of a piece of gear, regardless if they influence the stats on that piece of gear, creating a situation where you can have an item with very high item level, and near base stats - or an item with very high stats, but lower item level.

[b]Shared Realms[/b] - There appears to be some ability to share realms, but no clear and stable system to create shared abeyance realms or a "guild" type abeyance map for semi-public, semi-private cooperative maps. There's no ability to lock chests or protect your structures, anyone can build and destroy objects you create. While this isn't really a big deal with how private the realms are, there is some opportunity for griefing in the future.

[h3]The Bad:[/h3]
[b]Building[/b] - It's really basic, for a builder survival game. You have no influence over the environment to clear grass or large non-resource rocks, so you'll likely have grass coming up through your floor or rocks poking through your walls. There's no innovation in this space, you're basically building boxes with a triangle roof, all placed from the player's ground-perspective. The aesthetic choices for the currently available building recipes are uninspired. Materials don't seem to affect the appearance of the structures they create, which is unusual since they impact crafted items. There doesn't appear to be any form of painting or wallpaper, and for being a game with industrial, metal work, and fantasy points of interest... It's very surprising that there's no floor plans or building blocks that represent london architecture in 1905.

[b]Aesthetics and Lore[/b] - The game's look and systems are at odds with it's lore. It's like playing a higher-res Valheim after walking through the barrier into the movie Annihilation. it feels like either the developers were unable to capture the aesthetic essence of the story they had, or they had a game structured around the realms and slapped on the story afterwards.

[b]Exploits and Features[/b] - The interaction of minor realm cards and the crafting system creates the ability to duplicate items. It's unclear if this was intended, but it's surprising that the materials you can duplicate are wood and metal, when the economy on farming, seeds, fabric and food is so poor. At the time of posting there's also methods to mix and compound stats on metal items, which could be an intended feature as there's a visible upper limit, but it's again ambiguous and not how a player might expect the system to work.

[h3]Potential:[/h3]
I think this game has great potential, and overall has decent value for time invested at the EA price. I could really see it becoming something special and very fun with some adjustments and a lot of work. This build feels like an early alpha test state, so seeing it as an Early Access release is a little concerning as this usually implies significant adjustments aren't expected. I hope that in the future I'll have a reason to change this review to a positive one.

So, played this game for awhile till server maintenance hit and I was forced out of my game in the middle of streaming it. I'll start with the negatives about the game first. 
The biggest downside is that it's an "always online" type game meaning that if you want to play it you MUST have an online connection. As a survival crafting game, to me that is a massive downside. Plenty of other games, even recent ones have shown you can have an online experience with survival craft and not need an always online service i.e. Minecraft, ARK, Sons of the Forest, Terraria, Valheim, Astroneer, Starbound, Palworld, etc can all be played either P2P (Peer to Peer) requiring no server software at all or can have individually hosted servers and all are great games in their own rights. My opinion, but making the game one that requires an online connection limits its lifespan and its playability massively which is not exactly great especially for an indie studio.
Second, and far less concerning is the somewhat clunky nature of the UI and crafting system. It's not terrible, just a bit wonky compared to other survival crafting games which all have usually pretty similar systems in place. Once you figure out how to navigate it then it's really not too bad.

Now for the pros.
Its gorgeous. The game world I have seen so far, which just consists of the three starting biomes (A forest, desert, and marshland), look absolutely stunning. Detail is phenomenal and the lighting is wonderful, built in support for DLSS definitely helps and sitting on Balanced I can hold a decent framerate even without Frame Gen turned on, with it on I sit comfortably at my monitors max refresh rate of 100fps on a 1440 Ultrawide monitor on the Quality (high) settings. Could probably do with some optimization, but its by far not one of the worst offenders of game optimization that ive seen. Havnt seen many enemy types yet really, but of the ones ive seen I would like there to be a bit more variety in their attacks. Some Hippo looking animals are a bit overly aggressive and constantly charge at you and past you making them very annoying to fight if theres more than one of them. The grey goblin-like creatures arnt too bad to manage so far, but really only have two distinct attacks.

Overall, I'd honestly say maybe wait a little to get the game. Its not bad. Crafting isnt too hard to figure out, combat is maybe a little overly simple but I am just in the beginning, and some features are missing in the customization area like tattoos and scars and more fine control over character facial features, unless thats what the ancestry thing was about which seems like a bit too much effort to put in for what should be otherwise simple character customization. It has potential and it certainly looks beautiful. Just be aware that it does have that early access feel and limitation.

Message to the devs, if they read this: Please, please, please, give this game an offline feature that doesnt require an internet connection and allow for either P2P hosting to third party dedicated servers. To me, and likely to many others who play this genre of game, that is the largest hindrance to the game. The very last thing I and many other want is to have server connection go down in the middle of a major fight or building project. 158837025.review:
I have been hands on this game prior to release, and I have been excited for it to hit Early Access... i loved playing this game and seeing how it was changing during the development process.

The developers are highly dedicated and took a massive amount of feedback they received before EA release and implemented it. I was surprised at how the visuals received a lot of polish and the optimizations done between the last test and EA release.

I love the way that realm cards work and how you can design a new realm to explore. It's fun to combine major and minor cards to create some realms with unique characteristics. Looking forward to seeing what the developers do moving forward.

I see quite a few negative reviews already being posted. While there are some, very good, constructive negative reviews there are a lot that are written by people that do not understand the game, and the way it is built.

Always Online - Yes, this game has been designed from the ground up to be always online. This is due to the architecture of the game... each realm exists globally to all players. This allows people to invite others to their realms, or allow others to publicly join their realms based on preferred game settings. This also solves the issue of having a multiplayer group playing on different, interconnected realms, at the same time. There are many other global aspects to the design of this game, it was never marketed as an offline experience and as you progress further into Nightingale, it becomes more apparent why this is an online game.

Various claims of being broken - This is an early access title, however many of the issues complained about in negative reviews are occurring because of server load. If a portal does not open, the server was unable to complete the operation at the time you attempted to open it. Log off (not to desktop, just to the character select screen) then load up and try again. I've had to do this twice in 2.5 hours... it happens and will smooth out as the developers work on updates and optimizations.

Not understanding the card/realm system - You learn as you play the game, you start with nothing and have to learn a bout portals and cards in order to progress... follow the quests and you will start to understand how it all works (the information is spoon-fed a bit which I don't love, but it will add onto your knowledge as you play).

Cannot drop items - You cannot drop items right now, I don't know if that will change. However you can convert them to essence which is used to repair equipment. Is that stack of 1000 rocks weighing you down, convert it to essence (which is 0 weight) and keep moving forward. You will learn how to make simple storage bags very soon after the Tutorial finishes, they are cheap and easy to make and will store a decent amount of materials.

Can't split items - Right click on the stack in your inventory and select split (this is not called out in the game and the Devs should mention it somewhere).

No servers outside NA - I'm not surprised about the server locations for the initial EA release. It's difficult to understand how the demand will be distributed over the globe, and how the servers will react to players in the EU and Oceanic regions. With the persistence and connected nature of the game, it may take some time for the developers to come up with a solid multi-region solution. I understand and acknowledge the complaints about this, the only thing we can do is give it time.

Having played 11 hours at the point of writing this review, I wanted to give it a recommendation. It is by no means a perfect survival game, but what I've played so far, I've enjoyed far more than any of the other survival games recently. The environments, especially the forest biome, are very pretty, and ive had a good time just running around the game in co-op.

Some of the reviews on here are incredibly strange, and I wonder if the people writing them even tried looking things up or just playing the game before writing them.

- Yes, the game is always online. but there are definitely EU servers. I've played for 11 hours and I've not gotten any lag during that time. I've also had a grand total of two connection errors playing in that time. Would I have preferred for the game to be playable offline? yes, but the requirements quite literally state an internet connection is required to play the game. You knew what you were getting into when you bought the game.

- Ive seen complaints that there is no way to organize stuff, and that you always grab full stacks of items when taking them out of inventory. chests can be named, and you an use shift when grabbing to split stacks. That said, I'd LOVE for there to be a way to craft from chests directly and not have to get stuff out before doing so. 

- I've seen complaints that crafting is convoluted, and yeah, I can see that it might become so at higher level. but I saw someone make a huge step by step guide to cook berries. It's a truth with modification because while you can go through all those steps, you can also just use the autofill function in a crafting station. Don't care if you are roasting blueberries or raspberries? go into the cooking station, press cooked berries, press autofill, choose the amount of things you want it to cook. Don't care much about what type of fuel you use? go into fuel, press autofill, press ignite. enjoy oodles of berry flowers

- I've seen some complaints about the world being empty from people with very little time played, and I'm kinda wondering if they are mistaking the three small tutorial isles for how the rest of the game is. way it works is in the beginning, you go through three small biomes learning the basics, then the game sends you to the first "real" map, where after doing some gearing and setting up a base, you get the means to go to the first tier of more challenging worlds. the three tutorial maps are very small and basic, which I agree can be kinda boring, but they are also done very quickly. the only tip I can give for this is bring lots of fiber from the first forest tutorial area because you'll need it in the other two worlds, and they have a lot less available.

163342624.review:
There are an awful lot of negative reviews from people who seem to expect feature-complete, full-production games in early access. Early Access is just what it says on the tin. Early. If the devs considered the game to be ready for full 1.0 release, it would be fully released rather than early access. Speaking of version numbers, patch 0.2 is slated to come next week with a few welcome changes including build from storage and using the guidebook menu to purchase from traders you've already visited (no more having to run back and forth for separate purchases!) along with some new enemies and new combat behavior of existing enemies.

Yes, 0.2 meaning it's a far cry from 1.0 so consider that before you think about purchasing the game. If you expect 1.0-level development completion, don't buy the game yet and wait for full release. If you're intrigued enough by the game to tolerate occasional jankiness as the devs iron things out, and initial fun-but-relatively-shallow (read: placeholder) endgame content as that content is still in development and hasn't been pushed out yet, then by all means buy and join us in the realms.

Is the game good? Absolutely. I'm currently about 130 hours in and still having a blast. Exploring the options of the crafting system is very interesting. Base building isn't super elaborate yet but still presents plenty of options to make something good looking. Combat is smooth. Performance is great (I'm running with all settings maxed on an RTX 3060 and haven't had so much as a stutter).

Are there things that could be better? Again, absolutely. That's the entire point of early access. Points of interest on the maps need some more variety, endgame content needs more depth. I desperately hope we get clothing dye options soon as the current system determines color based on the material types used and those colors range from nice but dull to garishly spotted parody costumes with jarring color combinations.

Do the devs listen to the players? Yes, and this is demonstrably true. That 0.2 patch I mentioned next week re-introduces a game mechanic that they recently disabled that they had initially considered to be unintended. They originally wanted players to have to use several different materials for a spread of benefits for your gears. Players discovered they could stack the same materials to laser-focus specific stats.
Devs confirmed that wasn't the intended mechanic and removed that ability.
Players spoke up saying they actually preferred it that way.
Next week's patch re-enables that mechanic, and makes a variety of other changes to the crafting mechanics to take that unplanned feature into account and make using it better.

Do I recommend the game? That depends entirely on you.
If you understand what early access actually means, and are OK with that, I definitely recommend it.
If you expect 100% completion in a game that hasn't reached 1.0 yet, I recommend actually waiting for 1.0.

159418665.review:
[h1]WHAT IS NIGHTINGALE [/h1]
Nightingale is a survival game set in a Victorian era Gaslamp setting (gaslamp is similar to steampunk but with magic where as steampunk focuses on science). The player travels through portals using dropped and crafted "Cards" (as in like playing cards) that take you to different procedural generated realms (based on card type). You can always fast travel back to your base so exploring is encouraged and part of the game play.  As of this writing it's an early access game meaning we have access to play an unfinished product. (Sadly, many seem to not understand this which seem to be reflected in their poorly opinionated reviews).

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
The game is a survival game so has the typical survival elements of gathering, crafting, base building. and combat. 

[h1]CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION[/h1]
The character creator allows for a wide variety of faces, skin tones and hair styles. You can make some butt ugly characters (of course beauty is in the eye of the beholder), but if you spend the time (those who moan about "ugly characters" clearly do not spend the time) you can make some "beautiful" males and females in game. I really like the character creator. I hope we see a barbershop in the futuure.

There is currently no transmog in game. I hope this changes as a future addition to the game. My wife and I both like to customize our characters. 

[h1]GATHERING/CRAFTING[/h1]
The gathering is reasonably well done with trees falling after they are cut down, minerals/rocks smashing apart as you mine them. The crafting is layered and fairly deep, but not overly complicated. Different materials will craft better items and there seems to be good ranger of items to collect. I enjoy the crafting and the crafting stations. 

[h1]BASE BUILDING[/h1]
The base building is nice with a pretty straightforward UI for putting down base "blocks". The base parts are a full wall height so they take up a larger space meaning you can make a room with 6 blocks. A floor tile, 4 walls and ceiling. You can navigate in this space, but this is done easier in 1st person. It does not take too many base parts to build a functional and good looking base due to the nice graphics of the game and the textures.

Speaking of 1st person. The game was originally built for 1st person only, but due to player request 3rd person was implemented. 3rd is not as polished as 1st due to it being a fresher implementation. Its not bad, but it could use work as there is some minor clipping with base parts.

I enjoy 3rd person, but 1st person is really the best option for survival base building games. I wont get into why because this involves game theory regarding how a player navigates inside of a space and that is not the scope of this review, but regardless of how you choose to play, both work well. 

[h1]COMBAT[/h1]
The combat is ok, its not the best, but its not the worst. I would like to see some work regarding combat, but at the same time it has not stopped me from enjoying playing the game.  I also imagine combat gets better as you unlock some weapons and rifles, shotguns etc. I am using a mining pick mostly to fight right now.

You can also enchant your gear which can affect how you engage in combat. 

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
I am around 70 hours at the time of this review. I have played most of it with my wife and both of us have really enjoyed our time. We both feel we have our monies worth at this point in time, so I see no reason at all not to give a good review. 

If you enjoy survival and Gaslamp fantasy/Steampunk and or the Victorian era, I think you will definitely enjoy your time in game. Its a diamond in the rough, but has a solid foundation and I can see it going places.

If you like Survival + Base Building + playing in a small group = you will kinda like this game.

In generall i recommend this game as an EARLY ACCEESS Release for under 30 bucks, but you need to see it as that.

It is in Early Access and the Dev's explicitly said the wanna advance the game based on player feedback,
so im finding it interesting that people who didnt even play the game for 20 hrs without even seeing the start of the current end-game content and already come to conclusions about the whole game.

Technical:
First of all, technically besides a few disconnects and a few minor bugs it is one of the better online game releases that did not have massive server issues in the first few days.

Online:
The forced online nature is part of the game since it is a co-op/group game that isnt at its current state to be played completely solo, especially later in the game. But the Devs already took feedback and working on a offline version.

The Worlds: 
You only have 3 Biomes to start, a few Major Cards to set the difficulty and the general tone of the worlds.
After you get into that world you have a lot of Modification Cards that mostly change the playe/crafting stats or change the world entirely.
Only one of this modification cards can be active at once. This leaves you with around 12ish more or less individual worlds in the early game with some differences in creatures/nature or visual.

World activities:
These are based on the World you choose with your cards, but agreed are pretty repetitive after a few hours.
This consist out of sequence and search puzzles, defense and enemie camp combat activies, rare animal hunts and help on building npc housing. 

Creatures:
Also based on the choosen world, mostly biome, these are also pretty repetitive.
Only real exception are the boss monsters you can find in special hunt worlds, which are a bit more challenging.
The same goes for dungeons you can embark later on in the game.

The Crafting: 
You have to choose a recipe, then fill it with the ingredients, then click to start crafting.
Sometimes you also need to fuel and light up a fire in addition. This seems tedious until you realize that in the game there are different levels and stats for ingredients. So a Fur from a simple boar is different from a Fur from a rare mythical creature.
If you use the rare one in your recipes the result has better stats upon them. In addition crafting tables can be affected by upgrades placed in their vicinity by either unlocking new recipes or improving the outcome.

Building:
The game has a blueprint system, so you can plan your base completely before starting to build,
the choices are very limitied in the early game and more building types and architecture is unlocked at a later part of the game,
therefore early bases feel like makeshift block huts not like real homes with more artistic freedom.
A nice touch here are extensions for crafting tables that sometimes fit the table (like a hanging pan would fit in a kitchen) and do actually have an impact to the crafting and are not just aesthetic.

Combat/Movement:
The Movement in the game feels really nice and going to combat, the animations feel nice also the feedback for hits is there but could need some small improvements to just get a little bit more *umph*. You tend to just buttonsmash attacks until you are out of stamina, then notice you are out and go back to regain stamina and repeat. This changes with the first guns and boss monsters where you get more into acutally aiming for headshots.

Dungeons:
Later in the game you can kinda unlock worlds with dungeons or go from a hub world directly into ones, These are definitly more challenging with bigger enemy groups and boss monsters with a loooooot of health. Here again seems to be an opportunity to improve bossmonsters with more complexity like multiple phases in combat.

Since there is no official roadmap and the devs announced they will go for feedback of players, this could go really positive or bad based on what their takes are from that feedback.
I personally like the looks and the general feel of this game and i'm eager to see not only the full end-game but also having everything base building related unlocked.
Most of the improvements i could think of for this game are UX related:
Crafting -> Prefill resources after choosing a recipe, maybe get the closest chest as target/source?
Building -> Easier to find out which extensions benefit which crafting tables.
Quests and NPC -> If you dont read like reading tons of text, these feel dull and more in the background then they should be. The main quests are what are driving the progress for your character.
Tutorial -> A lot more needs to be explained, starts with certain UI Elements like bottom left (Bars and Buffs) and right (Actions) to general shortcut usage (hold E for Area pickup?). Also things like Extensions for Crafting tables are not really explained.
Some UI -> Comparing Cards or remembering which are major/minor cards could be improved. 
Generally to have some sort of notebook you can right your own notes in would be nice and fitting for the setting.

Of course expanding the game in general with more biomes and creatures and activities will be the key for this game to be a success.
