I've followed the development of Nightingale for a few years now, i love the lore, the setting and the gaslamp exploration fantasy that it promises, i purchased on day of release and have sunk a good 24 hours into the game at this point. 

Is this a perfect game at this current stage? absolutely not, is the potential there for this to become something that really scratches that survival itch that I've been looking for, yes absolutely. 

The environment and the lore are compelling the graphics are excellent and all the key survival metrics are there. There's almost certainly room for improvement in quality of life but for an EA title there's lots of content to be getting on with.

I love the flexibility the portal system offers us and the different variations that are possible at the EA stage, i can't wait to see what biomes we get in the future and the thrill of exploration is all there. 

The modular nature of the fae ruins the game offers us really shows a lot of promise and you can see the devs have given themselves a lot of leg room in ensuring they can really diversify and expand on these in the future to give us even more interesting content. 

After playing with a friend I'm really looking forward to exploring together and experiencing the challenges/dungeons that Nightingale offers.

I like that the game doesn't hold my hand (that does come with some slight caveats, see below).

While i understand the common complaint around the "always online" aspect of the game, this really doesn't bother me personally. 

My main gripes so far are:

Storage doesn't link up to crafting, so you need to pull items out of storage and into your inventory to craft.

Upgrading buildings, having to demolish then rebuild your base is tedious, just give us the ability to upgrade existing structures with new materials/patterns.

Follower AI is frustrating and followers in general at the moment are lifeless automatons for carrying stuff and soaking up enemy blows. Also issuing them orders and telling them NOT to use my stored lumber for 

The UI could do with some significant quality of life upgrades as it's not entirely clear or easy to understand certain aspects of it (for example completing challenges rewards you with essences? who knew!?)

In general the enchantment, charm, infusion system isn't very well explained so i had to figure a lot of this out via trial and error. 

We are aware of different factions but they feel like placeholders at the moment, i'd hope for the future the devs are looking to expand this area significantly, with faction specific rewards etc to give us a reason to care about/interact with these different groups. 

A lack of voice acting, a minor gripe i know but it would just help breathe some life into the different realmwalkers/factions you meet.

Inventory management could be significantly improved, there has to be a better way of categorising resources so that different variations of the same type don't take up valuable storage slots.

Spicing up the enemy models also wouldn't go a miss.

All in these are minor gripes and I'm loving the time i'm spending in Nightingale, i cannot wait to see how this game develops over EA and i would absolutely recommend purchasing especially at its current price point.

First off, I don't care that this game is always online, but as someone who plays almost exclusively solo, I do care if the online doesn't work well. There seems to be a misconception that people hate always online and that's the reason for the bad reviews, but it's simply not true. The issue is mainly that the online is just annoying. Loading between realms takes around 2 minutes which isn't game breaking, but it's annoying. I have this game installed on a SSD, but every single time you spend 2-3 minutes waiting on server... While I find the various online issues really annoying, I don't think they warrant a negative review, especially since the devs have announced that they plan to add an offline mode. 

To be clear, I didn't give this game a bad review because of the online, although I think it's a fair reason to give a negative review since it affects people's ability to play the game. 

Now, let me explain why I'm giving this game a bad review. But first, let me tell you what's good about the game. 

This game is beautiful and the backstory is really interesting. The creatures are cool and the crafting is extremely indepth. Seriously, the crafting gives you a lot of ways to customize the stats of almost every item. I also like the way the building system works. You can place phantom designs and then fill them with mats when you have them. Also, you can move already built structures, this includes chests with items in them, THANK GOD. I mean this is amazing. Have you ever played a survival game and had to first take out all the items from a chest before moving the chest? It's awful right! Well in this game, you can just move the chest with all the items inside. 

Speaking of good stuff, the survival mechanics are actually pretty good. They're what you'd expect from a survival game, but adds a little depth to them without making them too complicated. 

Now, the reason for the bad review....

1) Repetition. Unfortunately, this game is really really repetitive. Survival games tend to have a loop, but this game's loop is unfortunately kind of bland and copy-pasted. Most survival games have you grind materials from biome 1 to go to biome 2. Then you grind upgraded versions of your tools and go to biome 3, then to biome 4, then biome 5, then biome 6 and so on. Each biome is usually different and completely unique to the last. 

This game does the same thing, but it only has 3 biomes, and you see all the different biomes within the tutorial. They try to vary this experience by making biomes randomly procedurally generated so each time is unique, but it just isn't that unique. The forest is still the forest and the desert is still the desert. After tier 1, you're just looping back to forest/desert/swamp over and over again. 

Speaking of repetitiveness, you have to complete point of interests to get currency to buy recipes for the next tier. But the POI's are all basically the same and a lot of them are just kind of meh where you kill 1 wave of braindead AI or press 3 switches sitting next to each other to solve a puzzle. None of them really feel unique to the biomes and after you've done a couple, you've seen it all, even if the format is very slightly changed. 

2) Crafting is TEDIOUS. The crafting is really indepth which is cool, but my god is it tedious. You have raw mats which have various different types and tiers for the same basic raw mat. Then you need to craft it into a basic ingredient to craft other stuff, but you have tons of different work benches and everything takes quite a lot of real time to craft. There's not crafting from storage so you're constantly looking through hundreds of different mats to find what you want, and then when you find the raw mat that you want, you need to find all the other raw mats too bc each of the same raw mat gives different attributes. 

Like I said, the crafting is really indepth and awesome, but it's just not streamlined and it's a serious pain in the ass at the moment. The crafting and inventory management is such a chore that it often fatigues me while i'm trying to craft stuff and I just take a break from the game for a while. 

3) Combat is extremely MEH. The combat is bland. The ai is bad, you don't need to block or dodge, you can simply just strafe and backstep and never get hit. It's also just really simple, you swing until you don't have stamina, and then just strafe/backstep until you have it again. The only time you might die is when there is a swarm of enemies, simply bc you might get hit from the side or something. Combat is a little more fun like this but you rarely run into swarms of enemies. Also, the combat just doesn't feel responsive. The feedback from getting hit just doesn't feel like much and the attack feedback, especially for headshots feels extremely arcadey, it's kind of a weird and out of place.

People seem to like the ranged combat, but so far I'v found ranged combat kind of boring. I think the heartshots for animals is extremely awesome, but other than that it's just slow, clunky, and doesn't feel that great.

4) Bugs. I know it's Early access, but there are some gamebreaking bugs that just suck. I almost refunded the game when I first started because I couldn't finish the tutorial due to a glitch where the final portal doesn't work. While I wouldn't really care about that, apparently this bug was fairly well known and common in earlier betas before the game released into Early access and it just wasnt' fixed. 

Some of this stuff can be fixed like adding new biomes to the game, but I feel like some things like combat, repetitive point's of interest, and crafting might not really improve that much. 

The game has opened up and become a little more fun after unlocking the first new tier of realms, but also, it kind of sheds like on the repetitiveness of the game. I have high hopes for this game, but I think it's really undercooked. 

My recommendation is wait to buy. Give it 1-2 years and see how the devs respond to feedback and expand the game.

I want to begin by acknowledging that many negative reviews focus on a single aspect of the game: the requirement for always-online connectivity. I'd like to address this briefly because the developer has already responded to this concern. They've announced their commitment to delivering an offline option as quickly as possible. You can read their statement here: https://playnightingale.com/news/offline-play .This proactive response within just two days of early access demonstrates their receptiveness to feedback and their dedication to resolving issues promptly.

Now, onto my review, which will also include a couple of suggestions. I'm thoroughly enjoying the game and eagerly anticipate the improvements that will come during early access!

Tutorial: The tutorial is decent, although not exceptional. While it succeeds in teaching the basics, it could benefit from tweaks to enhance the overall experience. For instance, having Puck move with you while explaining concepts would be more engaging. His interesting dialogue could be better utilized if he led players to relevant locations rather than delivering information in one spot. Additionally, implementing a system where quest objectives are automatically checked off upon completion would streamline gameplay.

Combat: I haven't played enough to form a definitive opinion, but the combat seems promising based on the limited encounters I've had.

Umbrella Mechanics: The concept of how the umbrellas work is intriguing. Despite initial skepticism about the "Mary Poppins" aspect, using the umbrellas proved to be enjoyable and added depth to gameplay. The idea of them assisting players in various weather conditions and then floating around adds an innovative mechanic to the game.

Server and Graphical Performance: I've experienced no server or graphical issues, which is a relief in 2024, considering many new games have been plagued by such problems, often due to unexpectedly high player counts.

Character Creator: Personally, I'm not deeply invested in creating characters. Typically, I'll lightly craft a character resembling myself, then dive into the game. However, I must say there's certainly room for improvement with the current character creator. I'm honestly not the person to give advice when it comes to character but id probably start with the lineage part being described better so i understand that i will be using my parents likeness to craft my characters.

Price: At $35 for an early access game, it's honestly pretty standard these days. However, considering the potential of this game and my confidence in the studio to see it through, I personally consider it a steal of a deal.

Building: I'm absolutely loving the crafting and building mechanics! Planning out the floor plan before construction and the smooth snapping of pieces are fantastic features. I'm eagerly anticipating the opportunity to construct even larger structures soon!

In summary, I genuinely enjoy the game and plan to continue playing it extensively. It's a great early access title, and I believe the developers are moving in the right direction, especially demonstrated by their responsiveness to offline mode.

Nightingale is a game with an enchanting aesthetic that immediately draws you into its world. From the moment you step into its beautifully crafted environments, you're greeted with stunning visuals and atmospheric music that immerse you in a captivating fantasy realm. However, beneath its picturesque surface lies a game still in its infancy, grappling with numerous shortcomings that prevent it from reaching its full potential.

One of the most glaring issues with Nightingale is its early stage of development, evident in the myriad of missing quality of life features. Players will find themselves yearning for basic conveniences that are standard in most modern games. The absence of these features disrupts the flow of gameplay and detracts from the overall experience.

Combat in Nightingale feels clunky and unrefined, lacking the fluidity and responsiveness expected in action-oriented games. Engaging in battles often feels like a chore rather than an exhilarating experience, dampening the excitement of exploration and progression.

The building mode, touted as a cornerstone of the gameplay experience, falls disappointingly short of expectations. Its simplicity limits creativity and fails to offer the depth and complexity necessary to engage players for extended periods.

Character animations are another area where Nightingale falters. Characters move stiffly and lack the lifelike fluidity that breathes personality and charm into their actions. Instead, they stand static, devoid of the soul and expression that would otherwise bring them to life.

Adding insult to injury, Nightingale lacks essential features such as an offline mode and servers in all regions. Players from South America are forced to connect to North American servers, resulting in frustratingly high ping and subpar gameplay experiences.
EDIT: They've added South America and Oceania servers a couple days after the early access was released. 

Despite its myriad flaws, Nightingale shows promise. There's ample room for improvement, and with dedicated effort from the development team, it has the potential to evolve into a truly exceptional game. As it stands, however, Nightingale falls short of its lofty ambitions, leaving players longing for the polish and refinement needed to fulfill its promise. If you're willing to overlook its current shortcomings and hopeful for future updates, Nightingale may yet prove to be a diamond in the rough.

Rating: 6/10

You see the cool game in the store page videos? Yeah I have no idea where that game is, because I've played almost 20 hours and that game is nowhere in sight. I'm still playing a generic survival game that doesn't have any of this "Gaslamp Fantasy" aesthetic.

I unlock the ability to level up my gear score so that I can finally reach Generic NPC # 28, who will send me to another place I've already been so that I can finally be "allowed" to do the second tier of items, which can then be upgraded, which then artificially unlocks the zone that allows me to reach Generic NPC #29.

When I say "artificially," I mean the game WILL NOT LET YOU PROGRESS until you've checked the appropriate boxes. Imagine that you're playing Minecraft and you start with the ability to make wood tools, but the game won't let you make stone tools. Then once you have those stone tools, a barrier that prevents you from accessing the only cave that contains copper vanishes and you can finally mine copper, but before you can turn it into copper tools you need to spend another 4 hours doing NPC favors, then you unlock the recipe.

That's Nightingale, but for literally every aspect of the game.

Its taken me a while to figure out why this intriguing game bores me. That's because the writing in this game is great but core gameplay is a letdown. In practice, I've spent 90% of my playtime time grinding stingy resources to overcome arbitrary progress gates; rather than fighting, exploring, talking to cool fey, or having fun.

The failure of this game's design is simple - when I find some cool new rock to smash and I get that lovely new unobtainium in my inventory.... NOTHING HAPPENS.

Nightingale's mechanics are not actually about discovery and exploration. They're about buying unlocks from the vendor to use that cool rock. Then grinding resources to craft the stuff. Then grinding essence to go back to the vendor to buy the next tool I need.

This means that, when I explore, I mostly find things I can't access or utilize. Its a perpetual train of disappointments. For, to enjoy these discoveries, I have to buy the right whatever from a vendor, farm the reagents, and craft whatever is needed. Repeat a lot just to get to the fun part of the game... which I've yet to find because I gave up after the 3rd loop to the vendor for like 5 more crafting tables.

How'd someone make getting a new crafting table feel like acquiring a second job? IDK but Nightingale achieved this.

The shoe is on the wrong foot here. Exploration requires supplies and risk, so it should have rewards. Picking up that new rock should open possibilities for me. Not just be some dead weight in my inventory and a "come back to work in these mines later" pin later on my map.

There's a lot of potential in this game from the writing to the story and the solid combat. Graphics are good. Animations are good too. Environmental considerations like water, sun, and cold are well-done touches on the survival genre. But the core design decisions here make me question if the devs known what fun is. Someone is too into crafting simulators and not enough into filching power from the realms of infinite imagination. 

Which is why I don't recommend this game.

158948985.review:
Nightingale had a lot of hype building it up and I was very hyped too. They hyped it as if it was going to be fully released and not Early Access, not complaining but a bit disappointed. IMO, it was overly hyped. That being said, as I was very excited for Nightingale, has it delivered? I can't say for sure, but to me I'm neutral about the game. Why? The screenshots and trailers make it out to be so much more than meets the eye. The things you see in the screenshots and trailer are to attract you; however, you will not see that type of gameplay for a LONG TIME. The grind would be so much better if there was more going on in between the game to make it more enjoyable.

I'm 10 hours in and I feel like I haven't progressed at all, still chopping away with simple weapons & armor.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
Nightingale is in horrible need of a QOL update and lacks a lot of BASIC mechanics with Building, Follower AI, storage, crafting, etc. You're going to spend a large amount of time grinding through a beautiful world with linear quests, and those quests are the only way to progress, instead of progressing freely like in most survival crafting games. I'd only recommend if you enjoy a huge, easy and long grind.

[h1] EDIT [/h1]
Almost 20 hours in and I'm seeing some difficulty increase. This feels like an MMO, holy. At least I'm losing health and fights are starting to pick up. Enemy AI is still bad though. I ended up removing the AI follower since I don't need 'em anymore. I'm at gear score 87 and finally got to the point where item Tier is changing and higher level materials are useful. I was stuck for a very long time due to a progression quest that wants you to shoot animals in the heart (heartshot) and it took so long. I eventually went back to my realm after an hour of trying and got a heartshot on a boar and a wolf. I had to stealth to do it too. Very redundant quest. Anyway, I'll update as I go.

[h1] Review [/h1]
I have an open mind when it comes to Early Access. I haven't come across anything besides one crash and some minor lag spikes here and there. No issues with coop, servers, etc. Although, I really feel some of the things added within the game was not thoroughly created very well. For example, a lot of things are missing more (refer to Building and Follower AI). I also see almost everything shown about the game having third person, there's even a third person fov slider but yet no key-binding for third person.

[h2] Major Complaint [/h2]
"Waiting for server" takes forever between realm load times. Not sure why this game needs a game server when it's online coop, not an Online MMO.
The Quest System. As you know in most Survival Crafting games you have freedom to do what you will. In Nightingale the Questing is basically your progression. I want to be thrown into an open world survival crafting experience to do what I want, not what the quests want me to do when it comes to progression. I want to explore, unlock progression materials or items by myself -- not through a game's questing system. You have the freedom to do a lot, but you're limited on progression until you follow the questline. Big disappointment from me as I don't feel the freedom like I do in most open world survival crafting games.

HUGE Bug when going to or from realms: I lost all of my items (not gear) when going through a portal to another realm. I lost a lot of time in progression because of this. Not sure how such an important feature like going to other realms has this major bug with losing items.

Running/Walking Simulator: You will be running a LOT. Realms aren't too big but they can become big when you're going from one POI to another.

[h2] World [/h2]
The world is beautiful. Atmosphere is most definitely there. Gathering, chopping, crafting and mining is very satisfying.

[h2] Difficulty [/h2]
So far I'm not seeing any challenge to the game. Enemies are easy and their behavior is very dumb.

[h2] Building [/h2]
Very basic. There's also no "destroy" button after placing an object down. Only thing good about building is the mass "add resources" to build everything at once.

[h2] POIs and Events [/h2]
Each POI is the same in every realm. Nothing really special except the chests. Honestly, it seems added as a filler to unlock certain things like POT PLANT or CANDLE for your house. They aren't too worth doing unless you think you're going to get a card from one.

[h2] Combat & Enemies [/h2]
Combat is pretty basic from what I've seen. Nothing that stands out. Hit enemy, block their attack, eliminate, done. There's quite a lot of different types of enemies, but they aren't all that hyped up to be anything majorly different. Early bosses and AI are underwhelming.

[h2] Realms / Cards [/h2]
You can create realms, explore and do random POI events. I'm not seeing too many BIG things going to different realms. I'm only 10 hours in so I'm hoping I unlock newer things that spices up realms. 

Cards seem cool. Some cards you can add buffs to realms to make something spawn more, etc. Neat idea.

[h2] Item System [/h2]
I'm not really understanding the item system. When you, for example, kill an animal and the fur has "Maximum Stamina: +10%" and to craft an item with it, it doesn't apply the stamina. I did it with fur that had Health and it actually worked, but it was only 3 HP so it wasn't at all worth it. I feel early game you skip literally trying to gear out how you want and just progress. I'm honestly not a fan of the different types of Tier items. The main issue with this system is you cannot combine two different furs to craft an item, when you need that item now -- have to go out and farm more.

[h2] Stats, Food and Sleep [/h2]
The worst thing you're going to run into is Stamina issues right away. Lack of sleep or no appropriate food to keep your max stamina up. Food system is basically Valheim's food system. Eat certain foods they give you HP or Stamina. It becomes a nuisance after awhile having to constantly keep the food buffs going.

[h2] Follower AI [/h2]
There's no way to change the behavior of your recruits or "followers". They'll chop trees everywhere for no reason so watch out if your base is surrounded by trees. They'll pick items up but it seems no limit to their encumberment. The only thing they're good for is to be bait when killing enemies or bosses. To be fair, they make it too easy because their AI is so dumb. If they go down it takes one click to revive them with full HP (which to me is very cheaty).

[h2] Vendors [/h2]
There's vendors across the world so you can purchase upgrades from them. The main issue with the merchants is everything is too damn cheap. We're grinding hard in this game and I feel the merchants were added as a weird filler to have in the game.

[h2] Crafting [/h2]
Crafting is there. You don't unlock things fast so you normally look at the same stuff for awhile until you progress. I feel as if they could've handled managing everything better. Like, there's no quick buttons for adding fuel to anything, quick crafting, etc.

The thing I dislike the most is the storage doesn't show resources you can craft. You need the items in your inventory to craft them. This won't make much sense if you aren't at your base, but if I'm at my base at least show items I can craft with that's in storage.

[h2] Armor, Buffs, etc [/h2]
Not fully understanding this system. Infusion, armor enchantments/enhancements seems REALLY pointless in the early game. The stats are minimal from these items. I guess I'll wait til I'm at guns and stuff before writing more about this.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
Overly hyped. It's not a "too early for Early Access", it's right at "if they gave it another year the game would probably be ready". I /like/ the game, but I feel like I only enjoy it because I want to reach end-game so badly. The grind is ridiculous. Feels like I'm playing Project Zomboid or 7 days to die when it comes to grind, but I feel like I can progress in those games faster.

158872768.review:
My wife picked me up this game cause she thought it would be fun to play together. I hopped in and worked my way through the tutorial and some early game, but let me start at the beginning.

1. The character creation (though still in early access version) is really cool. You can use a genealogy tree to create a grid of facial features to "inherit" characteristics from and then further tweak the player design. Some might say the faces are a bit weird, but I can't help but get a very nostalgic Fable (Lionhead Studios) vibe from it and I can't overstate how nice it is to see a character creation that "feels different" given the amount of copy-paste creators there are out there (Palworld anyone?). This already told me the folks at Inflexion want to stand out from the first minute you get in.

2. Holy moly, creepy Fae contract feels in the tutorial. How cool is it I'm being riddle speaked by a Fae representative as I jump through gorgeous portal landscapes?! I usually hate tutorial sections, but this one totally caught me by surprise. I mean, yes, I was doing the usual "and now we craft a knife" but the way the game isn't holding my hand and my goodness the voice acting is Shakespearean intense! I did some googling and "Puck" (your Fae guardian) is voiced by Marc Warren from Johnathan Strange & Mr. Norrell who played the fae villain in that TV series (awesome show btw, if you haven't seen it, go do yourself a favour and watch it). Anyways, the narration for the tutorial is amazing, you'll know what I mean when you hear it.

In other respects, the tutorial also refreshingly doesn't treat you like a child. If you're well versed in survival games, it's nice to not feel like you're being baby-stepped through everything, there are clear "todos" and you can rapidly skip dialogue if you get bored with the progress rate. The enemies you get introduced to learn combat on are no slouch, but are still easy, you figure out the basic side step dodging and slashing mechanics and see a few different enemy movement patterns. The fact there are evil things that come out of the portals and attack you as you traverse is cool and keeps the tension up.

3. Random worlds with actual locations of interest. This was seriously the main attraction even just in the tutorial areas. There are cool things to go explore and look at. You're going to want to climb on everything and make a torch pronto. The points of interest are a lot more than the usual "Minecraft mod inserts a pre-made dungeon" thing or a Valheim "troll cave". They feel way more organic, like a tower in the swamp with remnants of human inhabitants that once lived there, supplies and other items withering to the sands of time waiting for someone like you to come upon. The lore just seeps out of these locations and surrounding areas, I haven't felt this excited to explore since Valheim came out. Honestly, also, this game has Valheim beat in the "prettiness" category, this game is frigging gorgeous.

4. NPCs and spawns interacting with the world. First thing I saw when I got into the desert was that a tree spriggan creature was walking around and it would make treant groans and plop out some sticks and branches onto the ground. The creatures were literally doing things to change the world. Later on, there is literally a forest spirit that goes full on Princess Mononoke and "summons" life out of the ground, bushes and other growth spawns as it travels around. How frigging cool is that for a terrain respawn mechanic?!

5. Finding merchants to unlock new recipes. This is a neat mechanic where you trade essences you get while gathering, crafting, building that forces builders to get out and explore to find traders to unlock new blueprints. I like that this adds a bit of interaction and changes it up for builder focused players who can get caught up in the "harvest and design" grind. Good excuse to leave the camp and go try to unlock new things. Reminds me of trying to find the two dwarves in Valheim, but with more variety at play here.

6. Ease of getting into the game and joining others. I know a lot of folks would prefer private servers and don't get me wrong, I'm a software engineer and have run more than my fair share of private game servers in my day, but I do really think that overall, Inflexion has made the right call here. For every full fledged private Minecraft server, there are countless "on demand" (Realms) servers made for instant play between "Mom/Dad and the kids + friends". It's seamless and gets you and friends together in a world quickly. That's no easy feat and props to Inflexion for having all that infra up from day 1 of early access. I'm sure there will be other modes in future, but for now, the fact it exists at all, to this level is impressive to say the least.

Either way, I'm thoroughly enjoying my first few hours and I have to say, they really found a way to hook you into this game. The lore, the vibe, it all feels really unique and I'm getting that "the devs really care a lot about this art piece of a project" feel. It's the same way I felt when I jumped into Valheim or Baldur's Gate 3. There is just a feeling you get when you can tell the people making it really care.

Way to go Inflexion, excited to see how this all pans out, I'm in.

Posting this on the day of launch in an attempt to counteract the blithering idiots review-bombing an online-only game for being online-only.  Yes, there are some server hiccups when transitioning between realms and I've had to sit through a couple more loading screens than I might have if the game had an offline mode. If you look beyond these petty complaints you'll find an original approach to solving the problem of allowing a player to build a glorious home base without requiring them to travel ever further in search of adventure. The portal system allows you to dial up the biome and difficulty you need to progress, get your loot, and easily find your way straight back to your base.  You actually get to *explore* in this game.  Movement mechanics are interesting, enemy design and environmental design are on point, and the bits of story you get- written or delivered through Puck's excellent vocal performance - are unique and well-written.

Definitely well worth a look if you enjoy survival, exploration, and base building.

I feel like it is time to address the review culture around this game, which is indeed a bit harsh and almost held me from playing a game i enjoy playing a lot. Also i have to add that i am not married to or related to a dev of this game in any way.

For starters i have to say that i am a Relic of a time where a game worth 30 bucks offered a campaign that lasted 25 hours and then just was over and the only thing you could do was to play it again. 10-15 years ago we considered this fine because 25 hours of entertainment were worth 30 bucks, when you go to the cinema you get 2 hours for 10 bucks and you would not complain about the value you get right there.

Today's Generation views things a lot different, i unfortunetaly read too many steam reviews recently and too often came over the fact that people nowadays play videogames for 50+ hours and then give them a thumbs down complaining about systems that are not convenient enough, the amount of content being limited and the pace of the game being to slow/ not rewarding fast enough. I am not very conform with this Culture.

For Nightingale special i really wanted to address this, because somewhere inside of me i knew this is exactly the type of game i would enjoy right now, while the reviews held me from buying it on release day. 

And thats exactly the first point i will address: why do people bother to make a rant in a steam review of a game which is obviously not the type of game they are looking for/ enjoy playing as their comfort game if their opinion is not product of false expectations or even meant in a destructive rather than constructive way? 

And then there is those who repeatedly start their arguments by saying something like ,,i know that this is a early access, but´´, and then in the rest of the argument completely ignore the fact that this is a early access...? Again i sort this a similar way as the first point, this type of argumentation seems not to meet realistic expectations of the product nor being meant constructive and only constructive.

Fortunately i am here to tell you what type of game this is, so you can build an idea if this is for you or not, and summarize some of the usefull criticisms to give you a realistic expectation of the product in its current state.

Please when considering to play this game note the fact that this is graphically a very advanced game and you will need to have a decent PC to get a smooth performance out of it. That said the graphics of this Game are stunning and the different seeds that are generated through cards you combine freely are stunning as well. The only thing i would critic about its visual immersion right now is that the creatures filling this world often move a bit clunky or even stutter through the world breaking the immersion of your surroundings a decent bit, This is something the devs can improve in the future.
Still the world and its immersion are beautiful.

This is a slow paced soft-core survival game centered around a crafting system with its strength being its complexity, while its weakness right now being its inconvenience in some points due to missing systems as well as a sometimes unhandy User Interface. Still the foundations of it being complex in a good way if you like and enjoy complex crafting systems.
You have to manage quiet a big amount of resources and different crafting recipes, this is something you need to be liking to be able to enjoy the fundamental part of Nightingale, i consider this a strength if you do so. 

In its current state you have to open different menus sometimes a bit often too look after things you need to have in mind for one single recipe which can be addressed by the devs in upcoming patches to make the crafting experience a bit more convenient, as well as this game needs a system that draws items automaticly out of chests in the area from any crafting station for any recipe. I see these as the easier points to address for the devs in the future.

The amount of Content of this game is quiet surprising and a big pro for a game being in early access still testing its foundations. You come to the point where you build a portal into your base if you want so and freely explore worlds that are based on the cards you combine creating them, and there are a lot of combinations possible. You can sink a ton of hours of your lifetime in this game if you want so, on that front the 30 bucks pricing is easily justified.

All in all i can say if you like slow paced exploring and progressing through a game, this might be for you.
If you like complex crafting systems always taking you to read through a lot of stuff and hunting for specific resources then this might be for you.
If you are immersed by graphically stunning and and creative world building and enjoy even just walking around finding places that let you forget reality then this might just be for you.
And if none of that describes the type of game you enjoy playing then why in the world would i recommend this to you? Well i cant answer that...

Yes, this is a early access and there are things the devs can improve on almost every front, but that does not make it a bad game in general, at this point i have to contradict the reviews picturing this as a disappointing product in general.

Having an average score of 6 on steam right now i dont feel like the product is in the position it deserves, considering the argumentation against the review culture i just submitted. Still this is subjective in many ways.

I personally would give it a solid 7,5 out of 10, with the potential to climb to an even higher rating with small improvements on its Systems and UI, as well as through adding content in the future.

04/02/2024 Early access.  I've played it a fair amount. I enjoy it as well. The game is early access at the initial time of review.  The game is a PVE survival game, sort of open wold.  The game does require online play, so if you are stuck in a snowstorm and your Fiber optic ATT service is down, or your cable company internet is down, you just don't get to play. 

I play with my wife and daughter, and it was bought for that purpose, primarily. The game is visually good, though graphically a little bit taxing on the systems.  Audio seems to be good. Game play gets a little rougher.  Combat is okay, nothing has stood out as spectacularly good or bad for combat.

Crafting system can be easy or complex depending on how min/max you are. That leaves going back to previously visited realms to gather resources, or to gather them as you go. If you go back to previously visited realms (note the game says you might not be able to go back when you leave, however, we have only been able to go back to the same realms we visited before, all of the realms seem to be instanced). If you gather them as you go you need to save them somewhere and that gets into the building system. You can only have 100 buildings, that isn't bad. Each building can only have 300 pieces. Every foundation, storage box, light, crafting bench and augmentation counts against that and you need different augmentations to be able to build different items.  I did not look it up for the review however, there are about 8-10 crafting and refining benches, and it looked like a number of them have 5 to 9 augmentation slots. so just for the crafting benches you are looking at  40-90 pieces just for crafting. It looks like you can't get all the augmentations onto a bench so you might be building multiple benches or playing whack-a-mole to move the right combinations of augmentations around to get things set up correctly and then move them around again for the next build.  The game is dark, so you are going to need 1-2 lights be foundation block size. Taking a reasonably sized 3x3 house so you can build a second story in the future if you want to, you are looking at a building with 9 foundations 9 ceiling tiles, 11 walls and 1 door.  30 pieces, plus crafting stations and augmentations and lights. add in storage and you'll easily get to 250 to 300 units for your structure.   Not a problem you are allowed 300, drawback, is the realm itself will only allow 350 units for the total realm. if we split them evenly we are looking at a central larger building that will have 200-300 units leaving each of us to build a house our of 50 units, maybe.  The building system needs to be fixed on that before I would recommend it for anyone other than a solo player.

There is a recruit NPC system, someone to help you. they can't help you with ranged combat, they can sort of help you with melee combat. They will attack the bad guys, often by jumping in front of your ranged attack, or melee swing preventing you from attacking the baddies. They will help you gather resources, like chopping down trees that will land on the structure you built or the Aid mission you need to complete.  If you are trying to gather resources and are weighed down, they will happily run away from you, leaving you to crawl at a snails pace while you try to catch up to their random movements.  Back to the Aid mission, they will take the high end materials that you are saving to build the better tools or weapons and give it away to other NPCs instead, or burn it for no extra benefit. Overall the best use of them is teleport into a realm, do the Aids and Defense missions, then recruit an npc, gather your resources now that they can't give them away, when you teleport back to your realm, ditch everything into chests and then dismiss them, so you don't have to deal with them again.

I do want to recommend this game, I just can't yet. I think it needs a few updates to the NPCs and the structures limits system before I would recommend it to anyone interested in anything other than solo play, and you have to play online so why bother with solo play. I look forward to those updates, and hope I can change the review to reflect a more finished product.

Just for reference I love Valheim and enjoy Enshouded so these are the bar I'm using. 

Nightingale is a beautiful game with some really interesting and fun components.  I think Combat is interesting and on par or better than most other survival games.  I also like how the building/crafting system has traits and enhancements that really flush out those systems.  The realm cards are also really nice and a very unique system that seems well thought out.

All of that said this game is not very well put together.   Each system itself is fairly well designed but the glue that puts all these systems together is slapped together in a very rough manner.  The Realms are nicely generated but resource nodes are pasted on with "Rocks" being a specific shape and any other rock looking scenery is not a rock.   Due to this issue Rock is only a little more common than most Ore and Crystals and to get any amount of any resource that is not wood requires a lot of running around.  The lack of destructible and mine-able terrain really comes out and is a major backslide from games like Valheim and Enshourded.  

The 'tech tree' is mostly on a purchased bases.  With all the crafting focused around the types of resources this feels like it doesn't really fit.  I feel like the Valheim tree flow (find components and you can make it) would work better, though I think a research table version (like in Raft) would smooth this out nicly.  

On top of all these design choices this game has a heavy online requirement.   Even the Tutorial levels take time to communicate online to change realms.   There is almost no reason for this to be online (other than anti-cheat).  I could somewhat ignore the online problem if I though this game was solid in its design.  However without an offline option I worry this game will not make enough money long term and one day will be the next news article about an online game closing and leaving its fans abandoned.  

There is a lot to like about Nightingale but at this time I don't think the overall design is going in a direction that will bring these awesome systems in a cohesive game that will entice people to keep playing and if people don't play then the game will not gain enough money to stay open and anyone backing this game will likely end up with a dead game that will not be usable in a few years.  I hope some of these core issues will get addressed in EA.  However these seem to be core and not unfinished options.  I hope I'm wrong becasue I really would like to see the unique systems in a game I enjoy playing.

160474277.review:
As of March 13, 2024 the game is pretty janky, so your tolerance for jank and bugs should be considered with this game

Nightingale is a Victorian Magic-punk survival game that leans heavily on exploration and combat. Combat is fairly standard in that you have damage types which are more or less effective based on your enemies. From hunting deer to chopping down living trees, there is a large spread of enemy variety. There is a hint of eldritch horror with many enemies as well which I hope they expand upon in the future.

The setting is quite unique. Historical figures like Bass Reeves and Nellie Blythe guide you through your travels of the fae realms. An apocalyptic event has severed the connection with Earth, and your mission is to find a way back. You'll use portals to teleport to new planes of existence, some of which are vibrantly beautiful. Each realm offering different challenges and resources for your character to collect.

This brings me to crafting, my personal favorite part of the game. While it currently has quite a bit of a work to be done regarding the UI and general ease of use, it is very deep. Each item is unlocked via a blueprint found or purchased from traders, and rather than being singular items, they are completely modular in stats and appearance. You can make a woodaxe out of trees and iron, or maybe you'd rather salvage the corpses of automatons and living trees. This changes both the appearance and statistics of the item. That depth applies not only to each piece of gear you use, but the clothes on your back, potions you drink, and food you eat.

An interesting story, solid gameplay, and in depth systems leads me to be quite excited about the future of this game. However, there is quite a bit of work to be done. There are confirmed issues of losing items, network instability, quests breaking, and over all general jank with the game. The main story is yet to be fully implemented, and it's unclear exactly how much is left to put in. If you're expecting a smooth and finished product, I don't recommend the game at the moment. However, the developers are quite responsive and open to suggestions, which gives me optimism for the future of the game moving forward.

159109539.review:
Objectively one of THE strongest introductions to any co-op survival game I have *ever* played. The customization, visual presentation and setting is 11 out of 10. I can't remember being this excited about a game in the first hours since... well, Baldur's Gate III. My heart and mind were blown the first night I spent maybe 6 hours straight in Nightingale, without sleeping, just being mind blown.

Now, with this said -- after about 50 hours, this game is a rough gem. The potential is above great, but there are a lot of tough obstacles in the way.

Setting and visuals - This is what this game does best. Everything from environments to creatures is just fantastic.
Sound design - Very, very good. The music is fantastic. The sound effects are impactful, eerie and beautiful.
Combat - Stable and functional but basic. The weapons and tools (yes, tools are as viable as weapons for combat) have a good FEEL to them. Hitting something with a maul feels bombastic. Slashing a crit is fun. Dodging is impactful and fast. However, there's a lot here that oculd be improved. Better enemy AI, more weapon types and moves, more magick.
Story - The main mission and storyline is, apart from the grinding, interesting and fun. Puck as a character is fantastic. Still, they could make mission points and info on what to do more clear. It starts out well, but eventually you will find yourself confused at certain stages. The other quests are lackluster. However, if they can pick up the other quests and NPC dialogues in the same voiced sense as Puck... then this could be great overall.
Crafting - Great potential. Rewarding, but clunky. There are a lot of quality of life things that could be improved here - especially a more traditional crafting journey (instead of essence traders being vital, and certain soft locks in the loop). Still, being able to plan out your constructions in blueprints is neat, and the stuff you craft in themselves are fun, visually striking and nice overall. This - along with combat and quests - are what I think needs most attention in the next steps.
Worlds: The realm system is creative and works really well so far. Being able to customize and change realms is fun and keeps things fresh. The realms themselves are GORGEOUS and full of... well, very interesting things that could be so much more.

I feel this is one of the strongest launches in terms of what this game could be, in years. The world carries so much feels and settings, but it's still so early that after a certain amount of time you run out of content. The worlds are amazing at first, but in "late game" (30/40+ hrs or so I reckon) you start to see how empty many things are. A lack fo NPC:s, quests, a fully realized crafting system and basic combat keeps Nightingale from being truly, truly great.

It's on its way, hopefully. WIth polish and much more content, this could seriously be the new Skyrim. That's how strong I think the foundation is. Hopefully the team keeps working on it, despite mixed responses!

Long story short, the paradox is that the game is marketed as the endless wonder of exploration through amazing fey landscapes, but the gameplay seems to assume that players are driven by wanting incremental stat increases on gear, and that the gameplay of grinding resources to achieve that.

Might change my review later if the game improves (given that it's early access), but as of now I recommend waiting for more development before getting the game.

Right now the gameplay loop is very boring. Gather stuff to make the same tools/types of tools and gather different versions of the same stuff in the same ways. This is to say that as the game gets into higher levels, nothing changes with how you actually play the game, there's nothing new - it's just more of the same.

The element that drew me in - exploration - is unsatisfied, as each 'realm' is basically just a recolour of all the other realms. Once you've played the tutorial you've basically seen what there is to see.

Combat is clunky and unsatisfying, requiring little to no skill and changing very little based on weapon choice.

Character and enemy AI is bad, and verging on a lazy 'out-of-the-box unreal-engine basic'.

Dialogue and story were interesting in theory but got old super quickly as it's mostly delivered as a lot of text or really long segments of speech that fully interrupt the action if you want to engage with them.

For a game about grinding resources, inventory management and QOL features (like crafting from chests) has been ignored, making sorting boxes of junk half the time you will spend in-game. Honestly Pal World has more QOL features in it and the devs could take a few notes.

160392311.review:
Nightingale was a game I was looking forward to since it was first announced. The game trailers looked more promising than the actual game itself. However, this game is still early access so by no means does this review solidify anything until it is fully released. I may change my opinion after but that depends.
So really this game atm just weighs out in pros and cons so…

Pros:

The game is beautiful. The graphics looked pretty solid and the realms were very detailed even down to the very sound of the environment. Honestly that transition from day to night is outstanding; the night sky is beautifully surreal. The swamp area was swampy: you could hear the mosquitoes and you could feel the stickiness of the muddy waters. The forest was relaxing: you could hear the wisps of the trees and really embrace nature especially when you’re surrounded by soothing bodies of water. The desert was dry and unforgiving. I could feel the draining heat of the hot sun and the sands were it’s only ocean with the actual oasis being the only form of relief. You can definitely see the life between the trees and water vs. how dead and empty the desert really was.

I appreciate that the only thing your character needs to worry about in terms of survival is sleep and hunger. Which can easily be done. 

Building was easy, hunting was easy and even farming for stuff was pretty easy. 
To me it was a relaxing game and if I wanted more of a challenge, I was allowed to change the difficulty upon opening a portal to get to a different realm.

The character design as far as the enemies go were pretty good. The creatures that would spawn were terrifying especially at night. They kind of gave a silent hill vibe (I’m thinking pyramid head and the undead/warped nurses).

Boss challenges were pretty difficult, as it should be, and for the most part their mechanics were pretty simple to learn.

I didn’t mind the grind for building materials or other items. 

I enjoyed reading all the lore that I got to find throughout doing the runs to farm. You also get to find recipes to craft new materials doing so.

The main story was interesting and the concept was definitely there.

I also really like that you can have some buddies to play in your realm. It makes farming and combat much smoother to navigate.

Cons:

Although I do enjoy a chance to create my own character in detail, I feel like the character design was just not it for me. I’ve never seen anything more embarrassing lmao. When it comes to create your own character I am a definition of snob. I appreciate you can choose your own face, skin, hair and control how and where you place things (eyes, nose,etc) but overall it just made my character look really weird. The hair design was so unsatisfying. I hated it. It could be because I was so spoiled being super detailed like in Baulder’s gate or Wild Hearts…hell in the Sims but I guess this isn’t those type of games. So really I feel like character customization was so unnecessary. There are no cut scenes to even see your design. This whole game is in first person by default. The only time you can see your character is when you set it to third person or when you get into your inventory but even then the details in the design look distorted. 

The story itself seemed a little hard to grasp at first if you’re not actually reading anything.

The whole portal system was so confusing to me at first. At some point I wasn’t sure how to get back to my original base. I thought wherever you place a respite in whatever realm you go to, you can fast travel by selecting it in the map but instead it takes you back where the game first starts you. The frustration to get back to the point where you wanted to be…jfc. 

In general I didn’t like the travel concept. Opening a portal took 10 years to load and imagine having to go back in forth between realms..
I wish there was fast travel within each realm site at least from mid map to main portal. I get that the point of no fast travel is to get the player to explore but a lot of exploration was met by empty space and rewards in random spots were pretty unsatisfactory.

Puzzles and occupation sites were pretty repetitive and nothing really changed other than the puzzles seemingly being a little longer but again repetitive. 

Building/crafting…I don’t even know where to start. I LOVE building. I love having the free range to do whatever I want. This game just barely made that exceptional. There are certain things I can’t do to build and overall had me have to redesign how I wanted it to be. Like walls and stairs were a hot mess to connect sometimes. Crafting was just annoying. I guess I can admit that I was spoiled from previously playing palworld and creating a base allowed me to use all my items without having to actually have said items in my inventory. So i know I’ve read that it’s a possibility to introduce that but man is it a pain at this moment. 

I hate that I can’t even organize my chest inventory in a certain order. It just places the item in whatever spot is available. Same goes for my character inventory or whatever is in my backpack, I can't organize it a certain way that I want. I have OCD about that kind of stuff. Nothing has made my brain more itchy than that lol.

Combat was so clunky. It felt so chaotic and inaccurate. I could be right in front of an enemy and I would still miss a hit or a shot. The magic definitely helps with crowd control but when you’re first starting, it’s honestly a nightmare.

There’s a certain point in the game where you get to play with other players online and although it’s easier to go through portal runs and boss fights, it’s still pretty bizarre that there is absolutely no way to communicate with them. Not even a chat bar to let anyone know where to go or what needs to be done. I literally had to do a crouch motion to thank a person for helping me get back up and staying with me after being taken down and breaking a limb lmao (thank you Cara99 or whoever you are!)

Overall I think this game had a good concept and I appreciate the design of it all. There’s just a few things I wish I could change. The server lag is frustrating but I do enjoy playing with friends. Survival crafting has always been one of my favorite types of games and for the most part this game did it’s thing. However, at this moment I don’t think this game is ready to be played thoroughly and I don’t recommend it. I’d definitely wait until it is fully released and updated. Again, my review isn’t set in stone until it is.

158951814.review:
Nightingale is less polished than Enshrouded, but imo it has far more potential. The ability to open a portal to a map you cook up yourself is both interesting and a huge QoL improvement over crawling an entire planet. Further, the roads it leaves open for the devs to expand the system will allow them to keep growing the game organically for as long as we keep playing it. The game has a great vibe, and the pure adventure feel might even transcend Valheim because there are so many things to *find* in the world. The sound is ok, the graphics are pretty good, but more than anything, the world and the game's concept are, for me anyway, enough to hold my interest through the Early Access issues.

What's not so great at the moment are combat, movement, and the ui. Combat is better than enshrouded but not as good as Valheim. Movement is almost fine, it's just a bit clunky and floaty and there is no proper roll maneuver. The UI and the build UI could use some more love. The lack of any sort of skill system, be it a live skill system or some sort of tree, is a very noticeable void. The servers aren't super stable for a permanently online game, but it's more annoying than problematic. A few crashes over several hours and you log in where the crash happened. 

There are rough spots to be sure, and Nightingale's success will depend on the devs ability to juggle adding new stuff with improving existing issues. The good so far is *very* good, so I'm hopeful that after spending a thousand hours in Valheim, Nightingale could be my next real game.

tl;dr: I love this game so far!  If you enjoy survival crafting like Conan Exiles, this'll be right up your alley.

It isn't perfect, but has been incredibly good for just launching in early access.  I have had minimal crashes and the core gameplay loop is fun and engaging.  Definitely needs QoL improvements and balancing.

There is a main story quest to follow, but outside of those objectives, the core gameplay loop is:

1.  Open a portal to a new realm.  This is done by combining 2 tarot cards and picking a difficulty.  Usually you'll either be target farming some sort of resource or going somewhere for a quest.

2.  Once inside the realm, you are free to run around doing whatever, but each realm has a fae tower.  This is the common open world mechanic of climbing the tower to reveal points of interests (POIs), etc.  So optimal gameplay is gunning it straight for that tower.  The towers themselves are composed of several points of interest and are great sources of the game's main currency, essence.

3.  You then run from POI to POI completing them.  These range from pattern-copying simon-says puzzles, hidden object game, building structures, and platforming to a few types of combat encounters.  These POIs make up a good chunk of the gameplay loop and are the main source of the main currency, essence.  They are really going to need to polish and expand these.  Currently, some are quite tedious and either need better rewards for the amount of time they need (aid POI, lookin at you) or need to be less time consuming.  I just skip the ones I don't feel like doing because you can always make a new realm.

4.  While running from POI to POI, you will come across the various resources scattered around as well as wildlife, monsters, etc.  This is when most of the gathering occurs for me.  Fairly standard chopping trees, hitting rocks.  The wildlife and wandering monsters generally aren't much of a challenge.  There are named animals/monsters you can hunt (and they appear on your map), but they also aren't much of a challenge.

5.  Return to your home realm and do all your base stuff.  Sorting inventory, crafting, etc.  This aspect def needs some QoL improvements.  I spend a lot of time putting stuff away when I get home, it is very time consuming, increasing the time between realm runs.  I would love to see something like a "move items to stack" button.  Terraria has a "move items to stack in any chest near you" button that absolutely ruined other survival games for me.  Every game with box based inventory management needs this.  Farming is also pretty lackluster right now (i believe I read it is not working as intended currently).

Outside of this core gameplay loop, you eventually unlock dungeons.  These are usually 3 POIs in a trenchcoat with a boss at the end.  They're fine.  You can also randomly encounter a portal to one of these dungeons as a POI, but I haven't encountered one of these as a POI with a boss at the end (that would be cool, though).

Progression is based strongly on recipe unlocks.  You unlock recipes by buying them with essence from vendors called essence traders.  Each combination of tarot cards has their own set of recipes that have a chance to appear on these vendors.  You also unlock these recipes as rewards for completing POIs.

- T0, T1, T2, T3 essence tiers make no sense. They could as well combine them together, eventually instead of grinding T0 essence you grind higher tier essences and extract them to T0. But you cannot change T0 -> T1/T2/etc. And to upgrade items to T3 you need first to upgrade them to T1, then to T2, then to T3 so you will need to backtrack and grind again lower tier essences (T1 and T2). 
- The T0 essence grind is simply stupid. you mindlessly gather everything around (spamming E) and extract it. Then you can extract higher tier essences (maybe not T1 because it's not worth much and probably better to do T0 grind) and you get more of them at higher difficulties and from dungeons, but you still don't want to lose too many of them because then you'll have to go back and farm more T1 and T2 essences again. Only at T3 the extraction ratio so high that it's no longer a problem.
- The T2 gear level doesn't make any sense at all. T1 allows you to unlock dungeons (you need a certain amount of power to enter them) unlocking basic cards and allowing you to collect tiered (T1) materials. T2 theoretically allows you to further upgrade gear, but you feel like you're playing PoE or Diablo 4 and about to unlock the highest tier of maps and items, so you don't want to waste T2 essences, especially since you need them to upgrade items to T3. I completely skipped it except for upgrading the backpack.
- Similarly, the game allows you to create T1, T2, and T3 infuses , but it's never worth it to do T1 or T2 because it's a waste, and T3 gives better bonuses anyway. I only used them to quickly make 230 power tools, but now I know it would have been better to finish quests, and with resources from public bosses, I could easily make better items (better schematics and better materials from public Apex Vaults bosses) later, and I needed to replace them at that point anyway
- The wood farming is the worst early game base material grind. So, trees are divided into chunks, and each chunk has HP. To cut a tree, you need to deal the chunk the appropriate damage. And in the early game, it's a tragedy because you hit it several times to get only few pieces of wood while you need hundreds. Since you unlock T3 essences and gear upgrades to T3, you can easily craft axes or pickaxes dealing 1-2k damage per hit and destory ore/wood in one hit. It's completely dumb to make it difficult until then.
- In the mid game, you can learn some special enchant spell, which allows you to destroy ore or wood in one hit without the necessary damage. This helps with ore farming. However, it doesn't work on trees because each tree has hundreds if not thousands of chunks, and casting the spell (attacking a tree with that spell casted) causes lag as you destroy every chunk... Even if you have an endgame axe and destroy a tree in one hit, you can't just run and hit multiple trees along the way because the calculations of damage (single chunk per tree) and multiple falling trees also cause lag. But still, it's somehow bearable at that point.
- I guess the most basic mistake is the conversion ratio in crafting, like 2 -> 1 (or 3:1, etc.). The most ridiculous example is with Animal Fibers, where you can create fiber from animal meat, because meat has different modifiers than plant fibers, and even if the conversion were 1:1, it would take much longer to gather the meat than gathering plant fiber in the same amount. And with a 2:1 conversion, the grind is enormous. In such cases, I feel like none of the developers ever played through the full gameplay because this is the most obvious and basic conclusion in such situations.
- In general, this conversion is a problem. Another moment where it stands out strongly is with buildings (walls, floors, roofs, etc.). I don't understand why the developers made building so much more difficult, especially using these bad conversion rates, because so many things there are needed only for construction, like bricks, beams. And yet they decided to increase the grind so much and make it annoying for players. Similarly, I don't understand why the best building blueprints are locked in Ascended Realms. They could move them to T2, at least there would be something to do.

[h3]If I were to start playing again with a new character, I would speedrun the game from T1 to T3, as these are the only significant moments of the gameplay. T1 unlocks tiered resources and dungeons, while T3 unlocks proper gameplay.

And it's not about having to invest time into something. In games like PoE, I play on SSF, so I put in extra time to obtain many things. In games like Tarkov or Dark and Darker, I dream about SSF. It's just about avoiding meaningless grind.[/h3]

Nightingale is a fantastic game either solo or with friends. Inflexion have crafted a deep, atmospheric experience that is visually stunning and rewards exploration.
Are there issues? Of course, combat - while improved since the closed play test - sometimes feels floaty and incoming hit detection needs work.  
Some POIs begin to appear repetitive as you progress and the gear score requirement for entering boss areas is, in my opinion, questionable.
The crafting system needs attention and resources pulling from chests would be a great QOL (if they worked it into the in game progression similar to how Enshrouded handled it I would be stoked and it would be lore appropriate too) but if you're looking for a shallow, basic system go elsewhere, don't ask the devs to dumb down the process because you're too lazy to learn.
Much of the negative feedback I've seen relates to the issue that the game is 'always online' (which is being rectified soon). In response here's an idea - before you spend your hard earned money on a game how about a little research? It has been clear since day one that Nightingale was going to be a live service game - if thats a deal breaker for you go play Minecraft rather than leaving negative reviews for a game developed by a team that have always been open and transparent about their vision.
I personally hope that the promised offline mode draws more players into what is quite possibly the most interesting early access foundation for a game in years - the possibilities for expanding on the core concepts of what Nightingale is blows my mind.

158959246.review:
Nightingale is indeed a great game in the survival genre with an open world. The game features an interesting visual style and numerous possibilities, but most importantly, it's never boring to play due to the abundance of biomes and maps. The developers have managed to naturally justify the variety of maps within the storyline and connect them in such a way that player progression is maintained while traveling between worlds.

The game does have two drawbacks, both of which are solvable. 
1. Optimization. This is a common issue for games in early access, and it's optimistic to say that there's time to address the problem.
2. The tutorial is absolutely terrible and underdeveloped. The problem lies in the fact that the tutorial and story are presented through quests. This becomes an issue because the tutorial seems like an unnecessary step. As a result, players don't obtain umbrellas, run around worlds with low health, and lack abilities. People generally don't like reading, so they tend to skip the tutorial. The solution is obvious - simplify the tutorial text and highlight interface elements that need to be activated.

A debatable aspect in Nightingale is the balance. If players don't go through the tutorial, it can be extremely challenging to survive and build. However, after completing the tutorial, backpacks and chests will be overflowing with resources, and local dungeon bosses will be quickly and easily destroyed. Still, even with these advantages, hostile NPCs seem to undergo some sort of auto-leveling during the night, and a single hostile creature can send the player to their doom with just a couple of hits. To add to this, the NPC AI isn't well-designed - enemies simply run towards the player and may even pursue them throughout an entire map. However, these balance issues can be easily fixed, and I'm confident that developers will find a reasonable compromise between enjoyment and difficulty.

162951999.review:
Nightingale capitalizes the "Crafting" in the "Survival Crafting" genre. Many contemporaries of the genre take the foundations laid by Minecraft and improved upon by Valheim to build upon it in their own style, resulting in a wide variety of takes on the genre. Inflexion takes those sound foundations and builds something more akin to an intricate, filligree clockwork.

The depth of crafting is on a whole different level. Want to craft a simple hammer? Well you'll need a hammer-head, a handle, and some cloth wrapping. These components all require materials refined from raw materials. It is what raw materials, and how they are refined, that will determine the specific characteristics of the hammer. Want a heavy, durable hammer? Iron hammerhead. How about one that is lightweight and accurate? Maybe crafting it from Tin to reduce it's weight. How about one that massively increases magical power? Make one from Silver.

This same calculus goes into almost every item in the game, and these effects stack, allowing the player to truly express themselves (or min-max) their gear to their heart's content.

This even extends to the realms themselves, which can be augmented and customized through a system of tarot-like cards. Opening gateways to new worlds tailored to certain tasks, even setting up permanent bases to optimize certain tasks or seek out specific resources. 

The game is early access, and it has some problems. I have run into issues with the lighting engine which seems to cause strange grainy shadow effects during long play sessions. The systems are fairly opaque from the start and require a lot of experimentation, and some people may not enjoy the "gear score" like system tied to the crafting. 

That said, the foundation laid here for Nightingale may be the best iteration of a crafting system ever produced in a video game, and I am eager to see how the game develops.

159421686.review:
I have really enjoyed my 40 hrs with the game so far and, despite many opportunities for improvement, I think it's worth the buy.

The Good:

1. The core gameplay loop is exactly what I hoped it'd be - namely, it provides you ample reason to want to go out and explore, gather, and hunt so you can build, craft, and ultimately progress once you get back to your home realm.  I've played a lot of games where it didn't feel like there was a lot of point to what I was doing, but Nightingale keeps you moving through it with a great progression system.  I compare this aspect pretty favorably to a game like Enshrouded, which felt more like two different (but excellent) games of combat and building without a lot of connection between the two.

2. The graphics and art direction are top notch.  You can get a pretty good idea from the trailers but it really made me go "holy shit" numerous times at a vista or encounter.  Just oozing flavor and a unique feel.

3. The crafting system's concept is great and has the kind of depth I love to sink my teeth into and discover.  There's a lot to understand about it and aspects are very poorly explained (will get to that later), but it's still an area that Nightingale stands above any other survival crafting game I've played, with the fact that you can so deeply customize the stats and relative power of everything you craft by selecting a mix of different materials.  You really will want to go out to hunt down one specific thing because it will give you that exact stat boost that you're after.

The Mixed:

1. The combat is functional and can be very satisfying at times, particularly with the weak points system where you are rewarded with an automatic critical hit when you hit a specific spot on an enemy.  However, I don't think it's perfect yet as the enemies tend to ping-pong around to an almost absurd degree at times which can be frustrating at times.  And I know they're the primary enemy but I am already really sick of fighting The Bound - hopefully there is more enemy variety on the way!

2.  The building is decent, but not a differentiator like Enshrouded's is.  It's pretty similar to ARK and would definitely benefit from some expansion in the base pieces like triangle foundations and half-walls.  The biggest issue right now is that there's a  pretty stingy build limit that's limiting your options if you want to play as a group and build a big base.  I hope they can address that soon since there's a lot of potential with the building system.

3.  Exploration is fun and the realms are a really cool idea... but they end up feeling a bit same-y with a pretty limited and formulaic set of POIs to find in each realm.  There's only about 5 of them and while they get harder as you level up the structure doesn't change.  Additionally, you spend a lot of time just running around between them in realms, so while the umbrella floating is a lot of fun I'd really love to see a mount or something to earn that speeds up the process a bit.

4.  Online-Only.  Yeah this is mixed for me, because while I do enjoy hosting my own servers for other similar games to play with friends, in theory there are some advantages to the MMO type of atmosphere they're going for here.  It was cool to drop in and play with multiple groups of friends in a way that wouldn't have been possible with the fractured nature of private servers.  It was also cool to have a hub area later in the game that supported some challenging group content that is a rarity in this sort of game.  The issue is - as has been discussed to death already - mainly that the servers aren't always reliable and there's no way to adjust settings or manage your own experience, not to mention losing out on mods which is a shame because the modding potential for this game is huge.

The Bad:

1. The UI has been improved by all accounts but it's still not great.  It's pretty to look at but there's a lot of fairly baffling decisions (like why would you denote something that you've unlocked the ability to craft by shading it red???) and a lot of very complex systems that are not really explained at all.  This is compounded by the fact that, at this time, there are a lot of placeholder icons for important items that add to the general confusion.  The Augment system drives me absolutely mad because half of it doesn't make a lot of sense and the other half is so poorly explained by the UI that I tend to just give up in annoyance.

2.  There are definitely some bugs and issues to deal with.  My follower annoys the crap out of me constantly by trying to "help" by feeding my forge's flames with my highest quality wood, or by dumping all the materials I've painstakingly gathered into an Aid POI (where you're supposed to finish a building to help an NPC).  Trees you cut will sometimes fall through the map and you'll lose out on the wood.  Multiple times my respite point (home spot that you can port back to from anywhere) randomly decided to unset itself so I got to enjoy a pointless run across the length of my home realm while loaded down with materials.  I'm sure these will be cleaned up pretty quickly, and it's nothing like some of the more notorious bad releases (No Man's Sky this ain't) but certainly can be frustrating.

All in all, I still recommend this game as I've consistently had fun with it playing solo, with my wife, and with a larger group of friends in the current (release) build, despite some of the issues.  I look forward to seeing how the game grows and develops through Early Access!

That leads me to the next topic, feeling lost or confused.  This game starts off in a survival mode, where you must craft your basic tools and clothing from components that you hunt or gather.  I wanted to learn how to play the game before adding another layer of difficulty, so I chose "easy" mode when making my character.  Even on easy mode I felt like my character was about to die.  I quickly gathered leaves, sticks and rocks, only to try to figure out what button to select to start crafting the fire that I desperately needed so my character wouldn't freeze to death.  Later I learned that their stats would just decrease and not regenerate as much, but right at the start I thought they were about to die.
