What I didn't know was you need to fill the green bar up, to stop from having to eat every 3-5 minutes.  I played this game for 45 hours and only just realized you need to just keep eating until it fills, and don't worry about whether or not you have the food picture showing by it.  I kept running around with 1/8 of the bar filled and my character would get hungry right away.  As mentioned before, I thought they were going to die (instead of a stat reduction) so I scrambled to find something.  The starting zone area had berries, mushrooms and deer (meat). Once it was dead I realized I had to use a dagger to cut up the carcass.

Yes, you can harvest and grow vegetables, you mostly will find that you will need to craft over half of everything using some sort of animal product.  Alternatively you may be able to purchase all the required animal components with essences from an essence trader, but I think that would be extremely tedious and quite pricey. This insatiable appetite has led me to skip reading most of the pages, cards and other things I have stumbled upon in my travels. There are a number of good and bad things in this game, but overall, I really enjoyed playing it through. It took me about 280 hours to complete everything defeat all bosses, including open world bosses, and get all achievements. 

I took my time with the game because the world was a consistent creation, I enjoyed adding new things to build with, and getting through the "ladder" of realms until I reached the very last ones. 

The difficulty is not bad, but varies. overall game play can be customised between "wuss" and "not bad". I played mostly on hard, with the last few ascended realms pushed up to Extreme. Extreme difficulty turned out to be the proper one for me. it was challenging enough. The only place I saw the balance broken was in the Solo vaults where I was dying and chipping away on a boss 1 bullet at a time, it took me 2+ hours to get through a solo vault. the public ones are set to easy I think, because with other players, it's laughably easy, 

Another point that I didn't like were the entirety of the vault system. It was the same as the realm vaults just 3 times longer I understand the system but found it really really boring. You are basically either piss blood in solo vaults, or breeze through them in a group without the need to shoot a single shot.. 

I really liked the skyboxes, I wish the game would have more variety in that regard. 

The building was a bit awkward at first, but it worked. The only thing bad about it was that the pacing in which the building pieces were distributed across the realms was way off.. I expected a new building set after my 2nd portal but I had to wait waaaaaay longer, to the point that I was borderline bored with the game.. I liked building and make an interesting house that I upgrade over time, so the lack of building pieces was frustrating. The devs confirmed to be working on the "replace" function for the building elements so I'm not giving them flack for it.

One system I found greatly confusing was the crafting one. I see that it's robust, but it's very convoluted. You need to unlock the station, the augment and the recipe separately.. Why? Why can't the augments just unlock the recipe?This needs to be 1 step shorter or better organised since this was one of the things I was considering giving the game a not recommended for, even though it's a brilliant system. In my opinion, the augments should unlock the new recipes. There are 2 ways to go at it. 1: the augments are cosmetic only, they are the "decoration" category, and you unlock stations and recipes from the realms. The other, perhaps better version is when you build an augment, they give the "exrta" recipes, and the workstation can build any item you unlocked without augments. 
The problem is the workstation / augment attachments. one augment can enhance more than 1 station, and 1 station can get limited augments in range This leads to me loose track of what workstation is effected by what augment, and missing out of recipes, because there are no more augment slots on the station. Then I look up what is needed and I see that workstation and augments are next to each other yet I still cannot build something. I have to offload the table for example, them move it to an empty area, then move that specific augment in range to unlock crafting of what I need, then put everything back after done.. I really liked the idea that there can be randomly named people out there that you can recruit (although a bit awkwardly). Getting NPCs in realms was interesting, and good idea but some parts are very bad. For example, 50%of the time, you need to help them build something before you can recruit them. WHY? Now we built a house halfway in water  with crafting stations, that nobody will use, because I took the NPC,, I think they should have a way to offer 2 things when you approach an NPC builder site: a quest to protect them while they pack and a quest to help them build, if you don't want to recruit them. That way you can decide based on name and look if you want to take them or help them settle. Much better system.

Multiplayer was more or less working, but it was a bit awkward to experiment with what was their loot and what was mine, what we could loot both and what we couldn't. It shouldn't have to be an experiment.. 

Building limits are assss.. Especially if you want to build on the same realm.. The reason me and my friends were not building on the same realm was that we all wanted our own house but kept hitting the build limit which was quite bad. 

The story of the game was quite good, and void of all agenda, which I've not expected just by looking at the gamedevs. Thinking about the game overall ,the largest contributor for why I recommend it it's because it's focusing on the game and the world, and not on agendas and quotas. An additional thing I wanted to mention was the voice acting. I'll probably come back when new biomes will be added. That and new building pieces are the only thing that can pull be back in, since I played this game nearly for 300 hours at this point, I've seen enough, and the endgame currently is quite lacklustre 

Overall good, game, time well spent, some misfires, lots more to develop but what's already in there is worth recommendation. Plus you can have a dog in-game.

I'm rather sad that I can't recommend this game, but there's just so much wrong with it.  
Let's start with some basics:
1.  It's boring.  The pacing is terrible.  The first realms have very little interesting content.  They are there for forced farming to unlock the next realm of forced farming.  It does pick up a bit when you hit the Herbarium realm, but I doubt most folks will really make it that far before getting bored.  Even then, it's still a lot of lather, rinse, repeat.  The puzzles are the same, the realm cards are the same (forest, desert, swamp), and the enemies are really nothing you haven't seen done before.  You'd expect more from fae realms, but nope.
2.  The AI is terrible.  Mobs and bosses do the same thing...they rush directly at you at top speed.  You can get a NPC helper who will assist you in battle, just be sure not to give them any high-end crafting materials or they will gladly chuck them into any random campfire or forge you walk by.  Learning that part was fun.  The rest of the NPCs, like quest givers and essence traders, are just placeholders standing there.  
3.  Speaking of quest-givers...I'm not sure why they have them.  I've encountered 4 in 80 odd hours of gameplay that are just there to make unlocking something a bit more difficult and time wasting.  The reward is something that you've previously unlocked through normal play, like a realm card or weapon, that has extra hoops to jump through to get just the next one in line.  
4.  Building.  I think they took the basic UE5 system and just threw it in.  It's just sad by today's standards.  Do not buy this game if you enjoy building nice places.  You'll be very disappointed.  Due to the way the crafting system works, decorating is not gonna be fun either,  Why do you have a wheelbarrow in the middle of the room?  Because crafting.  Why is there a frying and and a pot over here instead of in the kitchen?  Because crafting.  
When you realize Bethesda has better building than a game built on UE5...you get sad.  
5.  Crafting.  Probably the best part of the game, and the most confusing.  Get out your Excel so you can start making spreadsheets of what each station does, what items enhance which stations, which ones cancel out other enhancements, which components do what, what color they produce (yeah, no dye station here), and a host of other things...all pretty poorly explained in a barely usable menu system.  It's like alien technology.  It's probably awesome if you can figure it all out.  

You likely already know about server issues, slow loading and realm changing, disconnects, falling through places forever (luckily, never encountered this one), and a host of more issues,  
It's going to take a lot of work to fix this.  I'm hopeful that I can change my review in the future as it really is a cool concept, and there are glimmers of a good game peeking out from what is currently a bit of a mess.
But right now, it's a nope for me.

159944216.review:
I have been waiting for this game to release for well over a year now with great anticipation. And with about 60 hours in, I must say I'm thrilled with my experience of it. Is it perfect? No, it has several things to be desired and some necessary fixes to be made. However, I do not see the "redundancy" that many here complain of. Yes, you grind, you take on higher level encounters, you upgrade your gear, and you carry on to greater heights. I see no difference in many other crafting/survival games. Certainly some allow you to jump right in and bite off way more than you can chew from the start, and maybe those who are disgruntled would be happier if Nightingale allowed that as well, but it is far from tedious to get there. 

The worlds are phenomenal and fascinating. The Minor Realm cards that can be utilized in any realm allow for personal preferences to prevail in the realms. You want more of a challenge? Blood Moon card; you cannot walk 5 feet without encountering a new horde of monsters, both Bound and realm-specific. You want something to make travel and exploration easier? Thinly-veiled card; something to allow you to defy the laws of gravity, without suffering fall damage! And all of them result in stunning visual changes as well! My only wish here is that I do yearn for a greater variation of Major Realm card combinations, and hope to see that in future updates. 

Additionally, and perhaps my FAVORITE thing thus far, is the nuance of crafting! You do not simply upgrade your weapons/tools from stone to copper, then iron, etc. No, all the different ores have different characteristics and statistics to them, so you can choose what to use to create your weapons/tools based on what you are looking for. Better ranged damage? There's a certain ore for that! Better durability or melee damage? There's one for that! And this extends into clothing crafting as well! It is remarkably nuanced and the limits to what you can do in personalizing and optimizing your gear seems excitingly endless to me. 

If you do not have the patience, wait for some of the updates, because this game has much more in store for us all and I cannot wait to see it. Some of the communities biggest grievances are already in the devs sights and are being worked on presently. Like: offline mode, crafting from chests, and queued crafting to name a few.

I think its good, but know what you’re getting into. This is a grind game. The core gameplay loop is optimization. If that doesn't sound appealing to you, or you play survival games for different reasons, then its probably not for you.

A lot of people are complaining about the amount of augmentations or how the crafting system works. I think the real problem is just a lack of QoL features that ultimately make things take more time than they need too. All parts of a production chain need to be done manually, can’t be queued, and take time to complete. While this is somewhat necessary, as different items affect the output item, the system can be tedious since it requires constant attention. Its not as simple as queuing up the end product you want and then doing something else. Ultimately that amounts to a lot of time staring at workbenches. I like the complex crafting system but as mentioned earlier if you dont, then this isnt going to be the game for you.

Combat is fine. I don’t really understand why people say its bad. Its meaty and satisfying. Not perfect but light years ahead of many popular games in the survival genre. You can reset realms and make them more or less difficult as you please. There's good skill expression through headshots/heartshots. I really don’t see a problem here.

Outside of the other problems, the last problem is repetition. There’s not a whole lot of content atm and whats there is stretched pretty severely. There’s a lot of the same enemies, the same biomes, the same quests. Minor cards help with this, but there needs to be more. Either the grinding and min maxing gets its hooks into you or you’ll probably find it tedious. For me I loved it, and Im glad its not yet another survival game doing the exact same thing as the last popular survival game. 

Ultimately its a solid game, and for me even if its never updated ever again, I feel like whats already here is worth a look imho. It looks great, and has a very detailed crafting system that Im really into. Just be aware of what it is, and if youre unsure maybe wait for some more development.

159784138.review:
Nightingale is a diamond in the rough in its early access phase. After logging 135 hours of play, I think it offers great value for its price point. And the game will only get more content as time goes on.

Visual Appeal: Obviously the game shines with its beautiful graphics, which is likely a major draw for many players. The procedural generated landscapes in sprawling worlds are eye candy. If you’re someone who enjoys exploring visually stunning worlds and building a home with epic backdrops, Nightingale will not disappoint.

Combat System: Combat is straightforward yet satisfying. It rewards skilled players who leverage the mechanics more than those who simply button mash. The variety of interesting creatures, each with unique behaviours and weaknesses that adds to the combat experience.  Some of the bosses are quite strong, with challenging mechanics.

Resource Harvesting and Building: The core game play loop of resource harvesting, crafting, and building is addictive. The need to acquire specific resources from different realms keeps the game engaging. The building system is really user-friendly. It has no issues with 'clipping', so you won't see that annoying red outline when trying to drop the last piece of your epic mansion because it's an inch too close to something else. 

World Manipulation: You can influence realms on a global scale, altering their look and mechanics. This adds depth to the game play, allowing for varied experiences in different realms.  That has huge potential, but I'd like to see them do much more with this mechanic in the future.  Pro tip: This ability allows you to tailor your home world. If you plan to harvest a lot of lumber for a building project, modify your realm to increase lumber production. There's a lot of power there if you leverage it.

Challenges and Areas for Improvement:

Being unfinished, some icons are placeholders, which can be a nuisance.  And the UI could use a quality of life rework. 159703231.review:
52 hours in, think I'm ready to spill the beans... Nightingale is a faithful attempt to drag the crafting/survival genre back to a more serious, adult, and "crunchy" vibe. But, it is very bare-bones (IE. Absolutely early access) in its current state. Just for context, 7 Days and The Long Dark are my two gold standards of the genre - both games that involve a good deal of searching/improving your recipes, but ALSO makes room for an actual game while you climb the crafting ladder. Unfortunately, I feel No Man's Sky really broke the genre by turning the ladder into the game itself, but I digress. 

Nightingale runs on Unreal Engine 5, which is absolutely gorgeous. The atmospherics are top-notch, which is a large part of why I love these games, but some of the models are a bit iffy. NPCs are stiff and awkward, lots of potato faces to go around, and the fur on those wolves looks like it never properly rendered. The core loop is (yet another) ladder climb, unfortunately, with little actual "game"... You jump through (very slow loading) portals into various procedurally generated realms in order to buy recipes to get you into the next tier of realms, etc. 

The procedural generation, like NMS, really just noodles around the edges making most realms of a given type feel very same-y, and a single pass through all of the POIs in a realm is a fairly simple affair. Like Enshrouded, these POIs dot the map, and involve relatively little more than a simple puzzle or to kill a few mobs. Even the few-and-far-between dungeon delves seem mostly empty and hollow. However, the combat feels really great. 

Crafting is where this game shines, with an endless level of detail paid to material stats, levels of materials (tiers), enchantments, charms, etc. It's almost too much crunchy, to be honest, once you realize that there's a bazillion "augments" you need to keep around just to craft one or two items. Augments are similar to what we had in Valheim, where you put down an anvil within range of your smelter to buff the stats; except in Nightingale, you use augments to grant the ability to craft items you've unlocked (that wouldn't normally be available in the workbench without it). I personally LOVE the crunchiness of the crafting system, but I hope they streamline the management of all of it... because it's a lot. 

My final comment here is the building system, which is awful. They clearly left this system for last. Whereas Enshrouded has a beautiful, deep building system that not only allows you to place prefabs that "stitch" neatly at the seams but also grants the ability to add/remove bits to your liking... Enshrouded is prefabs only. And not very many. There's also no way to upgrade/replace prefabs, sending everything attached and above the object you're removing crashing down to the ground. It's a crazy amount of unnecessary rework whenever you want to replace a foundation block, for example, as all attached walls, roofs, and crafting stations need to be manually moved first. Total pain. 

What's worse is, relocating to a new realm involves breaking everything down into components, shuttling those components through a portal (capped by weight limit) over the span of a dozen trips, rebuilding at the new location, and then cleaning up after yourself. Awful. 

That all being said, the game in its current state sets a solid foundation for tons of content and improvements. I hope they stick with it and make the actual "game" part of the game more interesting. As it stands right now, I'm still enjoying the crafting and upgrading, but it's getting stale fast.

I cannot, right now, recommend this game. I have played it, walked away from it, come back to it, and left it just as fast.

Pros:
* Artwork is nice, the world is pretty.
* Followers seem to follow you without too many problems (pathing-wise), they fight, and are easy to resurrect and get back to battle.

Cons:
* World travel is briefly explained, but you definitely feel like you have been thrown in the middle of a book  without much knowledge of anything before hand.

* Without going online and searching how the cards work, how to get them, or what you need to get them, you are basically running around a farming treadmill until you figure out what you need to do. By that, I mean that the quest in the top right corner tells you what you have to do (most of the time) to progress the game, but it doesn't really tell you specifically you need a gear score of 30 to be able to enter this building. The building just has a force-field and no way to get into it, while your active quest says "Get Gear Score 30" - the link between the two is missing. Some people do not like it spelled out, but if you are trying to play the game without spoilers, it doesn't hurt to connect the dots in the beginning of the game.

* Difficulty of cards - most of them are so non-descript in what they do, you don't really understand what you are doing. They have base descriptions, but you don't know the fine details. Which is worse, the Antiquarian cards versus the Astrolabe card? Middling danger or Moderate? Probably Moderate, but you have to guess which one it is by engaging a monster and seeing the level. if you die, it is a corpse run, and you better hope you did not end up in the path of a roaming group of monsters.

*Small cards are realm cards that can change how the world works, and it is a cool take on changing your environment to suit your needs. A lot of them have a negative, or too negative of a, consequence to deal with it regularly, so you really only use it when you are farming something specific.

* As has been said, the crafting is terrible. They need to overhaul the entire system and give the player more information about what each unit does, how to upgrade it, and why certain upgrades you build for the machines do not actually upgrade them. LIke adding bellows to the starter forge does not do anything. When you get the upgraded forge, it unlocks one recipe. The description says it adds about 10 items, but it doesn't. You have to unlock those recipes and then they can be used at the forge. It is the same for all equipment you have to build, and there is a lot. The game never tells you this though, so it looks like it should unlock everything.

* The constant need to farm pelts gets old after the 3rd Fae Tower.  No way to store wood or grass, no way to store ores or rock in their own pallets. So you have to build an enormous amount of bags and place them all over your house, with limited inventory space, just to hold the extra starter items you are always going to need going forward. Always. You never stop needing animal hide, wood, grass, and stone. When I stopped playing I had over 15 bags in my house, that was crammed full of begging and upgraded machines, complete with the one-off items you build to enhance them.

* repetitive monsters -  - in the beginning world, it was wolves and pigs. In the next world it was hippos and something else. In the desert it was scarabs and another monster. Then you had the regular monsters in the Fae towers for each world. All of them feel the same no matter the zones you go into, just different skins. Hippos, pigs, and scarabs will charge you and a simple side-step negates all advantage they had and you can kill them easily.  Fae die fairly quickly, but in numbers can overwhelm you.

* Clothes - you stay in your starter clothes WAY TOO LONG. There is no progression until you upgrade like 3 or 4 machines to the advanced level, and farm all the materials for that, which is fairly far, play-time-wise, in the game.  Then you have to go farm another load of materials just to get new pants and a shirt. You keep the turban for the entire time (at least I did, I am sure there are other hats out there you can get), but I didn't find any unless I stole them from a follower.

Summary: The game right now is just not very good. It has some great pieces to it, but it needs a lot more clarity in the tool-tips, more ways to store items, better clothing system, and new monsters with varying attacks/skills.

Maybe give it another 6 months to a year and see if they can salvage it.

💠 Early Access Review 💠

I hesitate to recommend this game... because, while there is a lot that I do really like about it, the main idea (and promise) of the game -- was the possibility of "infinite realms" to explore -- and that just isn't fully realized yet. 

I want to walk through a new portal and be utterly surprised and in awe by the "infinite" possibilities that I might see when exploring a new realm. As of the time of this review... there is no surprise or major awe.

I want to explore lots of *unique* ("infinite") REALMS!  -- Right now, each "Realm" just feel like a set "biome" that is generated slightly differently each time. Therefore, this does not lead to that feeling of wanting to explore each nook-&-cranny of every new realm I enter, because there just isn't enough difference and variety (per biome) to make me feel like I'm seeing things I haven't seen before. 

That said... 
1️⃣ The overall *look* (or "vibe") of the environments, as well as the music, are both stunning and quite enjoyable! No complaints. ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

2️⃣ The crafting system is amazing! It's one of the best crafting systems I've seen (recently) in a survival game. And other than not being able to craft items from the resources in our chests, I have no other major gripes about the crafting system! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

3️⃣ The building system is serviceable, and can allow for some really neat looking structures, but ultimately could be better. We need to be able to build at angles, and not be so locked into the cookie-cutter boxes and placement locations -- especially for the decorations! We need more building pieces and decorations. But I do love that you can pre-plan your buildings (and can get 100% resources back when removing things)! If they can improve these things, I'll be quite happy! ⭐⭐⭐

4️⃣ The combat system is also serviceable, and is decently engaging, but it could also be better. We need more enemy types (always!), and I feel like the combat mechanics could be tightened up a bit -- especially in terms of enemy AI! But I don't hate the combat outright... there is a decent tactile feeling to swinging and landing melee hits (or firing weapons and landing shots) -- this is a definite plus! So, if they can improve some of the combat, in certain ways, it will be amazing! ⭐⭐⭐

5️⃣ Finally, the Realm system is such an amazing concept, but, as stated above, is only *barely* serviceable as of the time of this review. We need at *least* 3 more biome cards -- ASAP! And, if you ask me, the game could uses a system for the POI's, where the procedural AI, that generates each realm, would pull from a pool of hand-crafted POI's and other realm-specific landmarks, etc. -- and would not just use the same POI's again and again. Because, as it stands, once you've seen each biome (Forest, Desert, Swamp), you've basically seen them all. And the major & minor cards just aren't making me feel like I'm witnessing the possibility of "infinite realms!" ⭐⭐

▫ The Major cards just feel like a linear story-progression / gear-score check type of system -- with some NPC/narrative elements (and blueprints) locked behind each tier of major card. Thus far, I haven't seen any Major card *radically* change any of the biomes to the point of being surprised by an "infinite" possibilities of unique realms. 

 ▫ And the minor cards are merely for a realm-wide buff / de-buff system, that usually comes with a change in the environment's color pallet and other minor effects. 

📌 In summary... 
I'm 60 hrs in (and I'm only Gear Score 70 -- out of 200+)! I definitely do plan to keep playing, because I'm a sucker for a good crafting system!  Averaging my star ratings, for the 5 categories above, I would give the game = 3.6 / 5 stars.

At this time though, the gameplay-loop (and realm system) does feel a bit stale to me -- the game needs even more "shock & awe" added in (new enemies, new biomes, etc etc etc). I want to explore "infinite realms" of "infinite possibilities!" 

However, I can see the *vast* potential this game has, and I'm totally here for it, because there is enough that I do like, that I can overlook the things I don't love just yet. 

So, the reason I'm recommending the game, is because I do believe there are individuals who will love this type of game, and should definitely try it out, especially while it's cheaper (during Early Access). It's not a perfect game (yet), but it has so much going for it, and has a stellar team of devs working on it -- and they appear (so far) to be quite responsive to their community! So, I feel like that should be praised. 

That said... this game, in its current state, will not be for everyone. Some people hate the always-online element. I personally don't, but its an understandable gripe. Some may find the game boring, because some elements of it are! But the Devs have already shown they have every intention of fixing a lot of these issues, and adding more content.... So, I'm recommending the game, because I do believe this will be a pristine gem -- in time!

And the depth and customization in the craft system is fantastic. Want a new wood axe? Well you can just slap one together with whatever supplies you have on hand! Oh but you want a magic wood axe? Well pick and choose the types of ore, wood, and hides that you use to craft the components. Now you have the exact stat boosts you chose, be that damage, magic, stealth, defense, durability, whatever you selected in your material choices. 

Oh and if you have a grindstone near your work bench when you assemble the axe, it will also get a permanent damage buff to the blade. And if you REALLY want to make the best axe you can, play a card in the transmuter (or build a workshop in a realm where one has been played) to improve crafted tools, and get even more permanent buffs when you assemble the axe. You could even take that to the absolute extreme and make the individual components in different realms with cards played for wood or metal working.

I have played a lot of survival games. You name it, I've probably played it. Even the bad ones.

This game really is like no other survival game before and I think that's what throws people off. There is no traditional leveling system or skill trees. At its core, you are building your gear. Your gear is you. That is what dictates your level and what abilities you have.

The beginning is slow. I watched my friend just get despondent and stop. I kept going, I'm on T3 and it's more fun gathering materials for better gear and different building parts. Now I have magic attached to my gear and can cast spells. 

 I am enjoying this game, but I feel like I'm in the minority because the game is simply "go out, get materials, use materials to upgrade. Discover and conquer POIs to unlock new recipes."
I can see how this would be tedious and boring for some as there are only 3 biomes. You can play minor realm cards but I didn't figure it out for a while. The game is really pretty though.

Crafting is complex. If you have ever played Star Wars Galaxies, this is it. Just gathering a bunch of mats, weighing different stats against each other and the thrill of trying to make an item just a bit better than before.

If you love crafting, if you love exploring. If you love trying something different, maybe try this one out.

T:;DR: I was completely unaware this game existed until 2 days before it came out. I have been very pleasantly surprised. Especially for a sub-$30 early access game.

The game is absolutely gorgeous from the mini icons to the giant multi-moon skies. Hell, even the placeholder icon for items looks amazing. This includes the MANY different style options for housing and what I think is, at minimum, a very unique clothing and weapon style.

The combat feels good. The thunk sound of a maul accompanied with the enemy being knocked down is extremely satisfying as well as the gold letters and "dink" noise of landing a crit. I also like the noticeable difference in damage you get by making a weapon with crude t1 mats vs min-maxed t2/t3 mats. Also very much enjoy the visuals and feel of the Enchantment spells. Watching someone gather up a bunch of bound and then everyone aoe-ing them down with quake and a maul is hilariously fun.

While a bit confusing at first (and admittedly even now a little), the realm system is very cool. My current situation is my friends and I have one persons world where we go and contribute most of the mats to have sort of a 'hub' to go and craft anything we want but also have our own home worlds to go and build if/when we want. And the idea that if this person quits, I still have a portal to go and make things whenever I want is very nice. 

I also think the system at The Watch with being able to just do basically 'open' dungeons with other people is cool, most of the time.

Oh, and Puck. More Puck please.

Cons:
Several things in the game take a long time. If you have 100 ore to smelt I think it takes something like over an hour real-time to smelt and portals take a long time to open. That being said, if you throw on 1000 ore before long-resting it will instantly complete so that's nice. Would be great to also see a queue in the crafting  stations to craft multiple things at once.

The followers are a bit robotic and often very frustrating. I have found that they sometimes vanish and that I very often have to check their inventory lest I want them to help use mats to randomly help build something out in the world.

ENGLISH - ITALIAN (v0.1.0a)

Nightingale is a survival and crafting game set in an alternative Victorian era, where magic is present and traveling between realms is possible. The game is currently in Early Access, so it is constantly evolving and improving. Despite some technical and gameplay issues, it also offers some interesting and original aspects, that make it worth attention.

Among the strengths of Nightingale, we can mention:

- The unique and fascinating artistic style, that mixes steampunk and fantasy elements, creating various and suggestive environments.
- The intriguing and mysterious story, that leads you to explore the different realms of the Fae, mythical beings drawn from European folklore, in search of the magical city of Nightingale, the last refuge of humanity.
- The well-made building mechanics, that allow you to create your base and customize it with various objects and structures, using materials and resources that you find in the world.
- The possibility to play cooperatively with other players, sharing resources, challenges and discoveries.
- The card dynamics, that allow you to create the realms randomly, using cards that you obtain by exploring or completing missions. These cards have different characteristics, such as climate, vegetation, fauna, dangers, resources, etc. By combining the cards, you can create unique and different realms, that offer new challenges and opportunities.

Among the points to improve of Nightingale, instead, we can point out:

- The challenging and complex gameplay, that requires a lot of patience and dedication to progress, without offering much guidance or explanation.
- The simple and little varied combat, especially in the first part of the game, where you use primitive weapons and face uninteresting enemies.
- The performance and stability issues, that cause lag, FPS drops and various bugs, especially when playing online.

In conclusion, Nightingale is a game that has potential, but that is still in development. If you like survival and crafting games, and you are willing to tolerate some flaws, you might find it fun and original. Otherwise, you might wait for the game to be further developed and improved, before trying it.

Purchased day of release.  Really enjoying the game so far and excited to see where it goes.  The realm card system is unique and gives a lot of variety to play.  Love the ability to have some control over difficulty.  My family plays and our youngest player has struggled with other survival games when difficulty increases.  I have played other early access games, and want to give a shout out to the Dev team for releasing a product that is remarkably bug free when compared to other early access games.  So far we have run into a couple of lag spikes with enemies spawning into encounters and with transport between realms (literally only a couple in almost 20 hrs of play).  Solid and great looking game.  Enjoying the Victorian/Fae theme.  Have not yet found the lack an off line option to be much of a hindrance, though I do understand how this may impact some.  Would love a bit more variety in early game weapons (such as crude clubs and/or spears), would love a bit of early customization on clothing/"armor."  Maybe a dye bench as there are already similar style (saw, sewing bench, etc) crafting benches in the game.  The character creation is very individualized, would be a nice bonus to carry this over into the game.    My family and I are very much enjoying this game so far and look forward to continuing to play.

Update at nearly 200 hrs played: 
I still enjoy this game.  Love the Minor Card system and the unique opportunities it allows in the realms to tailor the play experience.  Grinding for building materials? Play a card to increase the yield of stone.  How about farming for better food items?  There is a card for this too as well as charm to increase yield and augmentations to increase grow speed.  
This game is still beautiful to see.  It has a decent start for a story line with lots of room to grow.  

Things I have learned: 
Color of clothing/items is determined by the materials used to craft them.
There are placeholders in the recipes for items that are intended in the game, but not yet available in early access (This is expected/anticipated in early access.  Not all content is yet available.)

Helper NPC's are a blessing and a curse.  They have no weight limit which is amazing when gathering resources.  They tend to stroll off when you are trying to give them heavy items, leaving you chasing them at a crawl.  Their is also no way to control how they help.  What I mean by this is some very high end wood can get shoved into a fireplace as they restock fuel or used to assist with building.  It is a great concept that they can help with these things, but the execution isn't totally in place and will need more work before this is truly functional.  Lesion learned- check every fire place before igniting.   Don't set down a new item to build until their inventory is completely empty.  Keep their access shut off for all chests.  

There are some bugs.  I will still say that I have experienced fewer of these with this others (here's looking at you ARK).  Hot bar items can appear as shovels on log in or just after portal to a new realm.  This is very easily fixed by opening inventory and running your mouse over the icons.  Trees will sometimes fall through the world when you cut them down instead of dropping logs.  You can lose server connection on transition through a new portal and/or time needed to do this can be a bit long (3 min-ish).  This is a moderate frequency issue happening about every 3rd (ish) realm transition in my experience.  I know some players get a lot more of this happening.  Recruited Helper NPC's can suddenly disappear on log in to a realm (has happened twice to me in nearly 200 hrs of play).  Any upgraded gear that was on them is just gone.  You cannot recover them and will need to recruit again and upgrade yet more gear.  I anticipate these being further addressed through Bug fixes and as the game progresses through early access. 

Things that I think could be better addressed: 
Item limit cap per realm.  Currently set to 350.  I love to build, love to decorate, and want very much to be able to do this in my Abeyance Realm.  This is independent of the structure limit (currently 100 structures per realm) or the build limit (300 walls/foundations/ceilings/etc) per building.  Honestly the 100 structures and 300 build are things that can be worked with.  The 350 items is profoundly limiting.  It is per realm- not per person.  If you partner up and share an Abeyance Realm with another individual or group, even sharing a central crafting area you will quickly run through this limit with augmentations, storage, and lighting.  Forget decorating.  I LOVE the complexity of the crafting system.  I like working through the best set up to make the benches efficient, finding the best augments for the recipes I want.....I hate not being able to organize and create something visually pleasing because cosmetic considerations need to be removed in order to stay under this limit.  
Reclaimed Ingots/Folding: (Please realize that I am not a game developer or coding expert.  I do not know how difficult it may be to "fix" a system in this manor).   The combination of various materials to affect color and attributes of items/weapons/clothing is awesome.  It is creative and fun.  It can allow for some exploits.  There has been back/forth in maintenance updates to address this.  Rather than take a very nice, creative feature out of the game, would suggest capping items.  If you never intended a riffle to be able to reach a million damage- that is fine.  Cap the damage.  Players can combine anything they wish, but once the max damage is reached, that is it.  It continues to allow for the creativity but limits the game breaking possibilities.

159153339.review:
A slave for the wounds.

I booted up this game and was immediately enchanted. As a reader of Susanna Clarke, I 'got it' right away. As I am playing, I am excited, not only in the world itself, but the graphics, and the entirely novel and deep systems it brings to the table. Everything about the game both surprised and enchanted me. 

Then I look on Steam and see reviews are mixed. How so? Fortunately, most of these are of the 'mummy, I've peed my pants' school of criticism. However, there are some genuine observations too - should you have the will to dig for them. Yes I would like to play offline (but guess what? This is being implemented.). Yes the menus are a bit clunky - I cannot tell you how many times I have fought an enemy holding just an umbrella! I think the menus will have some reaching for the refund button, but as soon as you become used to them - they are just fine. Yes the crafting takes time - but as a veteran of crafting games, I have played a lot worse. I remember one game where you had to craft individual bricks to make a house! Now, I would not go that far, but (for me) it reduces the immersion if crafting is too simple. *Understand the systems* before complaining. Just load up your crafting stations and set them running, go to bed  - hey ho, everything is ready when you wake up. Combat *is* a little clunky at the moment, but if I wanted it harder, I would up the difficulty - seems easy to me. 

Here is a thought - the game is clearly defined as being in Early Access. By now, we should all know what that means. If you don't here goes: You have bought the game with the full knowledge that it is not a finished product (moan at yourself, rather than the devs if you did not understand this). Then, the whole point of early access is for the devs to get feedback from the community, and to use this feedback to develop the game to be the game that the community wants to play. May I humbly suggest that positive feed back is more effective than 'boy have I had a bad day at work' style griping.

I cannot imagine the amount of resources, time and hard-won skill went into this game. For my part, I always feel the urge to celebrate such things. I feel this adds more niceness than squirting out a dribble of bile. I want to acknowledge any achievements made, thank those that provide me with pleasure, and encourage those that do to continue working. 
Here is the thing - I am glad this was an instant purchase for me, and that I did not look at the overall score of 'mixed', as this is a signal to me that perhaps I should pass. I am not the only one that make decisions on this premise - in an increasingly toxic world, perhaps I need to review my stance? The obvious result of 'mixed' is that less people buy the game - That the devs get less funding and eventually get into financial difficulties and stop work on the game - or, as we have seen far too many times in the past year - have to close the studio and seek other work. So, if you hate the game (or your life) so much, this is certainly an effective tool to consider in that act of killing it. 

That out of the way - I thank the devs for providing me we an immersive and  unique experience, and give me an alternative world to counteract the terrible one I find myself in. It is the most excited I have been in a game for a long, long time, and a game I see myself getting lost in for years. 

Mixed yes - but a mix of pleasure and appreciation.

Summary:
This review was written a few days after release into Early Access. At the time of review i have played 16 hrs.
At this time i cannot recommend buying Nightingale.

Pros
- Nightingale is a survival craft game, you collect materials, you craft things and you build a base. These things are fun in Nightingale.
- You can play solo or coop (up to 6 players). All players can quest together and access chests, this works pretty well.
- Random worlds can be created via portals, if you like exploring you will always have a new world at hand.
- The graphics are good (in my opinion).
- You can switch between mouse & keyboard and a gamepad. This works well. Personally i use gamepad for movement and combat. For crafting, building and sorting my inventory i prefer using mouse and keyboard.

Cons
- Animations are bad. The way the character moves etc. looks unnatural.
- The hit boxes are terrible. You never know where your hit will land. Hitting a moving enemy with a bow is a game of luck. But even if i stand face to face to an enemy hitting him with a melee weapon i miss a lot. Even gutting corpses with a hunting knife will only work after some fruitless attempts. Or hitting a tree, it sometimes just does not work correctly. This problem is always there no matter if you use mouse&keyboard or a controller.
- Materials: if you collect meat, hide, fibers etc. you will get variations of that material depending on the source. In my opinion this is unnecessary and makes crafting more complicated than it has to be. For example you need 2 hides but you only have 2 different hides than you can not put them into the crafting slot. You need 2 identical hides. And your chests will fill quickly with all the variations of meat, hide, fibers etc. Everything starts a new stack. If a developer should read this: why not just 1 sort of meat, hide, bone etc?
- Long loading screens: everytime you log into the game or use the portal to a different world, you will have to wait appr. 3 minutes …
- Nightingale is in EA, but in my opinion it was released at least 6 months too early. Comparing Enshrouded and Nightingale i have to say that Enshrouded is a lot more polished and nearly bug free. The things that are implemented work fine in Enshrouded. Not so in Nightingale: The stone pile which is your binding point will randomly stop working, then you will enter the map at the default position (in my case at the other side of the island … 1000m to walk … every time this happens). Some items don‘t have icons. Sometimes your character cannot sprint anymore, if you are using a keyboard and have connected a controller. All these things should not happen even in EA.

This is a very solid early access release. I haven't found any game breaking bugs yet, and I'm overall very impressed by the mechanics of the game.

I was blown away by the exploration part of this game early on, and the graphics are gorgeous.

It allows several players to put their 'home' in the same realm, so they can work and live together, without a certain person having to be online... and you can meet random people if you set your realm to public.

I would much rather have it this way than having to pay 10-20 dollars for a dedicated server for a month.

Overall, a solid early access release from Inflexion Games.

158997620.review:
I played this game during the closed beta and I loved it then. Now that it's out, I bought it immediately and I've already put more time into it than I really should. It's not a perfect game by any means and it's definitely early access and therefore unfinished. However it's got some really cool stuff. I'm editing my review to give some more details on the cool stuff in the hope that it convinces more people to buy this amazing game. The TLDR is that I love the crafting system, I love the realm system, and combat turns out to be more deep than I first thought too. Added bonus, building buildings has a few nice features that I really enjoy. Extra extra bonus is some suggestions/advice.

Good thing number 1: The crafting system
The crafting system seems kind of basic and confusing at first. Unfortunately one of the biggest weakpoints of this game is that the new player experience is rough and unfinished. It took me a lot of experimentation to discover all the cool things that the crafting system can do.
1. Some of the minor realm cards can give boosts to crafted items. I've got one currently up that boosts the durability of the clothes and tools I build. I have another minor realm card that increases how much ammo is crafted at a time letting me save materials. There are a ton of these minor realm cards and although not all of them affect the crafting system, some of them do.
2. Each crafted tool/clothes has some attributes on it. Each crafting material above the crude level has some attribute modifiers on it. If the modifier on a material matches the attribute of the tool, then using that material will boost the relevant stat. This lets you customize your tools and clothes to some degree. For example, my knife is focused heavily on boosting crit damage and since it attacks faster than the mining pick, if I get crits on a regular basis then it can out damage the two handed mining pick made with melee damage boosting materials.
3. Each piece of gear that is uncommon (green) or better can have infusions applied to them. Only 1 infusion for green gear but more for higher levels. These infusions offer extra attribute modifiers.
4. Each piece of gear can be updated for just some essences at the upgrade station. So even the simple gear set can be upgraded to green and gain infusions, enchantments, and charms.
5. Enchantments are spells that can be put on the tools. Putting it on your tool increases it's gear score and boosts it but it also lets you cast the relevant spell. This could be a recovery spell for healing yourself. It could be a spell to boost your harvesting/mining. I've only got a few spells unlocked but I look forward to seeing what other spells are in the game.
6. Every piece of clothing can have a charm put on it. These offer bonuses of varying sorts. My favorite is the Charm of Bounty that boosts how many resources are harvested at a time. It makes it so that a single swing of a sickle gives a lot more than just 1 or 2 plant fibre. Another charm boosts speed after getting a crit. Another boosts damage after using an emote. These also seem to boost the gear score and possibly other attributes on the item too.
7. You don't need special tools, items, or benches to repair your gear if it breaks. You just right click on the item in your inventory and click repair. It will cost some essence but essence is easy to get. Just go swing the sickle around a bit to collect some crude plant fiber (you do have the charm of bounty right?) and then right click on it and extract it. Now you've got the essence to repair your gear.

Good thing number 2: The realm system
1. The realms are gorgeous.
2. Some minor realm cards can change the way the realms look. One of them makes the stars visible even during the day. This is super cool and looks gorgeous.
3. The different biomes have different challenges, creature types, and resources. It makes it fun to explore new realms and collect new resources.
4. The more advanced realms offer more interesting things to see/do.
5. You can go to a private realm and basically play solo (even though yes it is always online) or pick a public realm if you don't mind potentially running into people.
6. You can choose your difficulty when you open the portal. If you find the swamps to be challenging, maybe you want to play those realms on a lower difficulty but the forests are too easy so you want them to be more difficult.
7. The abeyance realm is your hub/estate/respite and you can always return to it by clicking "travel to respite" on your map. Don't bother building big bases on other realms.

Good thing number 3: The combat system is deeper than I first thought.
1. At first the combat system seems simplistic. Swing your tools at enemies to do damage and sometimes get a satisfying sound effect and golden damage numbers for doing a crit. Then I realized that the crits aren't chance based. Hit a creature in it's weakpoint and it gives you a crit.
2. Each creature has it's own weakpoint. For most, it's the head but automaton bishops are too tall to reach their heads and some creatures don't have "heads". However they still have weakpoints to hit and once you learn them, combat becomes more interesting.
3. Heartshots. Everybody knows what a headshot is. It's standard in first person games and this one is no different, except that melee weapons can also get headshots. However this game adds the concept of heartshots too. It only seems to work for ranged weapons but if you can get a shot in the right spot it's an instant kill. In the heat of combat, this is very difficult to pull off. But if you can do it, it's very very satisfying. And the heartshot locations (at least the ones I've found) all seem to be semi realistic and consistent.
5. Each creature is strong and/or weak to different kinds of damage. So far as I can tell there are 4: slashing, bludgeoning, piercing, and missile. There may be more I haven't found yet. This means that different tools/weapons are more or less effective against different enemies.
6. Most tools have strength values. Higher strength means you are more likely to knock them down or knock them back when hitting them. Combine that with the crafting system and if you want to have a weapon that knocks enemies down really easily, then you can make one.
7. Blocking lets you prevent damage from an enemy hit. However, depending on how hard they hit it will fill up a bar. If that bar fills partially, it breaks your hand and you do less damage when attacking. Block until the bar fills and it breaks your arm. I think that's a cool system that logically makes sense. And if you want to block more easily, stack lots of block efficiency modifier materials when crafting your tool. Not every tool can block though and those that don't have blocking get dodging instead so most tools have some form of damage avoidance or mitigation.

Added bonus: when building buildings, you can put together the whole building in ghost form all at once. And if the pieces are connected then you can add the materials to build the building from any other piece of the building. Want to build a roof? You don't need to climb up there or build weird scaffolding, just place the ghost and then interact with the nearest floor/wall to add the materials. So much easier than some other games.

Some final suggestions/advice:

1. The flowers in the desert and spinach in the swamp give more essence when extracted than plant fibre does. In the early game, harvest a ton of those just for extraction and you'll never run out of essence dust.
2. Completing the different event locations (bastilles and aid/defense) give essences and sometimes new recipes. It's always worth doing those. T2 essences are especially important for making charms, infusions, enchantments, and upgrading tools/clothing at the upgrade bench.

I'm roughly 17 hours in, and I can honestly say I love this game. Everything about it is just right up my alley. I've not played [i]Enshrouded[/i] nor [i]Valheim[/i] - and have no plans to play either - but I've played some survival games before, like [i]Palworld[/i], [i]Grounded[/i], and [i]Raft[/i]. There is a lot of criticism about how this game is just not ready compared to XYZ game, but since I've not played the more recent ones, I can't compare. All I know is that I've been waiting for a survival game with this kind of vibe for a long time.

I love the story, the lore, the magic, and the environment. The realms are so whimsical; they make you want to settle in under cozy blankets and just spend the afternoon exploring. It's clear the developers have put in a lot of time writing out each of the pieces of lore, crafting out a magical Victorian-era background of characters and places. Who doesn't want to float down a tall cliff like Mary Poppins? 

I'm still early in my game play, but I can't wait to explore other biomes. There's only three right now – forest, desert, swamp – but I'd imagine the developers will be adding even more down the road. Snowy biome, maybe? Either way, I love the card-playing mechanic and I can't wait to try out all the different combos.

I can confirm that there are a few glitches in the game, but considering this is Early Access, that's to be expected. I'm running on a GeForce 3070 graphics card with a Ryzen 7 5800X processor. Settings are mostly set to "Quality", and I haven't seen any graphic issues. Connectivity has been fine too. I am not bothered by the "always online" game play requirement either; I'm usually playing with Discord opened on my second monitor anyway. I've also not encountered any game-breaking bugs that would make the game crash; most bugs look like minor glitches on my end.

However, I can confirm that the user interface does take getting used to; though I kind of like it. I'd rather not see the same ol' user interface across various survival games. If the developers are considering changing it due to player feedback, I hope the changes are minor, as I like that it's different. It follows the current Victorian vibe really well.

Anyway, I'm loving the magical whimsical feel of this game so far. (Seeing the Large Magical Moose in person for the first time was an experience!) I can't wait to see this game more polished and more fleshed out. Kudos to the studio for developing a more creative concept in the survival game genre.

P.S. I forgot to add that I spent 60 minutes just in character creation alone. Hah! The number of hairstyles and general facial combinations you can work with in the tool is incredible.

Needs work, but that's what early access is for.

The art direction is good, and being able to place blueprints for your house before building it is really nice to plan a build before committing. Realm cards giving players the freedom to choose a biome to go to and select modifiers (difficulty, creatures present, or even just never having night time) really opens up possibilities when exploring, especially since each new realm is randomly generated.

Crafting is pretty neat, with work stations getting buffs depending on what other work stations are near by. However, they can only get so many different buffs, so needing multiple work stations to craft everything will likely be necessary. Different materials will also grant different types of stat bonuses and resistances, which I feel could give players a lot of options when it comes to making their gear fit their play style or helping to beat a specific boss.

Combat, however, is pretty average. Third person animations are kind of jank (though the option for third person was added late, as the game was initially going to be first person only). The UI also needs a lot of work. They also have some serious bugs that need to be fixed (like people getting softlocked in the tutorial stages of the game and having to reroll a new character).

There's a lot of complaints about always needing an internet connection when playing solo as a single player, but that was advertised from the start. What was never mentioned I take issue with is that there's no pausing. Dogs want out? Kid needs something? Hope you're in a safe place, and won't be afk too long before you die. In this day and age, people shouldn't have to shut down their game simply because someone knocked at the door.

Nightingale might not be the next Valhiem or Subnautica, but if they do Early Access right, it could become like Grounded, and go on to be a solid survival game that offers players a unique experience.

Edit: Inflexion just announced on Discord that they will be "prioritising and developing an offline mode that we plan to release as soon as feasible"

158884229.review:
Alright, if you're reading this then I'm going to start off with a few assumptions and I'll list them here

1.) You saw the ratings on steam and immediately checked the negative reviews
2.) You're looking at buying an Early Access survival game so I'm going to assume you've played a few before and are looking for something new

Let me start off by saying what this game isn't.

It is not an offline game.  If you are looking for a game that you can alter server settings and mod like crazy, this is not it.
It is not a finished product that is being billed out as a AAA game that is feature complete.
It is not $60

If any of those things are a deal breaker for you then you should consider delaying your purchase until whichever of those things that is bothering you changes.

On to what the game is.

It is a UE5 game, so it is gorgeous with the right rig.  I have basically played every survival crafting game I can find and this one is right up there with Icarus as being absolutely beautiful.
It is in a much better state than any other survival crafting game I have played at Early Access.  I would go so far as to say it is probably better than most games in the genre after months of updates.  Which isn't to say it is perfect but ultimately if you told me it was a finished product that was getting some tweaks I would believe you.

In the 11.1 hrs that I played since launch I have not had a single issue with performance, crashes, or networking.  I am sure that under certain hardware configurations it is buggy since I also read a lot of the reviews but since I never found any of those problems I can't tell you if you're going to have such a smooth ride.

Combat is better than almost every game in the genre with perhaps the exception of Valheim but its a close second.  NPCs move around and actually make the fights a little interesting rather than just going face all the time.  AI pathing will get stuck on things and get confused but the core idea is solid.

Building is of The Forest variety so if you don't like that style its going to be a rough start.  I have some issues with the way it works but I've been playing a lot of 7 days recently and its pretty much the opposite of that.  Ultimately I built the base I wanted and it wasn't painful so take that for what its worth.

Resource gathering is pretty intuitive but the animations for trees falling makes me upset most of the time.  Honestly the biggest issue with it is that everything else in the game looks so good that when something isn't quite right it sticks out and I am excited for the day the trees fall over like they should.

Exploration is 100% best in the business right now.  Only game I have played where the exploration feels this rewarding and interesting is The Forest but since that is a linear game, the fact that they pulled off this much engagement in an open world scenario is pretty great.

Character customization is...well its a lot.  For a game without a skill system like Valheim, or a level up system like Ark/7 Days, it has a surprising amount of choices that you make about how you navigate the world.  It is an overwhelming start when you start looking in depth at the amount of item optimization you can do.  With that said, I am having a great time with it.  While the system has a lot of options, actually getting what I want is pretty straight forward its the selection that is a bit overwhelming.

Finally, I played for 11.1 hours and never had to google anything.  That is absurd in today's game market and I actually can't think of the last time I was able to find all the information I wanted without ever alt+tabing to a new window to look it up.  It's actually sad that I'm impressed by that because it really should be standard.  I shouldn't have to look at a 3rd party site to know how to play the game but it's the norm these days.  Out of everything this game does well I think that for me was the most impressive part.

You're looking at new survival/crafting games and you're looking at Early Access.  I do not think you're going to find anything that meets that description for the price tag.  Bugs, jank and all, the game is absolutely worth the price for what it is on day 1 and to be honest probably day 90 as well.

158882051.review:
******** Recommended BUT NOT RIGHT NOW ********

At a time when multiple Open World Survival Crafting games have released recently, all of which are far more polished, Nightingale in its current form was always going to struggle. 

*** Early Access note ***
I never count early access related bugs as a negative unless it's game breaking. Occasional crashes, not being optimised, quirky NPC behaviour or game mechanics, clipping issues, misspellings in menus or subtitles, missing customisation or cosmetics, etc, are expected and forgiven. 

*** PROS ***
- It is a stunning game and the concept is very cool.

- Building feels very smooth.

- The NPC guide is very cryptic and mysterious.

- Soundtrack is simple but decent.

*** CONS ***
- The user experience is very lacking. Some examples being: no reload button, you just press mouse 1 to reload when empty, which feels horrible. Not being able to easily compare equipped items to ones in the craft menu. Not seeing craft items stats without putting at least one ingredient in. Having to press E on EVERY resource you harvest, rather than it automatically going into your inventory - This would have made more sense if you were actually carrying the resource but you aren't. 

- The UI feels a bit janky. Also I don't feel like it explains anything well. It would feel a lot better if they used visuals (like highlight the food and sleep bars with a short note coming off them) rather than a big walls of text. This may change since it's in early access though.

- The puzzles are not challenging, but again this may change since it's in early access. 

- For a survival game it feels like there's very little threat. The vibe feels very relaxed, which I wouldn't expect from this genre. 

- (Going on from the above point) Strangely, the crafting/base building aspect doesn't feel like it adds much substance to the game. They could outright remove it and just making it an Open World RPG, with unlocks/a progression system, and I don't feel it would be missed.

*** CONCLUSION ***

Wow, significantly better than I was expecting in just about every way, and especially in the key areas of gameplay. I'm VERY picky about these types of games and most don't do it for me. So many are just tedious maintenance chores. Some work for me to various levels (like The Forest) but most others just feel like a waste of my time. I tried Enshrouded earlier this week and it was definitely too....childish (?) for me. This feels way more polished and less aimed at kids than things like Enshrouded and Craftopia.

[b]What I like[/b]: 
- Crafting is a simple process. THANK GOD. Place the blueprint where you want, rotate it with the wheel mouse. Add the items to it through quick add. Crafting complete. I don't have tons of menus to slog through or ingredients to manually select and add. It's just very straightforward and I'm so happy about that.
- The realm card system is pretty damn clever. Collect cards and pair them together to make a new biome to adventure to, with new resources and stuff to explore. Someone will do a way better job of explaining it in detail but I think it's one of the more clever things I've seen in games in quite some time. 
- I don't need to constantly be eating food to avoid hunger. In the tutorial you do but beyond that it's not this nagging thing to deal with like many other games. Shelter is important but you can make a tent and sleeping bag to protect you from hail/rail in about 10 seconds with nothing more than sicks and leaves. Again, making things simple and accessible is a huge positive for me. 

[b]What I don't like:[/b]
- There isn't much I outright dislike in the game but I will say that the performance is really rough. With a 3080ti amd 32gb of ram I can barely crack 60fps at 4k resolution and DLSS at Performance. None of the settings make more than a 1 FPS difference when I change them with the exception of DLSS and/or the Raytraced lighting. If I take off the lighting I get a pretty solid 20 FPS boot up to about 86 FPS but the game looks *significantly* less impressive at that point. My point in mentioning this is that mid/lower end cards will probably struggle mightily here unless you are running at like 1080p or something. 

I've seen a few complaints about the combat and so far I don't really have any issues with it. I'm just mainly fighting off boars, wolves, and some undead guys but it's completely serviceable combat. Nothing really wrong with it in my estimation, just mainly unremarkable.

So as someone who usually sees these type of open-world crafting games as nothing more than "chores," I can say that this is something much more enjoyable and I'm just really excited to sit down and EXPLORE. Already doing just a tiny bit of it in a forest biome I found run-down and destroyed altars that have rare items and new blueprints, unlocking new items and weapons to make. I wanted a game that makes me feel like I'm on a type of adventure and uncovering secrets as I go and so far this absolutely does that.

158846708.review:
While a lot could be chucked to "early access", such as combat (lots of big preys such as hippos that aggro you from miles and are way too fast), there are some core ideas that are just not fun or interesting. 

The weather system is a frequent request of the genre, and it is shown in this game that it is simply not fun. Tutorial puts you in a desert where you must wait in the shade for your heating bar to go down, else you will be overheating, which reduces your max stamina. Is it realistic? No, because you can just hold an umbrella and stripping down does not help you cool down. Combined with a stamina system that is more consuming than Valheim's (and God knows how many mods there are for stamina in that game), you know that the consequences of weather will be modded out as quickly as there will be mods for stamina management.

Combat is, at least of now, a total joke. It seems, or feels, that the stamina system is also applied to the monsters, where they dash really quickly out of your way, probably as some sort of attack that would suggest that it will damage you, and sometimes it connects, but mostly, they are just flying everywhere like a poor bee. You must then either chase them to land a hit, or just wait for them to come at you at some point, because of course, running, attacking, and dodging all consumes stamina. The stamina regen is slow, so it is somewhat a good strategy to just sit there, wait for the speedy hippo to slam towards you, and stab it.

Combat also suffers from a lack of responsiveness. Generally, you can see some sort of element through gameplay that will show you that you landed a hit or received one. A knockback, a flash on the screen, a good audio cue. Most of the times, you barely know if you hit, or if you got hit. You can see your HP going down, or you can see a discreet dark circle when you're hit, but it's barely there, it's just not enough. And attacking monsters have even less responsiveness.

Tutorial is very long for no legitimate reason. It is dragging, it does not put you into the core of the action until over an hour. It teaches you the idea of going through different realms, which is a fair idea per say for a game like that, it wasn't a terribly bad idea from Craftopia (even though they scratched that idea...) but it teaches you how to build stuff in different realms before putting you in your "estate" realm, and then you don't travel because you're busy building a lot, and it will not happen fast. I'd rather build then explore than the opposite.

Resources aren't that easy to gather, especially for building your house. There are a lot of rocks assets that aren't rocks, and you need a lot of stone to build a 4x4. Those same resources are needed for tools, and are very heavy. Being over weight stops you from sprinting and dodging, but not attacking, nor teleporting to your base, so honestly, I don't really see the point of that mechanic when the consequences are pretty low. 

It also doesn't help that you can recruit NPC to help you, but you can't give them orders like Kelvin in Sons of the Forest. That's right, there are NPCs that are less helpful than Kelvin! They always stick around you, and you can't tell them to help you with a specific resource. Instead, they will use the tools they got in their inventory and clear what's around you, so if you're looking for some stone, you gotta get there by yourself, and then they might help you out with that. Considering that you gotta manage their equipment too (all armours + tools), I question their utility and my willingness to bother with them.

Oh, and sprinting sometimes just doesn't work because why not. You know, the kind of bug you'd expect to be cleared before EA release.

The game is pretty, but once you reach your estate realm, it feels boring because it's not leading to anywhere. All you can see is boring puzzles, boring places, boring combat, trivial mechanics, and slow early progression. Hopefully, in future patches, the progression pacing will feel better, but do not expect guns and magic within the few hours; they will be spent trying to learn the game and dealing with mechanics that are not fun. I suggest to skip this game until a few patches, as the quality is far lower than games such as V Rising or Enshrouded, which show their fun gimmicks faster and with more consequences.

Nightingale is a game with a great aesthetic and concept, executed with the grace of a drunk ballerina. Sluggish melee combat, uncanny character design, and convoluted menus make this a beautiful hot mess.

You might think the game is just plain bad based on that stellar introductory paragraph, but it isn't a total mess. The dry tutorial definitely doesn't help capture new players, and many will stumble getting past that when its accompanied by rough melee combat, a crosshair that doesn't feel like it aligns with the character placement, and a crafting system that provides multiple menus and barriers with very little satisfying feedback to the creation of things.

That is a key component that's been overlooked in the design of this aesthetically gorgeous veil draped over shallow bones - feedback. Combat doesn't feel too weighty, mob ai would be bad by 2005's standards, and the crafting system just feels very distant from the character. You don't really feel a presence in this gorgeous world, and that's a shame.

I barely scraped past the tutorial, and perhaps there is more further down the road, but when the road is nothing more than a pretty facade of buildings held up by wooden poles and a clearly visible wind machine blowing plastic leaves in your face, you're not likely to want to walk much further down it.

I hope this is a redemption story like No Man's Sky, and maybe the devs will truly pull this out of the mire during its EA period, but it feels like this might just be a cautionary tale for other upcoming survival craft games - players want more than a pretty veneer over archaic systems, they want innovation, fun, and connection to the game world.

Maybe I'll revisit this in a year or so, but until then I'll be refunding.
