I love the lore we've gotten so far and I'm excited for more. I think it suits the game perfectly that the story isn't really the focus but is intertwined with the game, so you're drip-fed bits of lore as you progress, rather than having quests specifically built around getting to the next section of a linear story, aside from the goal of eventually reaching Nightingale City. More side quests would be a great way to add more content and lore. I really enjoyed the incorporation of real historical figures like Bass Reeves and would like to see more of that.

I farted around exploring every combination of realm, hoarding a ridiculous amount of materials to share with friends who haven't progressed as far, finding all the different seeds I could and building up a new realm just for farming, making stockpiles of food with different stats, building a village, etc for about 90 hours before I started actively pursuing the quest to reach the Watch, and never got bored or felt pressured to get on with it. Now that I've been to the Watch, I get to explore all those realms again as ascended realms, and it doesn't feel repetitive. I'm excited to unlock new recipes and face stronger versions of the fabled beasts I've already encountered, although more unique mobs exclusive to ascended realms would be a welcome addition.

The creature designs are fantastic, even if I do end up screaming when I get swarmed by a dozen 8-foot locusts. (The sound of their wings, god why?) The automaton enemies are so unique and I'd love to see more varieties of them and learn more lore about them in the future. Harpies still give me the chills every time I see them sneaking down a mountainside at me like a group of eldritch nuns.

I adore Puck, and not knowing if he's secretly plotting something terrible for you makes him even better. More voice acting would be great, but if you had to have only one voiced character, Marc Warren as Puck was the perfect choice, especially as a fan of Jonathan Strange and Mr. Norrell. I really hope we'll get to meet more fae, even if that's unlikely to be a friendly meeting.

The crafting system is a little convoluted to the point I and many others are using spreadsheets to keep track of materials, but I actually love that. I'd rather spend a few minutes and take some notes when deciding how to craft the next tier of gear than be able to simply click a button and have something more powerful. That being said, some minor improvements would go a long way. I'd like to be able to lock items in my inventory from being used by default when depositing materials at an aid POI or even building my own structures. Running around for 30min harvesting T4 fiber and accidentally dropping it into an NPC's blueprints with no way to retrieve it feels bad. Easier storage and organization of mats would be appreciated too. It's very fiddly right now to even place chests on shelves to save space.

I would love to see improvements to the building system (diagonal walls, triangular blocks, the ability to place items like candles or plant pots on windowsills or wall shelves, functional chairs) and more versatility in weapons, as the current state of combat kind of shoehorns everyone into using guns. I'd like more types of bastilles and improvements to the current ones. Bastilles of insight are a cool idea, but I'd prefer if they felt more like a puzzle (maybe involving the wisps or with more audio clues) rather than running around blindly looking for a glowing thing that might be barely visible.

Overall, Nightingale has tons of potential and I can't wait to see what they have planned for future content.

159648358.review:
After spending 50 hours in the game, I'm not sure if I was having fun or not.

[b]Crafting[/b], this game's focus, I think, is centered around the player running around, grabbing mats from different realms and crafting unneccesary mid-stage items that only exist as ingredients for another recipes. You're gonna spend [b]a lot of time[/b] running from chest to chest, as crafting stations (which are plentiful) don't automatically pull items from them, to craft useless ingredients just to make the item you actually want.
On the positive side, you can mix and match different variants of mats within a category to customize the end product to your liking. You can, for example, make an axe that'll deal more damage, be more stamina efficient or add some sort of magical element to it. This part of the crafting mechanic is actually pretty nice. Again, it'd be nice to know the stats of the base item without prepping any mats, but [i]eh[/i].

[b]Exploration[/b] is very mid. Enviroments are indeed very good looking, but as the game has you traveling between alternative, randomly generated Realms, early on you're going to start seeing the same things over and over again. As you go to a higher tier Realm, you will mostly meet new enemy types and MIGHT find something interesting if you're lucky. Then again, after about a mid-point, you visit realms just to find a trader, get all the stuff you need to progress and bail.
As much as the game's trying to sell itself on exploration, I never felt so uninterested to see what's new in the 5th almost identical Swamp I'm going to visit. Travelling between Realms is something I'll get back to later.

[b]Progression[/b] is weird. Instead of unlocking crafting recipes by picking things up, defeating bosses or making higher thier crafting stations, you have to hop from realm to realm and either buy stuff you want or complete points of interests to unlock a random item from this realm's pool.
Some recipes require augmentations, that you also need to unlock and may or may not connect to multiple crafting stations at once, which results in you moving them around in or outside reach of a crafting station so you can free up a slot so you can place another augmentation you need to craft this one very specific item. [i]Why?[/i]

[b]Resource gathering[/b], despite the aforementioned apparent focus on crafting, can be significantly sped up with Minor cards. I never found a need to use those, but they're there if you plan on building something bigger than a bare-minimum box. That is, assuming the building limit will allow you to build what you want.
One thing I have to highlight is the fact that the game features a built-on "wiki" that tells you where you can find every item in the game. You don't have to google where the hell is this ore you're missing. This is a very good feature more games should implement.

[b]Combat[/b] is a mixed bag. The feedback from using your weapons/guns and how enemies respond to getting hit is actually very respectable for a survival game. But the engagements usually boil down to running in circles and chipping away the health from enemies that just blob up and run in your general direction. And oh, you'll be stuck with the same three basic guns for the majority of the game. The [i]cool[/i] guns you see in the trailers are locked behind end-game grinding. And the basic pistol's particle effects block the middle of the screen as you fire, so I hope you like not seeing what you're aiming at.

[b]UI[/b] is a little bit on the "form over function" side. It's gonna take some time to get used to navigating various menus that might not want to cooperate at times, or lack key shortcuts. Apparently the UI is complex enough that it filtered a decent amount of players.

[b]Base building[/b] is another mixed bag. On the one hand, you don't need any dedicated building tool, you place walls, foundations and pretty much everything else as a ghost and the game (very conveniently I might add) displays a total amount of mats you need to complete the entire build. You can either put the mats in gradually, or you can grab everything you need and finish the entire build with a single tap of the USE key, which is [b]very nice[/b]. It'd be nice if I could pin this requirement to HUD, like I can during crafting tho.
Anyway, once you built the basic stuff like foundations, walls and roofs, there's no snapping to grid for most buildables. The collision during placement is very generous, allowing you to clip stuff into other stuff. For whatever reason, all the stuff you can hang on the walls has limited predefined snapping points.

One more thing worth mentioning is that the game is (for now) [b]always online[/b]. I've lost progress a few times because the realm I was in decided to die and kick me back to the main menu. I don't know if the game decided to put my worlds/saves outside of my region, but the entire time I played it felt like I was playing on high ping. Walk into water, the slow down kicked in a second too late. Hit an enemy and they react with a delay. [i]Incredible.[/i]
Be prepaired for a lot of waiting and staring at loading screens. As I've mentioned before, portals take about a minute to open and they close themselves after some time, seemingly for no reason. After you go through a portal, you're rewarded with more waiting, as the game does something in the background and this something may take from 20 seconds to multiple minutes, depending on [i]something[/i]. All this waiting is probably tied to their server infrastructure prepairing assets or something, hard to tell.
Another "benefit" of the game being always online is The Watch, the game's online social hub that allows players to enter late game dungeons and craft late game gear. These dungeons are designed around having multiple people in them, cooperating to complete challenges and eventually defeat the area's boss, so if you've been playing solo up to that point, have fun relying on other players to progress further at a reasonable pace.

Other noteworthy stuff:
- Performance is all over the place. If you get stable 60 fps in the open world, you're very likely to drop during combat, especially against larger groups of enemies. With my rig that exceeds recommended specs, I almost always dropped to low-mid 40s in these scenarios, no matter what graphics settings I used.
- Hotbar is split into 5 slots for mainhand tools and 5 slots for offhand tools. Why do we need 5 offhand slots? I'd like to know myself. What I do know however, is that these 5 main hand slots, considering the amount of tools and weapons in the game, aren't enough. I had to constantly swap tools on my hotbar, while only two of my off hand slots were used.
- There's no quick stacking to chests or quick restocking from chests. More running from box to box to store the crap you brought and restock on items you need to not die. Even with the chest inventory opened, there's no quick stacking/restocking option.
- Achievements are a bit buggy. I've got an achievement for entering the post-tutorial realm like 30 hrs in and I did not get the achievement for reaching The Watch, despite being there multiple times.
- Maybe I'm just bad at navigating, but a minimap would be nice.

Scroll to the bottom for tl;dr. 

I know people will look at my play time and cry foul, but hear me out. I deeply enjoy survival games. At this point in my life, they are my favorite genre. Jank, less than stellar combat, missing QOL; these are all standard for the genre, unfortunately. As gamers, we call these things "quirks" and we persist. 

A lot of people have been waiting for this game for a few years. Upon first seeing the game a while back, I wrote it off because of the card/world system. One of the reasons I enjoy these games is because of large, persistent worlds, and I figured Nightingale would have small world after small world. So I quickly moved on and stopped paying attention.

Until January 2024. As the game neared its release, I decided to pay attention again, to see if my initial reaction was haste. Maybe I was being harsh. To my surprise, I liked what I saw. I joined the Discord and followed the game and it's previews for the last month and change. It felt like each day, I grew more and more excited. 

I was working when the game released this morning, so I bought it on the app, and went right back to work. I took a lunch break, and looked at YouTube reviews for the game. Reception wasn't the greatest. I listened to the complaints, and figured the judgement was unwarranted. I like survival games, after all, and jank/poorly implemented gameplay mechanics is something I expect. 

Still working, I'm not checking Steam reviews. "Oh boy. This isn't looking too good," I thought. I figured people were jumping on a trend of hating on the game. This happens quite a bit in this community, especially to crafting games, as well as open world games. I also saw lots of complaints about the "always online" component, and while I don't like the requirements, I accepted it as a staple of the times we are currently in. 

I get off work. Reviews keep coming in. Very mixed. Steam seems to be the only place where I see level headed people recommending the game, but with some heavy caveats. I convince myself they must somehow be wrong. 

So I finally boot the game up.

On paper, the game sounds like a winner. It's also unique in this space, which goes a long way toward giving us a reason to play this game, instead of others in the genre. The amount of thought that went into crafting, and the tier system is actually great imo. It goes right in line with how, ON PAPER, this game is a winner. It's well thought out. The world building and semblance of a story was even something I found myself ok with. 

But then you play the video game. And this is where they messed up.

It's almost as though they forgot that video games are supposed to feel good to play. The forest world is designed to provide you with plenty of resources to get you up and going. That's fine, but what that means is the world is cluttered. As I darted across the map to prove to myself how small the game world was, I'm constantly receiving prompts to tap "E" like nobody's business. I wish I was exaggerating. It honestly felt like the worse parts of Ark. It was unsettling.

Third person is absolutely not worth it atm. Wait for later down the line when they have less critical issues to fix and can work on third person. It's uncomfortable to witness. It was however, the easiest way to perform during combat, because enemies are jumping about and popping up behind you constantly. I like that the enemy is flanking me, don't get me wrong. But as so many others have pointed out, the AI is absolutely atrocious. 

I didn't believe it as I read through/watched reviews. But the moment I entered the first world of the tutorial, a family of five deer spawned right in front of Puck and I. They panicked, and began to run circles around me. I started punching the doe, and after the second punch, she stood still and let me punch her to death. That was the first of three deer that let me do this before I shut the game down for good. 

Blocking is too powerful atm. You have a ton of stamina, and it regenerates far too fast. This makes combat, on top of the silly AI, brain dead. I mash LMB and side step any time an enemy shows their tell. They attack and miss. I kill. Occasionally I block when all enemy attacks sync up, and I can't dodge them all at once. Then I mash LMB. It's not good. 

Contrary to what some others are saying, I like how combat feels. There is something deep in the combat system that they got right. But as it stands right now, it is not good. This is due, in large part, to the lag experienced by the always online component. It didn't bother me much when watching preview/review videos, but upon playing it, you can feel it. It doesn't necessarily throw the timing off. It just makes the weight of combat feel unresponsive. There is something solid in there that can be improved, however.

And, to my initial reaction upon learning about the game, the worlds are small. Exploration is sort of pointless. POI's are meaningless. There isn't really a substantial way to interact with the environment atm. It took me a minute to realize some of the larger stones weren't breakable (yet?). The UI, which was revamped right before launch, feels cumbersome. The tutorial prompts in the upper right hand of the screen go on for a long while, and don't give a good first impression. 

Why did I spend that time talking about my reactions leading up to playing the game? To illustrate that I was a skeptic. Then I was a supporter. Then I was a defender. Now I'm offended. I think my review hinges on my experience with the game pre-release and post EA release. 

A lot of time was put into the wrong aspects of this game. A game has to either feel good to play, or be rewarding to play. This game has neither. It hurts me, because the preview footage looks great. And the team seems very excited and passionate. But the in depth systems can't make up for the fact that the game doesn't feel good. And it's boring. It feels like gameplay and player engagement was the last thing addressed during development. 

The biggest sin here is why play this over any other survival/crafting game? The question every designer and developer must ask. Enshrouded has a great building system. Palworld has Pals. Valheim has it's building system, as well as its sense of adventure (I also appreciate the exp/leveling in the game). Sons Of The Forest has great production value that is felt through all of that game's gameplay systems. Grounded has good combat, and its setting is very refreshing. I could obviously go on. I would recommend anyone play any of those games before this one. 

All of this can be boiled down to how this game feels. It doesn't feel good. It doesn't play well. It has some graphical issues that pop up, especially when using an upscaler, which is part of why they removed FSR3 right before launch. 

The game is in Early Access, so a lot of this stuff comes with the territory. But it doesn't change the fact that money is being spent on the product, and I felt compelled enough to not only refund, but review it. 

Oh. And bad enemy AI also extends to companions. Whew. Do they need work.

Ok. That was a lot. Now, for the 



TLDR


The game isn't ready. The systems and mechanics are great on paper, but implementation feels half baked. The game feels like gameplay and user experience was an afterthought. The always online component create an undesirable combat experience. Combat was already lacking due to CPU AI and frantic feeling player attacks. The game feels like Ark and its forgotten younger sibling Atlas. Play through or replay through any of the genre greats before checking in with this game at some point in the future, when it will hopefully be in a more complete state.

The biggest, major downfall of this game is the terrible external servers. Loading up can take well over 5 minutes and sometimes longer than 10. Loading between realms can take 1-13 minutes (so far). You're just playing and enjoying yourself? Nope, connection issues. No internet? In a storm? Bad connection, none for you. The recipes aren't offered as well as they should be, the grinding for materials can be absurd, the community, when you talk about it on the discord, are a bunch of toxic CODGamers who tell you to get over it and, "That's what video games are these days." They don't even have basic inventory icons for all of the items so you get a ridiculous number of items that are all these big stupid "N" stamps. A lot of the items are super heavy and the packs do allow for a fair bit after you get through the majority of the released game but you still end up in this 0.05 mile per hour walk anytime you have to move a lot of things around or, god forbid, you'd like to move. Speaking of moving... What to build a nice big home with decorations? Better give up on that, the build limits are so low that you'll run out 1/2 way to 3/4s the way through. There's also item limits. Placing items to beautify little corners and dress things up? Better watch out. This is to say nothing of the foliage growing up through the foundations of your home, the fog filling it up so even with tons of lights you still can't see anything, there's no paint or dye so no house or outfit beauty. Want to just chill in your favorite casual wear and have a friend over? Too bad, the enemies laser-lock onto you and destroy your home from underneath you while you lose all of your strength because for some reason this game went with the severely outdated gear score "leveling," and let's also be clear that having someone else in your realm tends to leave the little mini sever unstable. Let's also take a moment to remember that if you take your time farming movement speed materials for your backpack that you won't gain any benefit from it because for some stupid reason, even though we're in a game of magic and gear score leveling, all of the equipment only allows for certain attributes to apply to certain pieces, so F*** your farming and care that you put into that jacket, you can't have a strength buff on it! Your shoes? No! No weight benefit for you even though nothing tell you that, you just have to waste your materials which you cannot get back! Also, let's SPECIFICALLY leave out the base gear score for all of the new recipes you get so you could just be making something worthless because you have no guidance. 


Not everything is bad. The story is pretty good and then exploration is fun (until you realize they are remixes of the same zones over and over), some of the puzzles can be fun, and even though the gear system went with micromanaging inventory items to build your equipment out of things with multipliers that may or may not matter it can make for magical moments when you get it right. You can press E to pick up individual pieces of loot or hold E to pick up all loose items in a radius around you! That's honestly amazing. 

The game has potential but I am officially done making excuses for it. They've done about 90% of this game wrong, 7% of it standard and unremarkable, and 3% truly awesome innovations. 

My suggestion, in this state, it'll be a complete waste of time and energy to play this game. I regret I put so much time in. The game is in no state for stable play, at all.

160289662.review:
After trying my best to get into Nightingale multiple times. I'd like to share my experience as someone who really wants to like this game. Before sharing though, this does not help the current "mixed" status and I do want to emphasize that I think the game has great potential and like a lot of other reviewers mentioned, a great bunch of unique ideas.

[b] Introduction: [/b]
Despite the first few reviews I read before buying the game, I actually think the introduction is great. You receive both appropriate gameplay and lore progression alike. It is clear you get through a couple of portals in the sake of progression but I think Puck (your guide) is a great character that really reminds me of Fromsoftware characters in its own unique way. I'm a huge Survival game fan and the mechanics were all there. Enough to sink my teeth in, or so I thought.

[b] Gameplay: [/b]
This is basically where everything collapsed for me. For all the rough unpolished systems I can get through, what I can't look past is gameplay and progression systems. In my 15 hours or so of gameplay I have been on an never ending linear quest hunt. Clear this dungeon, get this Gearscore, go to a realm which uses this card. The sad thing is, I actually am a sucker for grinding and questing like this. But combined with a Survival game, this rips all the player agency and exploration right out of it. I don't get to explore the game my way, I have to follow a questline. 

[b] Progression: [/b]
The progression comes down to a few things. Hope, Gearscore and Cards. Now I like this idea, but I just loath the implementation. 
Hope: is a horizontal progression which is gained by a combination of what you wear, how much you have built, and I think what you have accomplished. 
Gearscore: Pretty straightforward, quality of your gear
Cards: How difficult the realm is you can create.
[u] The big problem with these: [/u] Hope makes me want to build a bunch of random stone to improve it. Gearscore comes down to spamming re-used  puzzles and fights, Cards gets down to clearing a re-used dungeon. Everything is intertwined so it might as well have been one system instead.

[b] Examples: [/b] 
I want to emphasize a few examples of why this game does not work in its current state. I do have to add I have not reached end-game or probably even mid-game, but to be fair I don't think this game can surprise me looking at how stale the systems got so quickly.

- Valheim: One of my favorite survival games. It brings mystery and player agency. You as a player are there to explore the world. If you don't get into the Black Forest for 20 hours it doesn't matter. No one or nothing is urging you otherwise. This feeling is great and really should have been focussed on in Nightingale as well. 
* In Nightingale: You are doing a linear boring quest. The world has nothing to explore besides chests around sites of interest. For a game with such an interesting theme it is really sad to see that the world feels so lifeless. 

- Grounded: A much more linear story with a similar fetch quest type of progression. Grounded, as all Survival games should focus on, has a lot of mystery. I can't stress enough how important this is as a player. I don't want to know what an enemy is going to do, whether it is passive or aggressive, if I can tame it or not, etc. I am new to a world, and it should surprise me. Grounded does this incredibly with bugs fighting each other, unique sets of behaviors and fighting styles, unique weaknesses and unique rewards. 
* In Nightingale: everything I've seen felt like a different model with the same behavior and move set as the guy before.

- Enshrouded: A game which to me has the same flaws as Nightingale and I'm no fan that the Steam reviews deem that game very positive and this one mixed. Enshrouded knows what it is and you can tell very quickly. A voxel survival game. The voxel part is used for an amazing building system, it has fun class/character progression and skills. The combat and survival aspect however I found to be very bad.
In Nightingale: Its linear quest progression takes away player agency. Building is alright. Combat is pretty bad, but it works I guess. No character progression and skills besides the items you craft. 

- Palworld: Very flawed but the focus is the pocket monster catching and the monsters helping in the base. Amazing feeling. 
* In Nightingale: Your companions feel as unique and interesting as the enemy swines and wolfs are predictable. There is just nothing there. No interaction, no dialogue, no unique behavior, no customization except what you give them to wear. If you recruit someone else, the previous companion dissapears and leaves a chest with its items. 

[b] Verdict: [/b]
Nightingale feels like a game with so many awesome ideas that I wish I could support, but a game that does not know what it wants to be, and thus does everything either mediocre or underwhelming. If you've done one mandatory tower, you've done all the mandatory towers. If you've talked to one NPC you've experienced them all, if you've recruited one companion, you've recruited them all.

[b] My Player Feedback: [/b]
If the developers were to look for a list of issues from a player's POV to improve on, mine would be this:
- The progression is too repetitive. I felt like I knew what was going on within the first 2 hours. A survival game's power is in the player experiencing the world for the first time and slowly working themselves up towards the next progression, which could be anything from a different ore resulting in different materials to a different card resulting in different materials. It would have been so satisfying to make a portal on my own and finding the next quest giver NPC. But since there is a questline I'm following finding an NPC in a new realm did nothing for me. 
- Drop the hand holding questline. The magic and beauty is in players just trying out cards they found or crafted without knowing what to do or where to go. It really should not come down to following a quest for progression. If I can't experiment, I don't want to play. Same goes with basic storytelling, if everything is being explained but a listener/reader is not invested in the overall story, then why tell the details in the first place. It just doesn't work like this.
- The reused assets and AI are very obvious for me as a player, and it takes away from any urge I feel to explore. If you're a procedural survival game, please adjust the way the assets work. Instead of a whole premade building and puzzels, try to go for biomes/areas with smaller premade assets. Minecraft's biomes/villages/towns are a good example of how every part of the map feels unique. Nightingale totally misses the mark and instead feels predictable and boring. 
- As a player I noticed very quickly that everything in the wild came in packs of 3. Another way for me to feel like I totally knew what was going on in the game's systems without even trying to figure it out. 
- Combat is just not there, but it feels like the base is solid. 
- Character uniqueness. I really liked the ideas of the family trees but nothing was done with it afterwards. Why not use a system like that and implement it partly into the story. Why can't I go for a certain theme. I didn't get far enough but it seems like I was just going to get a gun and a melee weapon. Terrraria is a great example of being able to wield and use everything but still building towards a specific theme or build.

[b] Positives/Conclusion: [/b]
As you might be able to tell from the length of this review, I'm very invested into Nightingale as a concept. I think it has a lot of potential and could be a great game. I definitely see that there is a large chance the studio will look at the mixed Steam score as a chronical illness and stake development. I root for the IP and I hope the team will continue improving on the game. I think Inflexion has some great ideas and I'd love to see a finished product

160807573.review:
Nightingale is an early access product, no doubt.

For me, it was also an enchanting experience, wandering through shades of reality toward a center that holds. The way, the realms of the fae wilds progress and also can be changed by the player reminded me of walking through the shadows of Amber in Roger Zelazny's books.

My experience started with only minor if any preconceptions, as I had only seen a few trailers in the past years and a glimpse into the gameplay watching streams during the stress test. But I did not follow its development or learned about its premises and setting.

Starting my foray into the faewilds with just my underwear, as I had caroused the night before the calamity, I soon found myself gathering and crafting the necessities of life while establishing a little place to call home. If you choose to prep for the end-times ahead, you will start your adventure quite better geared.

Difficulty is entirely in your own hands, as you can at any given time tune the challenge of your environment to a level you are comfortable with.

The gathering systems are engaging, if occasionally a little janky (I am looking at you, tree of frame stutter). With lots of different stats on basic resources, the final product of a crafting process can vary greatly depending on the input. Depending on the difficulty you play at, you find yourself really looking into the depths of the crafting systems or you can pretty much ignore it on easier modes.

Your gear can be buffed through various means, fully under your control.
*) starting with the components you use in the process of creating it
*) followed by increases in selected stats through infusions
*) adding charms for additional mechanics (additional gathering, movement increases on certain conditions, short term damage buffs and more)
*) enchanting your weapons to add a wide range of active abilities (healing, damage, weak-point information, boss-tracking, ease of gathering and more)

All this allows you to tailor your gear to your preferred playstyle, or change your rhythm by using something completely different.

Using the mechanic of minor realm cards, you can influence the mechanics of your current realm in various degrees, enhancing movement, changing weather, food mechanics, gathering and crafting multipliers and other aspects of the game.

The combat system starts out with a heavy focus on melee and it takes a while until you get good options for ranged or magic combat. Combat feels a bit janky at times, but I have the impression this may be due to connectivity-issues/server response times. 

Overall, you will need some patience, as various crafting options for weapons/items improvements/spells take a few hours of gameplay to become available.

Inventory management and item input for crafting is currently in need of improvement. The systems are perfectly workable, but are a few years behind what you would nowadays expect as quality of life. The team is aware of this and actively working on it as short term points on their roadmap.

You will experience a progressing story, which seems only a fraction of the final experience, but again, its early access and not a final product. In my opinion, the english voice acting of the prime narrator is quite good.

For me, the game was very engaging on my first playthrough of the currently available story on hard difficulty realms only and after that a short foray into the current endgame. I did not rush, used the available information in-game only, learned the various complex systems currently in place and finished after about 70 hours.

I was intrigued enough to start a second run on extreme difficulty only, just to see how the scaling works and if I could actually make it. I found it necessary to engage with a lot more systems the game currently provides to overcome that challenge, but I finished it after about 50 more hours.

Overall, I am looking forward to the future development and will revisit this game in a few months.

Very Preliminary (Will Update):

Cons First,

Network: The game never advertised as fully offline and while I haven't seen anything yet that requires network connection, I don't presume to know until I havev reached endgame its not necessary. If you have good internet and live in the US, you'll be fine though. If you live elsewhere or have bad internet see other reviews.

Character Creation: Not pretty, but adequate and above average for a $30.00 early access game.

Combat: Don't presume to know for more advanced enemies. Thus far no challenge but some enemy diversity. Doesn't seem to be the focus.

Pros:

Survival: This game doesnt seem tedious in my opinion in its survival mechanics but early on shows more diversity than many other games. Environments that expect you to shield yourself from the sun, avoiding hailstorms by taking cover, a valheim like food and stamina system, equipment repair that is relevant but not tedious since its exported to a universal material that can be extracted from any resource, swamps that give diseases if you wade through the water too long, wetness that effects gear and stamina and health long term. I like this, if you don't actually like survival, put this in the con category. We'll see if they front loaded mechanics or if there are more in a followup review.

World/Atmosphere: Very pretty worlds, and extremely relaxing which is what I like from my survival crafting games. I've seen a few reviews complaining about world diversity, I noted their time in game, and that they complained the tutorial took them nearly an hour, I would take those reviews with a grain of salt. Anyone who says "there are only three maps" is talking about starting areas, the whole idea being you collect cards thay allow you to unlock new realms. Now, I'm not to the realms extending outside the starting area but these ones are gorgeous thus far, and it seems to me that to be at the same point I'm at like most of these people are and claim there's only three maps likely requires braindead comprehension of the mechanics the game painstakingly tried to teach you during the "long tutorial" that clearly didn't sink in...

Tutorial: I feel its the right mix of freedom and explanation for me personally, but, can understand how those who just dont understand exploring buttons, finding menus, picking up objecfs, or basic survival craft mechanics could be confused. If this is your first ever video game period, the tutorial will leave much to be desired, if you enjoy the survival craft genre, you'll find nothing unintuitive about the tutorial.

Crafting/Building: Complex and layered mechanics for considering effects augmentations and synergies that make the game more interesting then many. Inspired by the upgrade system of adding elements from Valheim, but extending it to universals like all objects benefitting from warmth and cover and being on a foundation early on, but with far more indications of modifiers from the practical to the mystic as you progress (Seemingly more universal and less item by item niche). This level of advancement and augmentation seems to extend to items themselves, so the whole system seems reasonably deep.

Voice Acting/Story: This is the most subjective category but it seems mystical intriguing mysterious and drawing to me. The voice acting is definitely good quality, and I like it, but it is stylistically niche enough that I would understand some not liking it. I think its good. What it isnt is a cutscene heavy action adventure game with linear handholdy plot with perpetual compass icons telling you where to go, I suspect this is where critiques come from but would personally be a con for me so I suppose I revel in their disappointment.

158895643.review:
TLDR; I really enjoy it and have only a couple gripes. Much of what can set it apart isn't apparent right away but needs a few hours to unlock and experience. It isn't Valheim, nor is it Enshrouded, and it isn't trying to be. I played in 2 closed alpha tests and have been further than the 7.3hrs I have as of this review.

A lot of what will set Nightingale apart from others in the genre is aesthetic - the Victorian, gaslamp-punk theme - but a few mechanics are a welcome addition. It is online-only with company-hosted servers (at least during Early Access) which is something to keep in mind. Nightingale is it's own thing - but there are enough similarities between it and other heavy hitters in the genre that you may find yourself comparing it to them. If you've played a lot of crafting-survival games, you know what you're in for. It's Crafting-heavy, Survival-lite. 

For me, it's some of the best elements in the genre. Here are some key differences and points to consider:

[h1]Survival[/h1]
[*] Food - You can have 3 different foods active at a time, a la Valheim or Enshrouded. They provide various buffs
[*] There is no detrimental hunger or thirst to worry about, other than not having their associated buffs
[*] Every single food provides different buffs - even "mixed vegetables" can stack differently depending on which vegetables you mixed, so inventory management is a thing with foods (even if there is only one icon for mixed vegetables, they may not be the same combo and are thus different stacks)
[*] If you die, you keep what is in your hotbar, but you drop what is in your inventory. You will respawn at your Estate cairn or the nearest Faerie Ring, and can retrieve your dropped items where you died.
[*] 1-5 are your main hand and mousewheel will scroll between them. 6-0 are your offhand, and whatever you have equipped there can be used with 'F' (such as your umbrella, or food). Q is reserved for health potions in addition to the offhand.

[h1]Crafting[/h1]
[*] You right-click anything in your inventory and have the option to "Extract" it into Essence. Essence is both the currency of the game, as well as what you use to repair items. It is important to always have essence on hand for these reasons.
[*] Once you progress a bit into the story, crafting stations can be augmented with additional, non-functional items (Examples include a coat rack, glass jug, training dummy, teapot, etc). These affect what recipes can be made at various crafting benches. It is important to note that you may need more than 1 of a certain crafting bench as each kind has a maximum number of augments. There are a lot of augment recipes available as you play. This, imo, adds to the pleasure of base-building and managing the look, rather than purely the functionality, of it all.
[*] Benches and Augments are "unlocked" by purchasing them from vendors in exchange for essence. This means you will need to visit a variety of Realms in order to find different vendors from different factions to buy different crafting stations and augments. Augments unlock the ability for the bench to craft certain items, but does not unlock those items themselves
[*] You purchase Recipes for items to craft from merchants, so again, traveling to other Realms is very important
[*] You can blueprint out entire buildings at a time. They will remain like holographic representations of the floors, walls, etc. Then you can add materials as you acquire them, and it will build-out in the order of the pieces you laid. This makes planning out a building quite enjoyable. 
[*] Much like with food, every material used in crafting imparts it's own stats to gear. This means the type of leather depends on the beast it was harvested from, different metals have different effects, etc. This makes the crafting system quite deep once you're further in to the game and have access to more materials - I enjoy this, some may find it cumbersome, but it really lends to being able to tweak the gear to what you want it to be. This applies to just about everything you craft - even bullets. 

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
[*] You play through a required single-player tutorial to learn the basics, then start your own Private realm to place your Estate cairn (Estate cairns will only work correctly in realms with the Abeyance card played, which you do as the last part of the tutorial).
[*] From there, you can hit P, create a Party with friends on Steam and invite them to your realm. If they place THEIR Estate carins there, then any of you can log in and access that realm at any time. If they don't, they will only be able to access your realm if you invite them, each play session that you're online.
[*] Players in your Realm can build, destroy, etc
[*] When you use cards to create NEW realms, you can set them to Private (Party-only), or Public. Keep in mind the construction/demolition capabilities of all players if you set it to Public
[*] You can only fast-travel to your 1 Estate Cairn stone, so be sure to put it in the same realm as a friend if you want to share a base and be able to play without the other online

[h1]Gripes/Negatives[/h1]
[*] While melee combat feels decent, it isn't good enough to hold this game on its own. It's okay as a part of the bigger picture, but some evolution in combat capabilities would be nice to see through Early Access.
[*] Rest - Your Rested stat plays a big role in your maximum stamina, and the duration before your stamina drops noticeably is a bit short. Not game breaking, but I have to be cognizant of it a bit more than I want to be.
[*] Some game-play elements, such as figuring out how Augments work and how to get them, aren't incredibly clear in-game. Googling or official-discord-visits may be necessary.

At the end of the day, it's Early Access. If this period continues with updates and they listen to the community, I think this is a really solid foundation to build out a game that stands among the heavy hitters of the genre.

When crafting, for example, weapons, you require certain generic components such as metal ingots, but depending on which type, such as copper, tin, etc. it not only changes its attributes but also its LOOKS! A fantastic addition to detail, making things feel unique, and finally a game that I can play knowing for certain that the best gear available is the one I myself craft!

I believe this game is meant to be taken slowly, the amount of times where I simply stop in my tracks when visiting a random realm and just stare at the scenery is a constant reminder of how beautiful this game is. But that's how this game is:  you have to pay attention to figure out how to go about and do things.  That may be a bit too much for a subset of gamers who see something shiny, want to jump in and expect a straightforward approach they've seen everywhere else.  I don't think it's bad design, as I personally 
 like taking my time and figuring stuff out myself.  Maybe others crash too much and stop playing (Became an issue after recent patch.  I could see how annoying that could be especially if you don't have a high speed SSD and system to boot)

Don't misunderstand:  this game holds your hand and guides you through a lot of the major mechanics and it's great that they do because I have not come across some of the novel realm-building and micro-managing crafting mechanics they're introducing here - but there are still a lot you can miss if you don't take your time to read through what is given to you in your menus.

It can be simple enough to just plow through, and you'll survive, but if you want to make the best gear (without using the purple grape Twitch drops) then it becomes necessary to plan your approach.

Now it begs: do we need the best-in-slot for this game?  I do not know yet. So if you enjoy great writing and losing yourself in the realms of the Fae, and having the means to customize how you craft, you should check it out. I usually role-play and add tables and knick-knacks in other games to make the workshop feel like it is a workshop - but in this game, you actually will want to craft a little tool box or sawhorse and put it beside your crafting table, for example, and it will provide augmentations and/or recipes  to those tools. [+-] Give Melvin an axe and he will gather wood for you, but may also destroy your newly built tent when you're trying to build shelter in the wild Fae realms.

I understand it is early access, and I don't have 200 hours in the game, but it's not fun, so far. Here are my gripes:

(20 Hour Update in comments.
 tldr; synopsis: Hard Pass. 
This game hates you and wants to waste as much of your time as possible for some reason.)

-When any weather event occurs, you lag. And by lag, I mean it stutters like crazy, and actually doing anything becomes problematic. Feels bad man. 

-Encumbrance is a mystery. Getting the backpack doubled my weight limit, but it seems that all the crap I have to carry around to function weighs 40 pounds anyway... so that sucks. The fistfuls of berries and meat you shove in your face all weigh about a pound a piece and if you don't have several of each, you have no health or stamina. See below for more info on Food Buffs.

-The Survival mechanics are the same essential "Sleep and Eat or Suck" nonsense. Apparently you can die from not sleeping in this, but you'll die from nine other things first, when low energy fatigue sets your stamina at 4 points, which is barely enough to swing a weapon once before a long recharge. So any enemy will wreck you in a matter of mere hours while you try kill it and it ineffectively mauls you over and over. OR you may just get caught in a hailstorm, and die from rocks falling on your stupid, tired face. 

-The progression system is built around a Destiny-esque Gear-Score system. All of your progress in this game is tied to gear. You do not gain levels, you don't get abilities, and there is no "experience".

-The primary currency in the game is "Essence". This is gained from breaking down objects of various tiers into the constituent "being-ness". It also occasionally drops when you gather any kind of resource in a world of that tier. 
Once you start needing higher tier essences, the game grinds to a halt, and it becomes a repetitive and unrewarding process of trying to find that ever more valuable "stuffiness" of the stuff you are smashing. 

-Progress is also tied to crafting "Realm Cards" that let you do one of two things: Select the type and level of the world you are trying to go to... or Alter the world you are already in, often with dramatic downsides. For instance, one such Card I got thrust the realm into permanent darkness, and perpetually hurt me, all for a slight increase in loot from the "Bound", the zombie like denizens of the realms you traverse. It sucked and I immediately had to craft a "Cleanse" card to undo my horrific mistake. In the dark. While I got pinged by the existential nothingness of the realm I had wrought... or some shit. 

-There does not seem to be any real use for the metal ore I gathered and refined. I have progressed up to the next tier, and still am locked out of crafting anything more interesting than a stone axe or a leather drape for my butt. 8 hours in, and I'm still stuck in noobie rags that I have to spend resources upgrading. Usually you at least have a vision of when you can get alloyed armor or tools, but I see no such indication that I will be unlocking that any time soon. Perhaps the very next thing I do will unlock it, but I don't really care anymore. 

-You cannot move crafting stations, containers, or anything once it is built, and the only way to remove it, is to smash it with your stone shit-weapons. You lose resources in this process. And sometimes hit the floor or wall behind the thing you are trying to smash. 

-8 hours in and the only ranged weapon available to me is a "Sling Bow" that shoots marbles. It sucks, and cannot take down a deer without four or five very precise, and lucky crit-hits. 
This means your only solution to getting their skin and meat is to chase them. 

-Running, fighting, or chasing sucks. Everything costs stamina, and you only get a little bit without using expensive, time-consuming, and heavy food buffs. I found that you can stack these pretty deep, since it tracks every food buff based on the item it grants, and if the items don't stack, the buffs do, so you can do some neat things, but the buffs only last about 12 minutes, (Without the corresponding realm card that increases buff length, "Feast"). So actually fighting becomes a chore of juggling buffs and food items in your inventory. 

If you have enough of the food buffs, thought, combat becomes trivial, and the only real problem is how much hammer the enemies' faces can actually sponge up before getting crushed. Holy crap... I just smashed an overgrown Fae-Goblin in the face with a stone maul, and he took 26 damage. Cool. Lets do it five more times. 

-Building is okay, but as stated before, there are no happy accidents in Nightingale. You will be smashing walls to expand or fix errors. On top of that, everything is too expensive, and materials are heavy and sparse. It takes far too long to gather wood and stone, and you will be sick of it in a matter of minutes. 

Overall, its not great. It is a generic Survival-Craft game with the same uninspired "Eat and sleep or suck" mechanics, with a slightly worse progression system and a sortof "Steam-punk/Victorian Cave-man feel" to it. 
Also, the goat man's magic words do not make me feel good. He sounds like a more condescending mixture of V for vendetta and Edgar Allen Poe. Ick. 
The trailer had guns in it, but you will smashing rocks with a stone pick for nineteen (edit: No... more like forty) hours before you see your first musket.

After spending more than 157 hours playing Nightingale, I feel the need to share my thoughts on this early access game.

At first glance, Nightingale offers an intriguing concept. Stranded beyond our world, players are tasked with becoming skilled Realmwalkers to navigate a web of transdimensional portals to eventually discover the magical city of Nightingale. The game's promise of venturing through mystical portals into a variety of fantastical realms, crafting tools and weapons, and exploring stunning Gaslamp Fantasy landscapes is undeniably captivating.

However, the game's execution falls short of its promising premise. The characters are disappointingly shallow, failing to engage players in the immersive world of Fae realms. The gameplay quickly becomes repetitive, and the mechanics are notably clunky, detracting from the overall enjoyment. Moreover, the absence of clear instructions results in simple tasks like crafting feeling unnecessarily complicated and frustrating.

The inventory, crafting, and quest systems are overly complex and confusing, making it challenging for players to fully immerse themselves in the game and enjoy the experience.

One significant issue that stands out is the lack of motivation to progress once you reach the Watch. After reaching this point, there's nothing compelling players to craft new and better gear or continue exploring the mystical realms, which significantly diminishes the game's replay value and long-term engagement.

Despite its flaws, Nightingale still manages to offer a moderate level of enjoyment, especially when played with friends in the shared-world realmscape. Working together to build communal estates, uncover the mysteries of the realms, and face the challenges of the Fae can be genuinely engaging and fun.

In conclusion, while Nightingale has considerable potential with its captivating concept and enchanting Gaslamp Fantasy world, its current execution fails to deliver a truly satisfying and immersive experience. I sincerely hope the developers address the game's issues in future updates to unleash its full potential and provide players with a more enjoyable and engaging survival crafting adventure. As it stands i cannot recommend the game.

Okay so... I like this game. I really, really do. I would *love* to be able to recommend this game. However, my policy is to judge a game not based on its potential but if I think, as it is, the game is worth it.

I also ran into a bug during the tutorial that forced me to delete my character and start over after like 30 minutes in the character creator. This bug has not yet been patched.

It is also always online. This causes further issues I'll get into later.

In short, the game doesn't have enough content for what it is. Only three major biomes (Desert, Swamp, Forest, swamp and forest being very similar) with difficulty modifiers means that while yes, every zone can be different, they start to feel the same. 

Various points of interest on the map don't have nearly enough variety. Depth of content is vital for a game like this. I'm not asking for every new POI to be new to me, but I also shouldn't be going "ah, this one again". There are maybe 4 defense POI layouts. Maybe 3-4 agility POI layouts. The same applies to most POIs. 

Combat also tends to be wonky. Everything is server side, which means I had enemies hitting me through my block because the server registered the hit before it registered me blocking. Enemies tend to be very jerky and hard to hit, and not in a skilled way, but in a "these hippos are charging through me at mach 1, going straight up this sheer cliff, and then charging me again.

The biggest issue, though, is probably the loading times. Building in a zone is limited. Each zone can only have one minor card (basically a zone modifier) applied to it at a time. If you want to, say, stack both the card for more ammo and metal production with the farming card, you can get lost because those will be different realms. The process of moving between realms is that of waiting several minutes while the gate charges up and then opens (I believe this is the server assembling the zone), then waiting several *more* minutes in a loading screen to actually get to the zone, where you will then need to spend considerable time walking to the Fae Tower to clear it and get the POIs added to your map. Deserts in particular can be bad because terrain there is either sheer, nightmarishly difficult cliff to climb or flat open sands with nothing of interest.

Items are also buggy. Sometimes putting something in your inventory will cause it to vanish. Sometimes mission critical interactables at POIs won't render. 

The hotbar has room for 5 "main" items and 5 offhand items, but you have more than 5 main items you'll need regularly, which means a lot of shuffling items around.

The game is neat. There's a lot of potential here. I'm probably going to continue playing it, but that doesn't mean I *recommend* it. The current product is woefully unfinished and unpolished, however.

Come back in six months to a year and it might be great. If it doesn't get abandoned by the devs, it has real potential.

EDIT: Coming back to say my opinion hasn't changed, and additionally the devs annoy me because the only communication I've seen was a youtube video. 

I can't CTL-F a youtube video. I can't quickly reference a video. I can't skim through the whole thing to get an idea if they're saying anything relevant, where that is, etc. Always online issues still haven't been fixed either, and I suspect they're going to keep neglecting that hoping the review rating recovers.

158893036.review:
Not yet.

First off. It's early access, the game reflects that, but Devs are upfront about it. It's not one of those EA titles where they're trying to pretend it isn't.

In some aspects there's a great foundation in Nightingale. But raw content aside, there's a lot more work to go.

Combat has potential to be really quite fun and engaging. But it will depend solely on improvements to AI. The tools you have at your disposal are already really quite fun and varied. But what you fight against is currently a bit dull, and a bit dumb.

Crafting will be absolutely fine, and serve the vision of the game once the Devs implement some QoL features, and overhaul/update parts of the UI. There are too many different stations in the game to not have the option to craft from nearby storage (and build, but more on that later). Even if it has to be an object you build, or when you upgrade your crafting stations to the next level - it NEEDS to be added. 

Also you can't currently split and merge stacks of items without first transferring them to a different container, or dropping them and picking them back up. That needs to change. 

A quick stack into an open storage (all of same type) is desperately needed. And quick stack to all nearby storage on top of that would be greatly welcomed. 

Being able to type to input the amount to craft also needs to be added. 

And finally we need to be able to access fuel (for stations that require them) easier. There's literally a radial options menu, add it to that.

The environments feel very samey. I've been to a few 'major' different versions of the forest biome, and all are very similar aside from a few minor variations in the structures that spawn. I really hope I'm either missing some later game changes, or that way more variance is added as new content down the line. Otherwise Inflexion are definitely falling short of what they intended with the exploration part of the game.

Too early to tell how good/expressive the building system is. It's definitely functional. But unless some fundamentals are changed, then how enjoyable it is, and how unique you can build your structures is going to depend entirely on how many pieces (and variants) are available. It's far more like static building blocks and far less 'physical' and free than say, Sons of the Forest or Valheim (where your only real limit is game physics and your imagination). As previously mentioned. It would also help the feel of the game massively if you could use the radial menu to add materials from nearby storage. And while I'm not expecting the voxel editing of enshrouded, some kind of terrain deformation (or at least letting us remove non-mineable rocks etc.) would benefit the system greatly.

Puck's VA is great. So great that it's jarring that no other named NPCs talk.

Graphics/Visuals are weird. Hopefully they can be addressed in a major way, otherwise it's always going to fail in comparison to everything else in the genre that has recently released. Having foliage react to weather and fixing the many lighting issues will go a long way.

Performance is also really, shockingly bad. The game is very unoptimised right now. 3rd person inexplicably runs better than first. As soon as a few enemies (but not neutral creatures) spawn nearby it tanks the framerate. If you were to compare Nightingale to Sons of the Forest (even when that first entered Early Access) it's not even close. Nightingale looks worse whilst also running at significantly lower framerates and having a lot more instability and random drops. Inflexion have a long long road of optimisation ahead of them if Nightingale is to succeed. 

TLDR; It's good, but not great. If it's your kind of thing then get it when more QoL features have been added and performance has been improved.

From the outset, Nightingale greets you with a grind that could rival a blacksmith’s anvil. Want to level up? Grind. Need better gear? Grind. Aspire to unlock the next area? You guessed it—more grind. It’s like the developers handed you a pickaxe and said, “Dig your way to greatness, but don’t forget to pay the toll in sweat and tears.”

But here’s where things get murky. You’re mining for minerals, right? So why does defeating a pixie yield more experience points than unearthing a vein of precious ore? And why does battling a dragon unlock the ability to craft a wooden spoon? It’s as if the game’s economy was designed by a sleep-deprived alchemist who accidentally mixed up the recipe.

Now, let’s talk minerals. There are more minerals in Nightingale than there are stars in the sky. But when you venture out to farm them, you’ll need a compass, a sturdy pair of boots, and a lifetime supply of patience. Travel distances rival those of a migrating dragon, yet the yield? A handful of rocks. It’s like the game’s saying, “Congratulations, you found a pebble! Now build an empire.”

Nightingale dances on the precipice of greatness and absurdity. Its gaslamp fantasy world and intriguing ideas beckon, but the grind, the senselessness, and the paywalls threaten to snuff out the magic. If you enjoy masochistic mining marathons and have a penchant for pixelated pebbles, this game might be your jam. For the rest of us, there are sunnier realms to explore.

Remember, dear adventurers, life is too short to spend it chasing minerals across foggy landscapes. Perhaps it’s time to find a game that doesn’t require a cartographer’s degree to navigate.

It's an early access game that you should avoid for the next six months. There are far too few variants in the basic gameplay loop and far, far too many fiddly bits in the crafting and inventory management.

There are six primary materials (stone, ore, wood, fiber, hide, meat), three variants of each material per tier--discounting legendary variants--and processed versions of all those materials. There are five tiers. This results in hundreds of different primary components to juggle. Each takes up an extremely limited inventory slot, crafting requires that you have them in your inventory, and crafting itself is a player stall with completely unnecessary wait time for each step of the assembly process. If you have an ideal workstation and all the necessary materials, it will take several minutes to create a new gun, as you create ingots to make a shaft to make a barrel, lumber to make a stock, assemble that with all the other secondary components, then add infusions, add charms, and create ammo for it. Doing it right takes careful attention to material bonuses, on top of far too much patience. The game designer's love for unnecessary hurdles and details is psychopathic if not actively misanthropic in its attempts to waste the time of players.

In comparison, there are only six things to do on a map (help build, help defend, agility shrines, insight shrines, intelligence shrines, beat up monsters), with an optional tower and an optional dungeon that strings three of those things together. Aside from an extremely sparse number of quests, that's the grind. You repeat those six activities indefinitely for the resources necessary to spend hours managing inventory and making equipment back at your base.

The combat is simplistic and unrewarding. The game has a single martial melee weapon--the maul--and that's honestly already one too many, as you have limited space on your one and only hotbar, with far too many other tools to make room for a dedicated weapon. Seriously, they make you open inventory and juggle items in and out of your backpack just to harvest resources and navigate the world (Five slots for: Pick, Axe, Knife, Scythe, Gun, Maul, and the hated Climbing Picks, the worst navigation aid in any game I've ever played. Those not equipped in your five hotbar slots will be dropped upon death, so here's hoping you don't die on top of a mountain with your Climbing Picks in your pack.)

Building in other games, such as Valheim and Enshrouded, is a genuine delight that justifies the grind. The thought of putting together a base in Early Access Nightingale fills me with dread. I already have enough problems managing seven trunks worth of trash, I don't need to go harvest a ton of stone and lumber to make something nice on top of all of that.

I've played video games for thirty years, and never before has a game demanded that I learn and juggle so many fiddly bits for the sake of mastering such sparse and uninspired gameplay. There's some gorgeous artwork and craftsmanship here, but there isn't a game worth playing. Maybe there will be later.

I like Nightingale, but I can see why it is sitting at mixed reviews and I don't see myself playing it for weeks or months. So sadly, I also have to downvote it to keep you from buying in at this moment, at the beginning of Early Access.

This game fell for what I'd like to call the "the New World" trap of game designing: Technically, there is a good looking game, you can do things in it like gathering, crafting, running around (lots of it)... but there is no substantial gameplay behind everything. It's only a grind to: Unlock the next gear type, unlock the next card type, unlock the next dungeon - all with ascending rarity rating (aka a different color and higher stats).

By itself, being grindy and gear/base upgrade simulator isn't a bad thing per se, but Nightingale also pairs it with other less than optimal features: There are no rewards for doing what you're doing, no satisfaction of having overcome something, no loot that makes you experience lucky moments - it's just moving from gear tier to gear tier. From one Essence drop location to the next. From (blueprint) vendor to vendor. And you got only one direction to go, there are no alternate solutions to things, you can not accidentally get lost in a high level zone, the primary enemy group is always the same... each Realm and the locations in it are very limited in size, you soon have seen everything already, and then it's just you on repeat.

On the technical side, everything runs perfectly for me. But for my friend, who I wanted to coop with, the game won't even load into the world. Seems there also is work to be done here.

Could Nightingale potentially become a really good survival game with one, two, three years more work put into it? Yeah, absolutely. But until then the dev team has a lot to do and it is questionable if they will continue doing so after a failed start. My recommendation for anyone would be to check back in a year or so and see how much has changed.

158924322.review:
I have several thousand hours of gameplay in the open-world survival crafting genre. I asked for a refund on this game, and would recommend against buying it for players with similar interests.

The TLDR: this game almost has some innovative systems, but doesn't commit to them, dumbing them down to the lowest common denominator. It also seems to lean into frustrating trends like relying on grind instead of content. As a result, it feels stale (already).

If you love this particular gas-punk reskin of this sort of game, Nightingale might be for you. If you love the grinding experience of diving into a (fairly bland) new survival crafting game and just need a new fix, this game might also be for you.

If you've been playing survival crafting games and are looking for something innovative or thoughtful, you're probably not going to find this game very satisfying. There are a couple new ideas here: some variety in crafting and the system of realm-hopping as a part of the gameplay loop. However, these ideas are minimized by dumbing them down, instead of emphasizing them to make a game with soul. At the same time, the game leans into grindy content for building or crafting--or spam clicking eating consumables every few minutes--as if THOSE are the fun parts of the game, rather than things players do in order to GET TO the fun parts of the game.

This feels like a game where someone had some interesting new ideas for the genre, but then those were stifled by a manager who wanted the gameplay to be more typical. When I see a developer shying away from what makes a game fun/interesting, and focusing on making it more average, I'm not hopeful for the trajectory of this early access project.

I'll keep an eye on this game, but at this point I'm more interested in spending my entertainment money on someone who's going to do something new and interesting.

159386936.review:
[b]I LOVE this game[/b], but there are a lot of issues that are not typically seen with early access titles. To the extent that I would call it mistakes of developers who are new to the genre.

[b]I am not even remotely done playing this game. I would continue to play the game in the current state.[/b] I’d be overjoyed to see some much needed changes.

The game has high negative reviews because [b]people hate always online games[/b]. [b]Especially in the survival genre[/b]. I am immensely lucky that it’s not an issue for me, but I entirely understand the outrage. I'm against online only games because the game will get review bombed for it and I want the game to do well.

[b]No successful survival game is online only[/b]. The ones that are fail. (Such as [i]Last Oasis[/i] – what an awesome game, such a pity … and [i]Mortal Online 2[/i]). Online only is so hated in the genre that [b]not knowing that[/b] is a failure of the developer. [b]Market research needed to be done[/b].

Survival is my genre. I play literally every multiplayer (and some single player) survival game I find. So I have a far different perspective than most who would review this game on steam.

[h2]PROS[/h2]
- Unique explorations system unseen in any survival game. With modifiers (cards) you craft that you can choose to add to exploration worlds, which no survival game has done before.
- Fantastic and challenging combat system with numerous ways to customise your experience; without being over complicated or confusing. Simple yet full of skill expression and customisation.
- Unique cross genre end game that's never been done in any survival game of this type. At first it confused me as to why it was there. But I played it for hours on end without realising. The end game is surprising and enjoyably repetitive.
- Numerous surprises throughout play that has shocked even me (that almost never happens).
- Crafting is fun and interesting ... although confusing and requires [b]any[/b] guidance, developers, please help. (See cons).
- Auto loot by holding E is pure happiness. Thanks [i]Rift[/i] for making games feel like we need auto loot.
- The survivors (followers) system are a fantastic addition to make the world feel less empty.
- No loading screens once in realms.

[b]FEEL[/b]
- The aesthetic is perfect steampunk, fae, and demonic creatures. If you pitched that to me, I wouldn’t be able to imagine it. In game, it’s a flawless, attention to detail and incredible combination. Art team is genuinely skilled and has a crystal-clear vision.
- Ideal graphic quality for the genre. Outstandingly beautiful and overly creepy (in the best way).
- Music is perfect.
- Sound is ideal. A lot of gamers don’t realise the power of great game sounds. I don’t only focus critical hits because it’s good damage, but the (non ear hurting) glass shattering sound is so intensely satisfying.
- Lighting is fantastic. Day is super pretty and night is chilling. Ideal for a game in this genre but even more so since Nightingale doesn’t shy from the creepy aesthetic and themes. I [b]love[/b] developers who aren't afraid to commit to the horror element of the genre.

[h2]CONS[/h2]
- [b]The UI[/b]. The UI is suffering. Why, just why is it like this? No button for take all (at least that I see in options)? No button for moving an item from one inventory to another (at least that I see in options)??
- [b]Storage hell[/b]. Numerous items without images making the worst part of survival games even less fun (which is pretty incredible). The game doesn't even have a "stack with similar items" in chests type option.
- Crafting from chests is the new standard. It was only mods before, but since [i]Palworld[/i], crafting from chests is one of the top expectations. Even recently released [i]Enshrouded[/i] saw how wanted this was and integrated this (poorly) into their game.
- Item quality. I’ve never seen this done well and this game it’s even more confusing than [i]Last Oasis[/i] and [i]Atlas[/i] combined. There are numerous items of better grades without clarity on item quality. Some items have no number for their quality, and the ones that do, are less and more than those without a number.
- Crafting can be a nightmare. Outcome is entirely trial and error. You have to gather numerous different sets of items and compare the outcome to see the level and which stats from the items actually apply. It's worse that you sometimes have to craft 3 items from one to even start to compare stats for specific items.
- Building and crafting item priority absent. If you’re trying to build multiple things and you have all the materials, a project can take far higher components than needed making you unable to complete another project.
- You can only build in three of the numerous exciting worlds you can find, and they are the least inspired worlds.
- The survivors (followers) system. When I am encumbered, they walk away from me making me slow walk to them. They can disappear at will, along with their inventory full of items. I lost my NPC on a server disconnect (not on my end). They keep putting high quality burnable items in fires and there is no way to stop them, except not giving them these heavy items.

[b]STABILITY[/b]
- Because it's online only, crashes and disconnects revert progress.
- Servers (EU) are not entirely stable. I have been disconnected randomly while talking to friends in discord. When this happens. Thankfully these are not as common now.
- Loading times are suffering level. Disconnections in transitions are for me, around 1 in 6. It puts you back to where you started loading, making you start the overly long loading process all over again.
- You can get disconnected for inactivity while standing in your own base. Such as: waiting for things to craft while being at your PC, watching a video. WTF game? I'm at my own base.

[b]PROGRESSION[/b]
- Progression isn’t clear. It’s not [i]Enshrouded[/i] bad, but it’s lacking in understanding direction. Especially as to which is the main quest.
- The quest system need attention (I don’t even want to ask for love, please developers, play the game). Some quests are truly awful and made me want to stop playing. I spent hours looking for an enemy you can only find by walking on it. No alternative. It’s a main quest.
- Magic is progression gated too late in the game. It's the best thing about the combat system and you don't know about it until later.
- [b]PRO:[/b] Unlocking a new table is as exciting as finding a new item in [i]Terrerria[/i]. For those who didn’t play Terrerria, that model inspired one of the most popular games in the genre: [i]Valheim[/i].

[h2]OVERALL[/h2]
The game needs work. But we know that, it's early access.

It feels like it was made by developers who dreamed of making an MMO but didn’t have the capital, the people, or skill. That likely sounds like a scathing insult. It's not. Because what they did with those dreams is create something better. Something genuinely unique and re-playable.

The developers took risks, that is the basis for all exceptional games. Not all of their risks worked out. The ones that did made this a wholly unique experience that you can't enjoy in any other game. At this point, it is especially exceptional for the genre.

[b]Despite its numerous shortfalls, I absolutely love this game! As I said at the start, I will continue to play it even in this state.[/b] But as I also said, this is my genre.

Nightingale is [b]the most[/b] (recent) original title in the survival genre. Anyone who loves survival games should give this game at least (an estimated) 30 hours. [b]I am certain that it will surprise you as to what's waiting for you beyond the main quest line.[/b]
