I'm really not even sure still. It almost doesn't explain it at all, but there are more augments than there are crafting benches it seems, and some benches use more than one, some benches only use one, so you'll end up making a few of the same augments just because the range on the benches isn't very far. Also, it's almost impossible to know which bench affects which. You have to do such a waste-of-time image comparing to see which workbench is "tools" and which is "hunting". Which one is "blacksmith" and which one is "tailor". Some benches have 'fishing' augment, and some augments give fishing, but for some reason they don't affect each other. You also have to essentially keep moving and placing down the augment to see which bench it affects, because the green lines while placing it (to show what it affects) just seems to lead to every bench or no benches. It points to warmth, lighting, and benches it affects so there are just green lines everywhere and you have no idea at a glance what it's affecting. It's insane. Also you can stack benches or chests, but they don't mention you can't move ANYTHING you stack unless you move the last item you placed first. It's almost like a manual undo button, it's crazy. My friends and I were confused why we couldn't move a row of chests, and it's just because the last one placed needed to be moved first, then in reverse order. So ridiculous. The augments are also supposed to "Unlock blueprints", but they just do not. My group of friends have seemed to never unlock a blueprint to craft through placing an augment, we have only been able to unlock new buildings or benches by buying them or completing world objectives to earn them. The augments seriously seem so pointless, but they do reduce crafting time.

-The icons. Seriously? There are SO many icons that are just missing. Just a red N stamp. Not even a very basic icon for COAL or for CHITIN, even though they have good in game looks. It's so hard to try and differentiate items because they're just all a red stamped N. So lazy.

-The questing. The questing is also generally confusing. It starts out ok yknow harvest that, build this, traverse a different realm. But it seems like they wanted to encourage you to be traveling really consistently in order to unlock different realms/tiers of weapons, but also hold you back from doing so? But also you somehow end up way ahead of the objectives? I'm truly just confused a lot of the time on why I'm progressing and where I need to go. My group played for 20 hours+ before we were able to make guns because we just... Somehow fell behind the quests while staying ahead of the curve? It's a really strange thing to explain but it isn't done very well.

-The building. The building is just... bad. It's extremely basic, even though the buildings themselves can look really nice. it just always ends up being just a square room that you feel forced to build because of the amount of augments you're encouraged to build. I'm not even sure if I need all the augments, seriously. I don't know the difference or what they do because they definitely do not unlock recipes.

-The enemies. There are probably like... five variants of enemies? Each realm has some cool looking wildlife that can definitely change, but the main enemies are always the same select few and it just gets old and repetitive. 

-Unbalanced economy. Feels like they didn't test the economy at all, at least for basic T1 essence. You can buy a water bottle for 10 essence, and then deconstruct it into 200. What??? Why???? From there on out you can just buy all the materials you need. It's crazy, and this is basically right off the rip. The next tier of essence just seems so annoying to grind because you're just doing the same world objectives for different rewards that do the same exact thing. You make slightly different looking but oddly scaled weapons/outfits, to fight the enemies that are slightly scaled with you but the exact same look and feel. The combat just does not change.

-Just confusing. My group of friends and I play quite a bit of survival games and have for a lot of years. This is just the most confusing game we have ever played. It's just... So many stupid little things to make the game seem to have more content, when all it does is just make things more complicated. Like I mentioned earlier, I have played about 20 hours (They have played 30 or 40) and we are just now figuring out how to make a gun, and have yet to see any sort of magic, even though it seems really implied you're supposed to be getting those things early on with the amount of different things you can craft, which brings me to my next point.

-The crafting. You need almost nothing. I have NO use for ANY bench except the workbench and the sewing station for weapons and clothing. Every single other bench either is just to refine X material into Y material for the workbench/sewing station, or filled with stuff like potions/buffs that you just do not need and have zero use for, especially because you get so many from the world. I understand "Well in other games you can't just build stone weapons then cannons from the same bench without some grinding/progression". I definitely understand that, but there is just SO MUCH in this game almost to pad the content, it just all feels so useless.

-Bugs. The game is super buggy. There are just little bugs everywhere, in everything you do. It really seems yknow... tolerable? Ok? I find it so amusing I have put quite a few hours into this game with how many bugs or little things are just broken or don't work. The game is on such a good track but wow is it in bad shape right now.

Overall, I would wait to buy it. I mentioned before it seems like its on the perfect track it needs to be on. It's hard to stop playing even through all the bad aspects of the game, but there are just too many. It seems to *ALMOST* hit the mark in EVERY. SINGLE. CATEGORY. I really do have good hope for this game, and like I said I don't want to thumbs down it because I would hate for it to stop development, but it is just so overwhelmingly unfinished I for real cannot recommend it. From basic things like eating, drinking, building, to the main concept of the game like traveling and exploring (even that gets boring because you just dagger dash with your umbrella everywhere). I cannot say I didn't have fun playing this, but wow. It really did need another delay. 160022871.review:
This is the best survival game I have played to date. Bear in mind one caveat though, that people seem to be forgetting.

THIS IS AN UNFINISHED EARLY ACCESS GAME! DO NOT EXPECT A POLISHED PROBLEM FREE PRODUCT!

That said, the things I love about it are the building system, the survival elements, the types of challenges and number to overcome. the ease of getting into it and challenging gameplay that makes you think about tactics, and the character customization. 

The building system is virtually identical to that of Conan Exiles, but took all of the good elements of it and eliminated all the bad ones...like facing difficulties.  It's pretty easy to understand and comes fairly fluidly to anyone familiar with the style with a nice gentle learning curve for those who aren't. There is a building size limit too...make your building too big and you might have to sacrifice niceties like doors.

The survival elements stress keeping yourself, fed, which gives you some buffs to make life easier, rested so you can do things like regenerate your stamina and shelter so you don't freeze to death at night. There is gardening/farming that makes food less of a problem to get in a pinch and while they require maintenance they are easy to upkeep. Don't be out at nighttime either. It's not just freezing but there are a lot more of the bound (read badguys) out there hunting for human prey. Humans suck, so can't blame the bound for not wanting them for neighbors.

Speaking of bound, think undead fey. Some will smash you with hammers, some will throw balls of death at you, some will roll up on you and breath a cone of fire up your backside, others will try to introduce you to their turbo ginsu maneuvers...and the classic rush up and eat your face because bath salts are yummy. Add to this the various predators and some rather defensive prey out there and you have a nice rounded play experience.

As for character customization it is still only half done, but you can already get more customization options than a lot of finished games I have played. You even get to set up your own ancestry going back 3 generations and have that influence your character's appearance. If you feel particularly friendly to the crowd you can even make all members of the designed ancestry the same gender, at least at the time of this review.

All in all, even in its current state, I would expect to pay a lot more for this game than they are asking for. It's not without it's problems, and still has a good deal of polish to do before they can even try to get out of early access status, but this is to be expected in what amounts to a fancy name for a beta. So grab a friend, or go it alone. It's worth the time!

This is a very good and in depth survival crafting game. 
Each type of craft you do has its own work bench so for example you go to the forge for ingots and metal work, the tanner for leather, the sewing bench to make clothes and more, you start with simple work stations and then as you progress through the realms you unlock higher tiered versions of the workstations so you can craft higher tiered items you will also augment the benches with extra build-able objects.

You progress through the realms as you go making them more difficult as the story goes on, each time you enter a new realm you complete fae towers to unlock the map and then you complete some of the POI's this rewards you with essence the higher the realm the higher the Tier essence you get, you use this essence at the Essence traders to unlock your blueprints that you craft in the different crafting benches and the buildings you can build.

Once you reach The Watch you will find yourself in a town where you can unlock further blueprints and you can have access to doing Vault runs which again reward you with essence to spend at the traders in the Watch, you will also unlock further Ascendant versions of the realms you have previously gone to which again give you higher tiered items.

you are not handheld with this game and it leaves it up to the player to figure out what you have to do which can sometimes be confusing but then you can look in the menus and figure out if you are missing items from traders or if you are missing a quest or if you have a workbench built but need to also build an augment for the bench which will unlock a recipe.

as in any early access game there are bugs and things that could be fleshed out (more verity of enemies for an example) but given time this game has the potential for those things.

even though this game requires an internet connection to play you can still play this game SINGLEPLAYER without anyone else, you can set your realms to private which is the setting by default, you will see other players when in The Watch but you do not have to interact with them, when running vaults you are grouped up with random people but you don't have to talk to any of them you just go in and fight the enemy's and solve the puzzles in the rooms to move to the next, there are currently no roles like Tank, healer and damage which would require more in depth grouping.

improvements can be made like more main realm cards currently there are only 3 (forest, desert and swamp) more varieties of fae creatures and enemies, loading times, farming, but again this is all things that can be worked on

This is an interesting game but not a particularly fun game at this point. The realm card system makes the game a different take on the survival, exploration game. Not sure if Zelzany's "Nine Princes in Amber" was a starting point but if you are familiar with the premise of that series you will see the parallels.
Reasons you might like it:
1. The lore and background and graphics are spot on. No complaints there. Graphics and writing team nailed it. 
2. Sound design is pretty good. Only one NPC is voice acted, Puck - your guide, and they nailed the delivery on that.
Reasons to avoid:
1. Whomever designed the UI apparently thought their task was to make the UI as intrusive and complex for no reason as possible in order to hinder the player at every opportunity. I have seen this more and more in games as companies in order to cut costs drop UI/UX development on the game code developers and let them flounder at it.
2. You have a building game and the building system is really, really poor. It is locked, seems about 22.5 degrees, to a grid rotation and to compound that the building grid doesn't align with the world grid so trying to dovetail stuff together is an exercise in frustration. Exactly the same issues that are in other recent games, Return to Moria comes to mind. My experience is that after building my base, it randomly and spontaneously  decides to disassemble portions of itself.
3. The animation for your character is pretty poor and not fluid at all.
4. Combat could be described at best as mediocre especially with the disconnect between the aiming point presented to the player and where the game actually thinks it is. Even worse if you try to use 3rd person view. NPC AI is pretty much straight line attack with no real intelligence demonstrated.
5. While they did add a keybind system after the alpha testing it still doesn't always work and the hint interface doesn't present accurate information to the player. For instance the building option to raise or lower objects.
6. No accessibility options, other than the keybinds mentioned above, just a placeholder saying it is coming. Which is a not so subtle way of saying that gamers with disabilities are second class citizens and instead of building in support from the start they might get around to it - which would not surprise me at all if that just got dropped eventually.
7. You character is apparently a teen-aged male shrew that must eat their body weight in food or starve to death. Literally minutes after eating something your character starts mewling and you are warned you are starving and their health starts to decrease. It can be somewhat tanked at higher levels but at lower levels it is fatal. Pretty sure that people don't die from not eating a snack every 15 mins.
8. Inventory management is pretty much non-existent. They couldn't even implement something as simple as sort by...adding to it that the same icons are used for items and some are just a generic N icon (I would give them a pass on that since it is early access if not for the fact they have should no real work in coming up with an effective inventory system).
9. It is pretty easy to get into a "Red Queen Hypothesis" scenario where all you time is taken up with just maintaining your stuff and you make no actual progress. especially if you only have a limited time to play. The really high cost to repair your stuff almost makes it less expensive to make replacements instead of repair stuff. Not sure if that is a subtle dig by the developers at our planned obsolescence industrial society or if they can't do math.

Great graphics, intriguing lore and world generation absolutely crippled by the gaming UI and gaming systems they developed. For not I would recommend taking a pass.

I'm hesitantly recommending this game. It is very good if you enjoy complex crafting systems with huge and limitless open worlds to explore. If you view a game like Grounded or Palworld as complex as you really care to handle, then you probably will not like this game. If you like a game whose crafting system is more akin to Eve Online than a game like Grounded, then this may be a survival game for you.

Some of the major problems for this game right now are just #earlyaccess things: 
Some systems feel a bit half-baked / awkward
UI/Menu navigation needs some work
Progression pacing is inconsistent and feels weird (I felt like I was in T1/T2 forever then all of a sudden I'm done with the whole tutorial/campaign - to be fair, I think part of this may be on me due to my love for random construction projects, especially early on when I'm learning how a game's building system works)
A lot of QOL stuff missing (survival games REALLY need to learn that crafting from chests is an absolute necessity (especially for Nightingale with such a complex crafting system) - I believe I read somewhere that the devs are planning to add this soonish but do not take it as gospel).

Positives:
Realm Card system is an incredibly well thought-out and great system that can be utilized in ways the devs may not even have thought about yet. Master stroke here.
Seems to be pretty bug-free so far.
Graphical style and fidelity both great. (I'm on a bit of a monster machine so I can't speak to low-mid range PCs on this)
Love the world, though I'm more immersed in the worldbuilding itself than the story. I'll be honest, I mostly skipped through anything that wasn't Puck. Can't speak too authoritatively on the story.
The endgame systems are really cool.

Negatives:
Early to mid-game is tedious and arguably very boring (unfortunately, most of the friends I started playing with dipped out before we got to the end for this very reason). There doesn't seem to be a whole lot of point to this part of the game other than as a glorified tutorial. Devs need to work on this part of the game or make it clear that this is an extended tutorial and give a more guided approach. Also, let us SKIP it if we want to. PLEASE. (At the very least, on future characters after a first playthrough) I might be in the minority on this (though I doubt it), but most survival players aren't that interested in a guided story. We love our sandboxes.
I think that because most of the progression awarded by the story/tutorials can also be bought from the essence traders, this isn't a huge ask. But I also didn't make the game, so I do not know how onerous this would end up being for their devs.

I mentioned this earlier, but some crucial QOL is missing from Nightingale that are hard to adjust to. Specifically, crafting tables accessing your containers (or, at least, nearby containers).  With a crafting system as complex as Nightingale's, we need to be able to set up elaborate containers to do the sorting and we just craft from those. I've gotten literally dizzy at times trying to fly between chests to get all the constituent parts, craft the right pieces, then go back to my chests, put some stuff back, craft the thing, and then put surplus supplies back. This becomes a bigger problem when you use things like the settler's card for bonus refinement yield (which is a great thing, I love it), but means we usually end up with a surplus (unless you intentionally screw yourself out of yield, I guess.)

Those two things (early-mid game and crafting from chests) pretty much covers all my negatives about the game. 

All in all, I think this is going to be a great game and is going to eventually be a hell yes.  Right now I say yes if you know what you're signing up for.  I don't know if I can whole-heartedly recommend it, though. Maybe in a year / when it comes out of early access.

Let me preface this review by saying: I'm quite enjoying the game so far.

That being said, let's just jump into the meat of it and go pros vs cons.

Pros:
-It looks beautiful.  I've always said that Skyrim has some of the best sky boxes, especially at night, but this game is a very close second.

-Being able to customize your lineage and have that potentially influence how your character looks, while it has some hiccups, is definitely unprecedented as far as character creators go.  Kudos to them for trying something new.

-The crafting and combat is really engaging. The fact that your equipment can look different depending on what you use to craft it is a very nice touch. Also the only game I've seen where you can instakill enemies by shooting their heart is very unique, and forces you to really study your enemies instead of just blindly rushing them.

Cons:

-Everything.  Costs.  Stamina.  Stamina management in this game can be a nightmare.  The fact that I can sprint halfway across a map before running out of stamina, but can't use the climbing picks for more than 2 seconds is kind of baffling.

-The idea of having 2 sets of hot keys for both hands, while it sounds good on paper, it's pretty awkward in practice.  Having to let go of my mouse or movement keys just to switch to my umbrella is cumbersome and clunky. I'd suggest using a key modifier plus scroll wheel to scroll our offhand slots.

-Being able to craft items from storage is the default of 90% of survival crafting games, so it beggars belief why this game chose to forgo that on release.

With all that being said, I'm still going to give this game a thumbs up.  Not for what it is now, but for what it has the potential to be.  Because under the clunkyness and weird design decisions, there's a fantastic game that just needs some nuturing to become easily one of the best survival games in 2024.

When you get down to it most of the complaints or negative reviews are things folks should expect when they purchase a game in EARLY ACCESS.  

I personally overall had a blast with the game, I ground myself up to gear-score 276 which is damn near the maximum from what I can tell. my experience was mostly smooth and the game maintained my interest and I cannot wait for more content. (side-note: a snow biome would be so much fun!)

CRAFTING - 8/10 I enjoy the wide variety of materials that can be used in crafting, I like that each type of material effects various stats. What I am not the biggest fan of is the fact that it's a bit complicated to know exactly what certain things do such as augmentations. Sure, you can go through each of the 57 augmentations and set aside 5-10 minutes of your time doing so to figure out exactly what you need. I personally hope they link each augmentation to each type of crafting bench in the build menu so you can quickly assess which augment goes to which crafting station and exactly what it does. Also my other caveat is there isn't cloud storage in the game yet, so it gets rather tedious moving stuff around to craft. 

EXPLORATION - 10/10 I loved the sense of exploration in each of the type of biomes as well as the various realm cards and how it altered everything from the sky, space, fauna and even creatures. I strongly enjoyed the bits of lore that can be found in various places throughout the map. I would love to see more variety in the puzzle mini-games when it comes to getting essence. 

COMBAT - 8/10 I enjoy the combat, the melee feels very fluid however the ranged with firearms can be a bit frustrating when you miss your first shot and suddenly it's taking an eternity to have follow-up shots.  

GEAR/WEAPONS 6/10 - It's early access so I can't complain much but I really am looking forward to seeing what other weapons they add because currently it's quite limited. If I can get a sword, dagger and bow combo I'd be in heaven. The weapons we have now have some fantastic detail to them, I enjoy how the crafting materials effect the appearance of the gear. My personal dislike at the moment is the lack of variety in clothing/armor, there just isn't much. 

I also find it annoying how you cannot see what base item level gear will be until you put materials in. Which means to check any of the 6-8 hat recipes I have to see which is the highest base gear-score I need to go haul all my mats out of their chests just to put them into a bench and see what I'm working with. Also, in my opinion there is a real lack of clothing/armor for male character types. 

ENDGAME - 7/10 I'm one of those weirdos who loves the endgame grind in games like this. I enjoy grinding dungeons for more essence just to get myself a nice new piece of gear. Looking forward to more variety in these dungeons/vaults in terms of location, enemies and mechanics. My biggest gripe about the endgame is how the vendors work, the clothing vendor for instance - I can buy bundles for druidic armor but I would love to see a breakdown of exactly what I am buying in that bundle. I would also like to have some type of gear stat breakdown so I can determine which bundle of gear is going to be better for my playstyle. 

In conclusion, for a game in early access this game feels absolutely wonderful, the developer seems to really be focused on further improving the game and has created a gorgeous detail-rich game. I do hope they don't "dumb" it down too much because I love the complexity of the crafting system, just needs a handful of tweaks in my opinion. I look forward to upcoming updates, and hopefully a road-map for future content/changes. I HIGHLY recommend this game to fellow survival/crafting/RPG lovers like myself, just give it a chance and realize it is an early access game (also for $30, that fact I got over 100 hours of fun out of it is WELL worth it to me!).

158840077.review:
This game is amazing. And even though you think you've seen a lot of "open world survival" games, you've never seen anything like this.

Premise:
Earth has suffered a magical apocalypse and is ostensibly gone. You have survived by entering a magical gate to the Fae realms, a multiverse of interconnected magical dream/nightmare dimensions. Your goal: reaching the last safe place left on earth, the magical city of Nightingale.

Always Online:
First off, this is a pseudo-MMO. It's always online because realms are actually semi-persistent dedicated servers that you, as a player, get for free. Co-op is built into the game's DNA, so as you hop between realms (i.e. magical dream/horror dimensions) you can also hop to the realms of other players (by invitation, of course)... with additional surprises later in the game. This is NOT and was never intended to be a fully offline game. You can play solo, sure, but you're online for a reason. If you buy it with an offline expectation, that is on you.

Difficulty:
There is a LOT of customization for gameplay styles and preferences. You have a difficulty for your own character and a separate difficulty option for each new realm you enter. At the lowest difficulty, the game is darn near cozy (pure exploration/adventure with almost no threat) - and at the highest (called "Extreme") this plays like a first-person Elden Ring (very high skill requirement, but always fair).

Gameplay:
You arrive in a new realm and hunt for "cards" that will let you open gates to even more, newer realms... ever increasing in nightmarishness as you go onward. The fighting system is great, taking cues from Soulslikes... but with difficulty options that range from "I hate fighting and want to feel like One-Punch Man" to "if you make one mistake you are worm food".  There are temples, puzzles, crafting, building, and all of this in a game with incredible graphics that runs great regardless of if you use an upscaler like DLSS or not.

Polish:
The game is very, very feature complete and very stable. It's mostly missing little bits of visual polish - like some item artwork or minor animations (like doors opening/closing). Given the game has faced over a years worth of delays, it's nice to see that it's launched in such a solid state.

Early Access Completion:
The current version of the game only has about 1/3 of the planned story. You can follow the story until a very obvious point where all of the training wheels come off. While you can continue to play after that, there is no more story to advance... which is painful, because the story is actually really good. The game sets up multiple big plot points that just... cease. This is similar to the EA releases for The Forest and Sons of The Forest... where the mechanics were there from the start, but the story was being constantly developed and expanded throughout Early Access. Just be aware, this game is following that model - so there is clearly a LOT of story and content left to implement.

Conclusion:
This game is incredible. It's learned all the right lessons from other games in every genre this touches. And at under $30 it's an absolute STEAL... it's easily worth twice that. But hey, that means it's all the easier to convince your friends to play... and that is, after all, EXACTLY how Nightingale is meant to be played. With friends.

Nightingale is less than what it could've been at this point.

It's Ark:SE all over again. An interesting overambitious little (huge ass in terms of gamedata) UE Game with the tried and true: 
First Person, OpenW (realm-based), exploration sandbox game with some survival mechanics.

This is nothing new, but they sprinkled a lot of interesting new little bits and bobs in it to distinguish it from other games. The graphics are up to par with other U4/U4 SCSGs, and the launch is not that bad for a gamedev of this size with overpromised features and a whole hypetrain behind it to crash any ambition to hustle all these day-one logins. Every hyped game has this, and everyone has failed, even huge companies. 

[h1]So, what's the issue? [/h1]

[h2]TL;DR[/h2]
The game has a decent story, a solid crafting base with some but not much upgrades and plays better than most early titles of this genre. Bad timing (Palworld/Enshrouded) leans heavily against the next-gen claims of this game. So it's as always: tell the devs (forums/discord/offical communications pipelines) what's wrong, and they may fix it. If they don't fix it, change your review and learn for the next time when you buy EA-Games from this company.

[h3]Long Story:[/h3]
Warning: Please do not read the following if you are easily offended or have a personality that is centered around retro games. Or do, idc, not your father.

[h3]Gameplay:[/h3]
Heavily inspired by other SCSGs, this one has nothing new to bring to the table except a different flavor of fantasy setting and storytelling. It's fun; it scratches the itch for some new form of content in this genre without straying too far from the path. Imagine it as ice cream, while Ark is your sour-lemon sorbet that surprised you with a whole new world, while you were expecting vanilla ice cream. This sensation worn off with all this strawberry, apple, whatever sorbet-sellers trying to squeeze into this already tight marketspace and some of them thinking, well, e.g., "pokemon"-styled sorbet will bring all the fans of other genres into this one (with more or less effect) or, let's make it, "minecraft" would make anyone care for that old ass flavor. Now this one comes also as sorbet but lets out one main mechanic (taming) and adds so effing much sprinkles and glitter that you would think this is something new, but soon realize it's the same thing again with less taste and more pizzazz. This game gets dull real soon without something to work to, so they added a goal to get to somewhere and to work toward getting "stronger" to make more of the thing you already needed to get to this point, artificially cutting of your progress by saying, "You need more of this, but that you can only get if you leave behind everything and start the grind again with other colored resources!" It's mediocre, but okay for the price, I guess.

[h3]System:[/h3]
The game runs fine if you play it on a halfway decent PC with modern DLSS capability and a wired connection over 5 mbit DSL. It's not Skyrim; I mean, why would it be? No one needs a FPARPG with a long-ass story and a crowded overworld, right? Right? But jokes aside, as always, expectation meets reality, bummer for every idiot that still thinks all the big titles from before 2010 were so much better and timeless classics as Skyrim haven't aged a bit and that no game before the great Addon-/Paid-content-/DLC-Cataclysm were perfect games with no patches needed, and you never needed to update your system, let alone your game, to play it on your potato-celeron inside clusterf'ck of a PC to get it to work: Welcome to the world of "new games needing more space on your mini-ssd doesn't mean they must have more content: [b](UHD) Graphics > Sound-files > Rest (Shaders, Scripts, Frameworks[/b]"

[h3]Issues:[/h3]
Performance issues even with good setups (like every other SCSG), always online (shocking for a coop-focused amirite), less than average innovations for a saturated genre, and poor/unresponsive combat (like all others... No! Dodgerolls doesn't make it better, looking at you, Enshrouded), pisspoor reception because of too many prerenders and too little gameplay showing.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]
So why do I still recommend it? Because if this is what makes a game bad, prepare for the hell that is indie-mini/streamer-game/AAA-Cashgrab hell that's about to come. Indie/Short-Arcade games are fun, yes, but fundamentally flawed in that, in order to be unique, they need some massively good concept, and guess why most of the songs you hear consist of the same combination of tones and concepts of rhythm and flow? If you think this has nothing to do with each other, good for you. Just don't ask why there is no new cool, unique music (genre, concept, or idea) anymore and everything repeats itself after 5–10 years. 

That is all. Game's okay. Maybe it will get better; maybe nothing changes. Fundamentally playable experience with little to no innovation for SCSG enjoyers with fairy sprinkles and fancy clothes.

Fifty-four hours in at the time of this review! 
This review will be long as hell as it's taken me nearly twenty minutes to get my thoughts together; it will also touch on my thoughts on a lot of negatives people are listing in their reviews / on Reddit.

I one-hundred percent recommend Nightingale... for a limited selection of people. Don't get me wrong, I'd love if a bunch of people wanted to pick it up, but it is a strange blend of survival mechanics, mmo-ish presence and servers, exploration game and (easy, mostly) puzzler. The theme is going to appeal to more people's tastes than the gameplay itself, I think, especially judging by many of the negative reviews I've glanced through. (Common complaints I'm seeing are about the building system, the UI, the grind, or specific items / too many item types, just to state what I'm seeing.)

For me, this mix is perfect. This is ABSOLUTELY what I hoped Nightingale would be. I'm always stumbling over strange finds and exploring them, or being a busybody around my Abeyance (home) realm, or grinding materials with a gorgeous view. 

Notes on the negatives people have listed as follows for those in-between in opinion.

-On grinding: I expect the grind from a survival game - I've dumped a hilarious amount of hours into Conan Exiles, No Man's Sky on xbox (not so much on pc), etc. I personally enjoy it - not everyone will.

-On the UI: I honestly don't see a problem with any of it. It's to my taste, and I think it fits the game very well.

-The building system is ... like most other survival games? Again, I'm so used to this that it just works how I expect. It's not good or bad, really. I do see lots of frustration about Augmentations - little items you place near a workbench to increase it's speed / give it new recipes - but when I figured out to build a different one for my workbench that was overloaded, my mental response was, "oh, I'll just move one of these away real quick then, they look like furniture anyway." Boom, solved. Now, if you're coming from Enshrouded, you're going to be disappointed if you're expecting that, because Enshrouded *literally has the best building system I've ever seen* and I personally don't hold any other dev to that standard. Enshrouded also wasn't for me, despite the cool building system.

-Itemization. There are SO many different items. I will agree that it can get annoying trying to sort them all, because different items do not stack (in those items' defense, they are different items, so... duh?) which means to store them, they need to take up separate storage slots, which means that you need to build a BUNCH of chests. At the moment there is no craft-from-chests option, so you end up running to and from your chests a bunch while crafting if you're like me and have a short memory span or don't like to hold onto more than the necessities while at home. However, as an upside, this means the crafting is SO wildly varied - I can farm the materials that are right for me as they all have different stats. It isn't immediately clear which stats will modify an item based on type, but I honestly am so fine with experimentation that this wasn't a negative to me.

-The AI is actually moronic. My companion is an idiot who actually stands in my way while I mine, 90% of the time. I end up yelling at her a lot. Fighting the Bound is personally very fun for me, though.

-Combat isn't really flashy, but I enjoy it anyway. Again, a personal thing.

-The big one for me personally: Nightingale doesn't hold your hand through a LOT. I'm seeing this here and on Reddit: there's nothing that I saw telling you to look at your Glossary (journal button (J), Glossary at the top) to find where you can find an item. Nothing that really explains that different materials have different capabilities when crafting. Sometimes the cards are weirdly worded so it's unclear what changes they'll make, even if you're reading the stats on a realmic transmogrifier (I forget exactly what those are called). This can be... testing. I've had a good few times where I out loud was like THAT WOULD HAVE BEEN GREAT INFORMATION HOURS AGO. I will say that, in general, maybe Nightingale's lack of hand-holding is awesome in most cases for some players - maybe for some, it's the thing that makes you want to refund. I won't judge one way or the other, you do you.

I will also quickly comment that, having made it to the watch, I genuinely see the point of "online only" and honestly do not have any inkling of an idea what they'll do to make this NOT the case. When in the watch, you are in a public area more akin to the Division's home base. The dungeons there are very, very public. My friend and I entered one on a whim and ended up fighting with (three? maybe two, I was tired) other people against a giant Eaton (ent). It was dope. If they can figure out how to make it not online-only without compromising their vision, props to them.

Last note here, and this isn't touching on a complaint but a huge positive from me towards the game. The ambiance is astounding. The other night I was in a gloom forest, where it's always night, with a piercing moon through the trees. Far-off cries of predator vs prey and distant screams occasionally filled the otherwise-still air, and I had limited bullets left in my pistol and very few health potions left, so I weighed returning but I pressed on for just a little while longer. It started raining, and then hailing, and the hail and rain drowned out the distant screams and for a moment, where before I felt hope and excitement toward the realms of the Fae in general, now I just felt unnerved.
The ambiance is amazing. Sound design, amazing. From the ridiculous PING on a headshot or heartshot to the sound puzzles to the crumbling dusty ruins to the cries of the birds in the forest to the desert wind, sound is amazing.

TLDR;
+This game will absolutely not be for everyone! You've gotta love the theme, survival games, exploration, not mind puzzles. If you're naturally curious and go explore crazy things in the distance, you might like this game. If you're into crazy crafting systems, you might like this game. If you don't like your hand-held and are stubborn, you might be into this game. I have mostly played alone, but this game IS better with other players; you should be good either way (though I can't speak for how the dungeons in the Watch might play out after the Online Only change coming). I personally am very excited for the future of this game.

-If you don't like bugs (I've had very few but my experience is rare and I'm aware of that), wait till Early Access is done before considering. If you don't like survival games, hate the concept of something being multiplayer, are not the explorer type, or are really not into the concept of sorting items / your group doesn't have someone who can, maybe pass on Nightingale. 

If you made it all this way through my long-winded rambling in support of this game, get yourself a snack as a treat.

[h1]Game Play[/h1]

The game loop is very short and gets boring fast. Go to Fae tower. Kill the mobs there. Do some simple puzzle somewhere. Get essence. Go Home. Repeat. Injuries are just annoying, have no way to fix them (so far) and just waste the players time.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]

Many quests require every player to do everything. The 3D map markers have poor visibility due to the chosen colour. There seems to be no difficulty scaling for player count at all. The tutorial seems to be single player only and even parts of the later quests encourage you to build seperately at first. Weird choice.

[h1]Art direction and graphics[/h1]

The game is really beautiful. UE5 is not used to its full potential but the world looks really good. Art direction is all over the place. I am not sure if this is intentional or not. Most places fit the steampunk fantasy universe. Some seem a little out of place. Evil tongues may say they were just cheap in the UE asset store...

[h1]Performance[/h1]

If you could live with everything mentioned above here comes the part that is [b]game breaking[/b]. The game runs fine most of the time. Loading times are a little long but if the game ran fine otherwise I would be ok with that. Then there are the frame drops. These can be very bad and even constant. They could be related to physics or lighting (falling trees or night time seem to make em worse). In some cases I went from a stable 60 fps down to 7fps at which point I had to fast travel home. This seems to fix the issue at least (memory leak?). [b]The servers are terrible too[/b]. Getting kicked and rolled back a few minutes is common.
(Happened 4 times in one session. All players affected. Clearly server side). A big portion of my play time is just in the menu waiting to be able to reconnect. I had an instance crash which made me unable to play my character. [b]Now every time I tried to connect it kicks me out with the server issus message[/b]. This is where I wanted to cut my losses and request a refund. But hey - steam policy. More than 2h played. No refund. I would not have written this review if they had actually refunded me since the game is in realy access after all. But not being able to play at all seems like a valid refund reason to me. Well I hope you got some impression of the game and the state it is in.

160116292.review:
After having played all the available content in Early Access, I must say that I definitely disagree with the negative reviews here. 

I don't say this meaning that Nightingale doesn't have flaws, no, it has several, some quite evident, but I feel like people are focusing too much on the negatives, while at the same time downplaying the positives.

Nightingale is a true Early Access, and as an Early Access, it's very good. There's a lot of content, plenty to see and explore even now. If this were the 1.0 release, I would agree with the negative reviews, but as Early Access, I vehemently disagree.

Perhaps it was hindered by the fact that there were many Survival Early Access games in 2024 that were basically full releases disguised as Early Access.

Nightingale has a beautiful world, one of the most stunning I've ever seen to date. The card system is incredible and innovative, with huge potential for expansion. There are many things the cards do that took me many hours to realize; not everything is described on the card.

The progression is slow and challenging. This can be a positive or negative depending on your opinion. There's a lot of grind to improve gear, and the crafting system is elaborate and deep. The story is simple but very well written; the main character is very well narrated and charismatic.

The bosses are creative and interesting. There's a lot of difficulty variety depending on the cards you use and the level you select at each portal you open. The same realm can be a breeze or extremely difficult depending on your choices, with appropriate rewards for each difficulty.

The endgame feels like an MMO rather than a survival game; it's a unique and interesting blend that can be expanded upon. You don't need to pay for servers like other survival games; friends can access your realm, and you can log into it even when the realm's "creator" is offline, all for free.

The areas needing more attention is the combat, which is quite clumsy at the moment, and the issues with network and servers. But these are two problems the devs have already announced will be addressed.

The devs' communication is another factor deserving praise; they've already implemented improvements based on community feedback and have posted a very promising roadmap showing that most requests will be addressed in the medium term. The teasers for future content, new biomes, make me very optimistic about the game's future. Nightingale has the potential to evolve and become something unique in the industry.

For all these reasons, in my opinion, this is the most underrated game of 2024 so far.

I have very much enjoyed my time with Nightingale, and am very hopeful for future development. The endgame crafting of materials, despite being a chunk of peoples dislikes, is actually the biggest aspect of Nightingale I enjoy. 
So you have to find the raw materials, all with different stats of their own, to then refine with other raw materials, to refine further, until putting all of your materials into the final product (say a knife or clothes etc.) This allows for massive diversity and range in how a single piece of gears stats will look. It actually reminds me more of Diablo or looter shooters, but instead of getting the gear with the stats you craft it yourself. I really hope they keep this structure in place because a very unique game could come out of it the further they go.
Sure it's slow, and a lot of work, but that's the point. I understand the criticisms fully, but I also think of the possibilities with this mechanic and think it sounds far better than a Victorian era Conan Exiles.
I imagine if they went full Diablo and made the ascended realms (the harder versions currently in game) go higher and higher with increasingly better resources with diverse stats on each one.
Or if they went more MMO and improved the Vaults to be more of an epic raid or even go Warframe with the Vaults and make them a way to fuel a power fantasy with the overpowered gear you crafted.
Or they could go more No Man's Sky and make the randomly generated realms have more to them and be even more unique and fascinating.
The thing I fear though is that they backtrack and appease rather than focus on whatever their vision was, more than any game I have played in EA or tested Prerelease in probably near a decade I am excited about the potential for Nightingale, not just how fun it can/will be, or how well received it can be, but the potential to be something grand, possibly larger than itself.
Sure, it mashes a lot of other game mechanics together, but that's what games have done since the early 90's. That's how new genres are born.

With that said I would recommend this game currently, because it is fully playable and enjoyable, but only to people that enjoy slow paced, grindy, big number big damage type games - I would say 50 hours for a typical player currently and a couple hundred if you're like me and want to experience everything you can to offer feedback/personal fascination/whatever

TLDR: Nightingale currently is a beautiful art piece with interesting mechanics, rough around the edges, and currently would only recommend to a niche set of people but has the potential to pave it's own niche.

First, this was a gift from a friend, and I'm deeply appreciative for the gift copy.
Second, there are a lot of things about this game I do like. It's got some very neat creatures, and I love the way portals look when they open. I also think the augments idea is neat in theory (though the execution is poor).

However, it does not deserve a recommendation at this time.
1. The biggest reason overall: Gear Score. You unlock areas by equipping better items which raise some abstract number called a gear score. However, the game only tells you the gear score requirement for the first area restricted in this manner. The rest are simply locked away with no explanation. I dunno who green lit this idea, but it's definitively not fun.
2. The instructions for completing various objectives are not immediately apparent, and need refining. When walking past a challenge, you receive a journal entry describing the goal of a given challenge. However, this occurs when they are not registered on the map, leaving the player to guess what they are looking at. Additionally, some aspects are never described, such as hitting buttons via a slingbow.
3. Climbing picks are useless. They eat up stamina so fast at the base level, there is zero advantage to using them.
4. Unlocking recipes is a chore. Scavenge materials just to destroy them then hike back to a shop with random stuff that may or may not be what you need. The same item used as currency is also used to repair items, which wear down constantly. It's an inflated time sink.
5. The augmentations aren't cohesive. They work as follows: build a crafting station, then build a decorative item to unlock recipes. Cool idea...but why do the bellows unlock recipes for the sewing bench and not the smelter??? They can't attach through walls either, so there's no way to fudge cohesive decor while still gaining the proper functions.

For a game which has spent so long in development, it feels surprisingly "same-y" compared to other survival games. There's no reason to pick this specific game over another aside from perhaps the Victorian theme.

I *do* hope the game stays afloat long enough to fix the various issues. It just feels like an uphill battle right now.

158994661.review:
As a survival game enthusiast, The more I play it, the more I want to keep going. It has a lot of things going for it, and maybe my favorite is the hosted servers. 

Typically survival games are hosted locally (your friend needs to be online to be able to play on the server they're hosting), or dedicated servers hosted privately that usually assumes some fee or maintenance requirement. In Nightingale, the servers are hosted for us by Inflexion (the game studio) and you can join and play on the same realm regardless of who's online.

Just following the main quest of Nightingale took me about 80 hours of casual gameplay to reach the end of the story (theres a bunch more of content  after the story). 

The main gameplay loop is awesome. You go through a few tutorial realms and end up in a safe realm to get your footing (and begin to meet up with friends if you want); this is where your main base(s) will be. At this point you're free to do what you want, but a main quest will guide you through progression in typical survival game style. The main idea in Nightingale is you craft some gear, explore a new realm, return home to clear a point of interest which unlocks a more challenging realm up to a point where the story takes you to a main hub. This is technically the end of the story, but it gets a lot harder with the content that's opened up after this. All along the way there are puzzles, and objectives all over the maps giving you plenty to do. 

The crafting system is insanely good. Every single material that you use to craft with contributes towards the crafts stats. It's my favorite crafting of any game I've ever played. Enough said.

The building system is solidly designed. Theres a cap to how many objects you can place down, but its sufficient enough to give you room for creativity, and the cap is only limited per realm, so you could have multiple bases to bypass the cap. There's some more intricacies to the system. All in all it's nothing too inventive, but its well implemented and what you would expect from a survival game.

The combat is actually pretty fun, to the point where you're using all your tools differently based on situation. When im clearing a group dungeon, I'm switching between multiple tools for mobility, damage, healing, etc and it feels pretty fluid.

All this being said, the game is still in EA, so there are some challenges. There can be occasional disconnects (due to popular demand, they're looking into an offline mode), the UI is a little tedious in some places, follower AI is basic, placeholder assets very apparent on item thumbnails, personally i get framerate drops a lot (but im on an ancient pc and havent bothered looking into the graphics settings much), and the game overall has a few areas to polish off. It has a solid foundation and incredible potential.

TLDR: Game is great, has a lot of potential and I'll likely be playing and coming back to this game frequently, but if you can't handle a few Early access headaches (nothing gamebreaking) you may want to wait until it's on sale or a few kinks get worked out. Do wishlist for later though.

159576723.review:
If you're wondering why this game has a low review score, it's pretty simple to say: this is a tried and true early access game, and people are not used to "early access" actually meaning "early access." It's a game in its early stages, and there is going to be a lot of unpolished portions of the game. I know some games use the "early access" tag for funsies (looking at you Ark Survival), but this isn't one of those games.

With that said, is this game good? Absolutely. This game is fantastic. The foundation of this game is insane, and will absolutely lead you to know that its future - as long as they continue on this path - is going to be something even greater. 

So what's so good about it? 

The world: the environment, the story, the aesthetics... they're immaculate. The gaslamp/victorian/edwardian-vibe mixed with a magical twist has created something breathtaking. Look at screenshots & gameplay, and you'll see it in the skybox, in the enemy art. It's beautiful, and it's just the beginning. 

The gameplay loop: the loop for this survival game is unique and interesting. You go through procedurally generated realms to unlock & obtain what would otherwise be limited resources. The combination of the type of realms that you can enter and raze are many, and they've already stated they'll continue to add more and more overtime. 

The combat: the combat could use some polish (as magic is experiencing some limitations at the moment) but it is satisfying. You can get heart shots, which are even more potent than head shots. You can use magic, guns, and melee weapons, and will need to switch to better deal with enemy strengths/weaknesses. 

The story: this game has, perhaps, some of the best writing I have seen in a long time. The story is profound, and has many twists and turns that keeps you on your toes. The fantasy it sets is a refreshing take on steampunk, and you'll see some familiar names from history riddled throughout. You'll be able to read journal entries that tell the tale of the final days of its writer, the beauty of a marriage between Fae & Human, the strife of the Fae Courts, the horrors of the unknown, and so much more. The writing casts such a wide net so quickly, that I worried it may have been too much too quickly. But they do so well in explaining and keeping things together. Pay attention, you'll find sometimes that not everything is as it seems. 

THE DEVS: These are the most quick-to-address devs I have seen in an early access. They listen to the population and have consistently said "We've heard you, and now we're working on it." They're active, they're doing what they said they'd do, and I give them so many props for that. 

Alright, so what needs help?

Polish. It doesn't have it, and it desperately needs it. From things like wonky traders, who may trade varying sets of the same armor, to trees that can lag you to high hell if you're not careful... The game has fantastic features, but they're rigid and definitely need polishing. 

Building. It looks like they're testing their servers strength by first imposing a building limit. For people who are into massive builds, you'll find that you may have to employ some tricky strats in order to get around limitations on building. To quickly tl;dr the situation with building, you can make hundreds of midsized buildings, but if you're looking to go Minecraft Mega Builder with a single building you'll need to get clever. 

And finally: it simply needs MORE. There is plenty to do now, but we need more! The early access gives you a great breadth of the game that leaves you wanting so much more, and they tease you with all the soon-to-come things, that you'll be begging for all of it now. This is where the early access part comes to bite us all. 

I could go on forever about this game, but overall: I love it, and I can't wait to see Inflexion grow this beautiful game into something enormous. I wish them all the success they deserve.

In its Early Access state, Nightingale shows great potential with its captivating world and solid core mechanics. However, it’s not without its rough spots. The game can swing between being aesthetically pleasing and outright jarring, and making meaningful progress can sometimes feel laborious.

159731079.review:
I just crossed 40 hours with Nightingale, probably half solo and half with a friend or two. I'll start off by saying I desperately want to like this game and genuinely hope the feedback and early access cash infusion happening right now translates into more fruitful development. There are a lot of great ideas and potential I am sincerely excited about. But Nightingale needs a LOT more time in the oven before before I expect I'll be able to feel optimistic or pessimistic about its ability to rise to that potential. This isn't 'early access' as we've come to experience it in the last ~4 years. It feels like ***EARLY*** access.

Spoilers to follow:

I'd like to focus more on what the initial experience was like, what worked and what didn't, and then what I would hope to see added or changed in future versions of the game, and less on the aspects that are inherent to the 'Early Access' status, like janky animations, or the immature crafting and progression systems.

The tutorial process was fine, pretty smooth. Character creation is currently meaningless. The family history aspect of creating your character either needs to be streamlined and made more impactful down the line (like on your stats, or maybe some story beats?), or just cut in favor of something more straightforward that can achieve the same visual results.

The Fae dimension-Stargate system with the Realm Cards has so much potential. Each realm you open a portal to is finite in size, but still decently large, and has a small degree of procedural generation. But currently there is not enough variety, of anything, to take full advantage of this setup. Realm traits, like the topography, numbers of creatures and enemies, types of sites and puzzles... are all going to need a great deal more diversity. No Man's Sky in 2016 suffered from this, but eventually iterated its way up to something that is way more fun to explore. I see no reason Nightingale can't get there, but it's going to take iterating on the bones. Everything currently looks and feels too much the same, regardless of what cards you use to spice things up.

The best example I have is when I first jumped into the Desert Herbarium level realm, and realized I could not access the next story character without adequate climbing picks and stamina to make the climb. Everything before that point had just been "find icon on map, walk there" level of challenging. That made work I had done previously feel meaningful, instead of just filler. Nightingale needs more progression obstacles and solutions like this. It could really fill out how much exploration and play time you get per realm you visit, instead of just popping in, raiding it for every resource you can, buying all the recipes from a vendor or two randomly dropped in the map, and then never going there again.

A handful of quick ideas on this topic before moving on: Maybe vendors don't show up in the Realm until you've done some objectives and built a base of operations. Reconnect some portals so they can find you, and have a safe place to show up, THEN you can have their recipes/knowledge as part of the reward loop. The instanced 'dungeons' that are found in some realms could be expanded and diversified, and maybe opening those portals to do that content is gated by some realm-specific crafting which isn't difficult, but encourages exploration. Gating things behind tool upgrades for resources you can't harvest until your tool is a certain level feels very outdated, and not adequate alone. It could take a Zelda:TotK approach and let crafting certain equipment be part of the exploration progression. Generated ravines that you need the right equipment to get across, creatures you need materials from that need a special lure, a gatekeeper who needs three very specific items before letting you pass, which you can read about in the lore drops found around the world... just more. More variety, more obstacles to solve, more ways to solve them.

The building system shines because of the 3d blueprint feature. This should be supported down the line with more cosmetic building component options, and less grueling crafting queues/times to get higher level building materials. Just like with Enshrouded, there is currently no real threats to your bases, so materials are essentially just cosmetic. A roof made of sticks keeps the rain off just as well as stone, or fancier materials. Creating reasons to build forward bases and benefits for going deeper into the build trees will be beneficial.

The boss fights are currently a pretty low point to the experience. These need work to even bring them up to Valheim's level of boss encounter enjoyability, though it would be amazing if they ended up feeling closer to Remnant II's boss encounters.

The crafting system gets pretty complex, and for many, very tedious. I don't personally mind a complex crafting system, especially if I have sight of some great goals it will eventually get me to, like access to higher level realms, more challenging combats, or really amazing cosmetic build options. But using No Man's Sky as an example again, there is a balance to be struck with a complex crafting system that has many different items. It can feel rich and full of options, or just a tedious drag. Getting this right is probably going to take a lot of testing and iteration.

I'm never going to want to reach the end game as the trailers depict right now if the game is repetitive and works against engagement. Nightingale needs to do its best to not re-tread tired mistakes that the Survival genre has been making since inception, and seize on the "what's over the horizon?" feeling, along with "I want to live there!", or better yet "I want to live there with my friends."

I will look forward to jumping back in to see how Nightingale progresses, but I think I'm probably mostly done for the time being. Good luck, have fun.

159724130.review:
Nightingale isn't a terrible game, but there are some really bad decisions that the devs have made that significantly lowers the enjoyment value as a whole. I would hold off until these issues have been resolved. I think you can boil down the problems to two main categories: networking and crafting.

This is an online-only experience, and one of the worst I've ever played in that regard. I have never seen loading screens this long in any generation of gaming. Sometimes when I initially load the game, it takes upwards of three minutes to actually load me into the realm. There is either something seriously wrong with how the game loads assets, the path my computer takes to communicate with their servers, or the servers themselves. Perhaps all of the above.

Network-related issues don't stop once you've loaded into a realm, either. You will frequently encounter significant freeze-ups or stuttering when mining or chopping lots of trees down; for whatever reason, the server doesn't seem to handle this very well. During these times my framerate is not dipping whatsoever. Enemies often just straight-up miss you as long as you are walking backwards and diagonally due to network lag. It's a real shame because I don't think the combat is nearly as bad as the server sync issues portray, but when you run into fast charging hippos that are rubber-banding all over the place and nearly impossible to hit as a result, it makes you want to just ignore them and do something else.

You are going to repeatedly be jumping between realms to complete quests, gather realm-specific materials, or head back to your main base to drop off loot and craft better gear. You can only have one main base and thus only one spot where you can fast travel at a time, so it's pretty much required that you build your base near the NPCs of that realm if you don't want to walk for several minutes just to buy items or do quests. And going back to the comment about loading screens, since you only have one base, you'll have to sit through twice as many loading screens every time you need to pick up or drop something off (these are usually shorter than the initial loading screen, but still take thirty seconds to two minutes each time). To a small credit, I have thus far not been disconnected from the server even once in 40hrs. Whether or not just being disconnected would've ameliorated some of the weird issues is another story.

The other major issue with the game is the crafting system. It is a convoluted mess. There are more different materials and items here than I've seen in most other survival games. It almost reminds me of an overly-modded Terraria, minus the ability to have any quality-of-life storage to mitigate the bulk of the confusion. You have different composite materials, material types, material tiers, even different version of materials such as those with ingots. There is no visual differentiation between any of these items at a glance from within your storage. Even worse, many of the materials have no unique icon to begin with, instead sharing a placeholder 'N' stamp symbol, meaning you need to hover over each individual item with these placeholders until the tooltip pops up to inform you what the item actually is.

Most of the recipes involve crafting some obscure material from another bench, which as it turns out requires some other obscure material obtained from another bench to craft said bench, and the recipe utilizes some incredibly vague wording to not-quite clue you in as to what it means you need to acquire, so then you have to give up and tab out to look it up online instead of checking the in-game guidebook or search functions (which absolutely suck btw, because networking hiccups often cause the search bar to become just briefly unresponsive long enough to make the game thing you're trying to change menus instead of type in the search box)

You will receive tons of augments, which are basically furniture/decorations that grant certain recipes to your crafting stations. As it turns out, the game gives you more of these than you can use per station, meaning you'll have to remove some to utilize others. This is a pretty stupid and meaningless limitation that just adds to the fu­cking-you-around element that crafting is.

There are other issues, such as the bizarre flickering on every single surface when you move. I don't know what causes it, but it's probably my runner-up for third worst issue that occurs way too often and doesn't seem to resolve itself until you reboot the game entirely and sit through another several minutes of loading screens.

Your NPC survivor/recruit follower is impossible to control and does whatever it wants, when it wants, sometimes to great detriment. Giving it an axe before clearing the entire area around your base of trees is a miserable experience, giving it a hammer seems to make it actually damage your base, giving it any type of precious wood that happens to double as a fuel source (because you weren't being screwed with enough) causes the stupid fu­cker to beeline to any campfire you come within proximity of (and don't think avoiding building a campfire will prevent this, because there are prebuilt campfires littered throughout every realm) and promptly chuck all your burnables into the furnace. It is incapable of using ranged weapons. As useless and annoying as this all sounds, your personal idiot is unfortunately indispensable for its lack of weight limit, meaning it can carry full stacks of heavy materials for you without issues.

Overall, Nightingale is not worth it at the moment. Check it out when the major grievances have been ironed out and the game is more than just beautiful vistas and skyboxes.

159262225.review:
Unbiased Review

Initial Excitement Fades:

While initially anticipating Nightingale's release with high expectations, my personal experience has fallen short of the mark.

Inventory Frustrations:

The inventory system presents a significant hurdle. It's overly complex, featuring multiple tiers with similar items, often lacking images. This lack of clarity and organization hinders user experience.

Repetitive World Design:

The world design suffers from repetitiveness. Similar layouts, including identical cracked walls across different biomes and levels, dampen the sense of exploration and discovery.

Character Annoyances:

Certain characters, like Puck, are annoying and condescending, detracting from the overall enjoyment. Additionally, the companion AI, Perry, consumes valuable resources unwisely, further frustrating players.

Engaging Mechanic:

The ability to modify environmental variables through card selection across biomes offers an engaging and dynamic gameplay element.

Visual Appeal vs. Gameplay:

While the visuals are undeniably impressive, they unfortunately do not translate into equally compelling gameplay. The experience is often described as bland and lacking depth.

Grindy MMO Concerns:

As an MMO, the game leans heavily on repetitive actions (grinding), which may not appeal to all players. This, coupled with the previously mentioned issues, could lead to player dissatisfaction and made me go mad.

Trailer Accuracy:

I think that concerns should be raised regarding the trailer's potential to mislead players. While a "No Man's Sky" style turnaround is theoretically possible, significant and immediate changes are seen as necessary to prevent the game from aging poorly. And the stats showcase that many never made it as far as I did.

5.5 out of 10

159202863.review:
I'm an avid lover of survival games. I play them all, including the many many in Early Access. I ran into no bugs, very little lag, my system played it completely fine. I have run many D&D campaigned based in the Fae Realms. This game is the epitome of a game for me.

Do not buy this game.

This game, despite the marketing and style is barely scratching the surface of Minimum Viable Product. I played for 9 hours, and have made it through to the end of Tier 1 content (Which is actually the 3rd tier of gear and items). During my time playing 85%+ of the enemies in game have been: Bound (which lets be real are just Zombies) which are probably 60% of that number, Deer, Wolves, Pigs and Rabbits. For the remaining 15% I fought actual "Fae creatures": mostly Robots named after chess pieces which... I dont know maybe that's Fae but I've never read it before, Grasshoppers but bigger, a total of 6 Water Kangaroos (from the tutorial), Deer - but green and with curly fries for horns (thus Fae I guess?) and the one creature I might actually consider Fae being a Fae Elephant.

That's incredibly disappointing, they couldn't even really create a style of substance experience, in a theme that is so EASY to make stylistic.

OH AND LETS GET TO THE SUBSTANCE!

The main game loop starts up really fast after you get past your first few hours of grinding basic survival stuff to get your main base going and your crafting stations online. In hind sight, I should have got this much faster if it weren't for me trying to play the game like a survival game and collecting the items. A very large bottleneck for getting stations up was turning meat into fibre to unlock all the stations. I would go around hunting animals specifically to get more and more meat, but multiple stations took 30 meat worth of fibre, and that's when I started to notice something. The number of animals and locations always spawned near a point of interest, and in the same amount, and there was only so many to farm.

Then I realised that actually farming materials is not how you play this game. You need Essence, and this never changes. It is the only and single most important resource in the game, and is incredibly easy to get early game. I could buy a meat for 10 essence, and by cutting down a grass I could get enough material to turn into 6 essence per swing. Instead of 40 minutes of hunting I quintupled the amount I got in like 2 minutes. Oops, my bad for playing the game.

Now onto the main game loop. Stop me if you have heard this one before: You climb a tower in an area, and it unlocks the map of the area. You then run around and do highlighted points of interest to complete either an "intellect puzzle", a jumping puzzle, kill 5 zombies (and it was ALWAYS zombies), defend a machine from waves of Zombies (and it was ALWAYS zombies) or turn in a bunch of wood, sticks and plant fibre to complete a building an NPC requested. This would provide you with the true material that matters: Tier 1 Essences! Its like the other essence, but you have to do these events, and its green! Yes you can also randomly get a little bit from gathering materials, but it simply was viable or a good use of your time. You need these to upgrade the item level of your gear. No other materials needed, just the essence. Better or different materials will let you make the EXACT same axe, pick, weapon, umbrella whatever, but with slightly different or better base stats, but the item level of the item is all that matters.

So, the game is climb an Ubisoft Tower, then do World of Warcraft world quests. Except they are all procedural generated BUT also extremely samey, so ... worse than World of Warcraft world quests.

I tried to push the main story far enough that maybe, MAYBE This game gets better. I got to a point where I found Victor Frankenstein! OH! He was mentioned in the Trailer! This must be good!

Oh... he's talking about ... robots and the writing is extremely verbose, and not stylised at all... doesn't sound like the books. Sure whatever. So he talks about these Chess piece robots for at least 12 click throughs where he talks about something different than what we ask. He then of course sends me on a quest.

To kill some robots? No no no. Maybe find some plans for these robots since he was talking about figuring out how they work? No. Maybe capture one and bring it back? No.

HE SENDS YOU TO KILL FUCKING ZOMBIES!

159195311.review:
Now that I have 100% the achievements and killed every boss and vault, I cannot recommend this game at this time. I will keep an eye on this game and reassess when and if changes are made. 

It has a great aesthetic and setting, but does very little to differentiate itself or even rise to the level of other survival titles. If this game hadn't come out post Palworld and Enshrouded I would be a little more kind to it, but as it stands now it lacks so many QoL features and makes frankly baffling gameplay decisions. On top of the woes of Early Access bugs. 

Pros: 
- Good aesthetic
- Good setting
- Vaults are a neat idea, even though they are very shallow right now
- Using dash in the air with umbrella and veil card or soaring favor is actually so much fun. Please do more things like this. 
- Puzzles are fun at the start, but there isn't enough variety. 
- A bright future if the devs stick with it

Cons:
- Trivial combat, I died once ever on Medium and that was in the Apex swamp vault at ilvl 169. Then I came back with Ice Buckshot and killed him in 3 mins. 
- Bad gear progression. I used the same gear I started with to finish the game. I didn't bother to make new sets because they come so late and the enemies are just too bad to matter. I didn't bother crafting any of the firearms besides the first shotgun and rifle, and I'm certainly not going to grind for Dauntless stuff when the enemies are such jokes. 
- Item level requirements force you to do more chores in order to earn the privilege to fight a new boss that will take you between 60 - 200 seconds because they are so trivial. Then you go back to chores. 
- Horrible UI, placeholder icons, numerous errors with tooltips, codex journal and guidebooks all use unclear language at several points. 
- Can't craft in base with materials in chest, yes palworld has spoiled me. 
- Gameplay loop consists of doing the same puzzles over and over again till you can get a card so you can do the same puzzles over and over again.
- Outside of chores the content is very lacking compared to other titles such as Valheim, Palworld, Enshrouded, V Rising, etc, this will hopefully be improved over time. 
- As a solo I felt the content was boring at medium and hard, and then just long and boring at extreme, as a group I bet it feels even more meh. Difficulty just makes bullet sponges, it doesn't actually add gameplay difficulty. 
- Most monsters are just reskins. Boar, Bigger Boar, and Hippo all do the same thing. Each forest biome upgrade has "deer with a different name," desert has bugs but different colored. Attack patterns (if there is even enough depth to call it a pattern) are all the same.
