I absolutely cannot recommend this at this time. I gave it a chance but couldn't help but compare this to a mutated survival game which grew additional legs just to shoot itself in more than two feet. I will likely try it after about half a year since I cannot envision them fixing all the problems earlier and I doubt the design problems are going away at all..

Graphics
- are good but in this instance overshadowed by the game running like crap

Performance
- horrible even when surpassing HW requirements
- game performance goes down with the amnount of entities in vicinity
- the only redeeming quality here is that the game goes down in the fps but does not stutter, however playing at 20 fps if the game spawns more than 5 entities (which is quite common) is just not acceptable

Design
- very confusing and it takes a very long time for the game to actually open up so expect a very linear experience at the start
- game has survival mechanics that simply do not make sense and only serve to annoy the user
- unless you look at the wiki and other sources the building mechanic will be confusing at best
- game does a very bad job at explaining how to unlock recipes and progress other than through the main quest
- there are areas which are locked until an item level is reached and the only indication is if you go directly to them and check if you reach the requirements

Combat
- enemies are often unable to deal with you strafing their attacks
- before you get ranged weaponry you truly realize how bare-bones the meele combat is
- the hitboxes often do not line up and enemy animations often go through you serving for a very clunky gameplay especially during group combat
- the projectiles just feel very weird, hitboxes on structure are often much bigger than you would think from their visual representation therefore shots that are close to floor/ceiling/wall often get trapped in it even if visual line between you and target exists

Game has many survival mechanics which allow you to modify the sandbox map severely which is a very good. It does give you the option to modify your experience just the way you like. But the above mentioned problems just outshadow the good qualities of the game.

Overall the game just needs a lot more work for me to consider downloading it again...

DISAPPOINTED
This was the game I was anticipating the most for the 2024, unfortunately I have to say I am quite disappointed with it.
WHEN you can actually play the game, it is quite decent, nothing spectacular mind you, but after playing Enshrouded, this game feels mediocre at best.
I am not gonna bother describing the good things about this game, which is mainly the card system and the art style. I am sure you can read about that in other reviews.

These are the main issues:

1) THIS IS UNFORGIVABLE. I don't understand why developers keep doing this.
The game requires you to be ALWAYS online even in Single Player mode, so if you have a bad connection or bad ping because you live far from the servers you will get frequent disconnections.
I don't get ping lag, but I do get disconnected from time to time, not often but enough to be very annoying. It also takes a long time to be able to reconnect giving you various connection errors, which add to the frustration.
And let's not forget sometimes their own servers fail.
So, if you play Single Player, forget a smooth game session, it will be filled with disconnections and re-connection problems.

2) This game feels very grindy, everything takes ages to do. In Enshroud the grind is so well balanced you hardly feel it. In Nightingale you feel every bit of it.

3) The Maps are soulless. The procedurally generated content is beautiful and fun at first but gets really boring after a while. Exploration gets repetitive very fast, and you will find yourself walking a lot before finding something interesting to do, which is a problem for a survival game.

4) Combat is basic and clunky, not fun at all. You CAN'T even Dodge or Parry in this game, and considering you will melee most of the time, this makes fighting mobs annoying rather than fun.

5) Crafting and Building in general is really interesting. However there is a major issue with structure building which makes it tedious and grindy which is the fact that you cannot move Work Stations, Building Blocks or Furniture, you need to destroy them with a weapon and rebuild it. It takes ages to build a nice and comfy looking home base. Enshrouded does it much better again.

CONCLUSION
Not an awful game, with some cool innovative ideas, but if you are on a restricted budget or have a bad internet connection I suggest you buy Enshrouded instead. Better game overall, less grindy, fun combat, better Base building, and most importantly, you won't get disconnection problems playing in SINGLE PLAYER mode.

In it's current state, I'd say wait and see.  I feel like I just licked the batter of the chocolate chip cookies and got salmonella poisoning.  It's not their fault, it's mine for not waiting for waiting for the cookies to bake in the oven first.  But I'm on the toilet clearing out my colon with a stomachache. You can interpret that closing line however you want.  Point is this game needs a lot of time in the oven.

There is a great foundation here for the game.  The gunplay is definitely good.  I can see the ex-Mass Effect dev veterans here at work.  The melee needs a bit of work.  It's floaty and the hits are iffy.  Half the time I feel the hit isn't registering where I want it to.  And when it does it is rarely on center of where the crosshairs are.  They are trying for the Vermintide-style combat but it will definitely need to be a lot tighter to succeed.  I'll be honest I cannot tell if it is on my end or a consequence of their always online therefore lag.  Talking about the lag, I'm lucky enough to be on the same continent and I can feel the lag and connection issues. I definitely feel for those outside of North America.

Art direction is amazing. I am a sucker for steampunk aesthetics and I'll admit it.  But you realise that with the random generation you still get a lot of reused assets and a handful of them at that.  So the novelty wears off after you've seen the same things in world one be in world 10.  Character design is questionable, the joke about fetal alcohol syndrome characters or opium addicts play very well into the Neo-Victorian era.  Clothing designs are not as plentiful as I want.

Crafting is tedious but nuanced.  I get what the devs are going for as there are many layers to creating gear but they are not well explained or proper contextual information provided.  They would have Tier provided for most crafting materials but not for ore and food. Sometimes tier crafting mattered, some times it did not.  It isn't explained clearly when it does, which stats do, etc etc. A lot of it is play and figure it out as you go, but it isn't done well and intuitively like let's say Terraria.  Most of my play time was just figuring this stuff out making the game tedious to play. The nuanced part of crafting for example is crafting Desert/Forest (Desert fibre + forest thread) cloth will have different stats compared to a Forest/Desert (Forest fibre + desert thread) Cloth. So there's a lot of combinations to build your gear. It's fun but time consuming and kills you're inventory management as everything is it's own item.

And talking about time consuming there is a lot, a lot of things that just eat time for no reason, causing my internal entertainment gauge "fun" slowly ticking over to "chore".  Crafting takes time, starting portal takes time, traversing is mostly by foot, cutting tree takes an oddly long time for it to fall, certain enemies require you to kill them for them to drop it's core (if it didn't fall through the floor 80% of the time) which you would need to break with your pickaxe to drop it's loot.  Why can it not just drop it's loot. bound enemy spawns take time.  Crafting recipes are spread out between between the 3 biomes across every major realm (read higher tier world).  ie Shotgun in desert provisioner realm, pistol in forest provisioner and rifle is in swamp provisioner realm.  You want all the firearms, go through all 3 realms.  Every little thing is tedious and time gated making the game feel like a time sink.  God forbid you are a parent with children and an hour to yourself everyday. This game is not for you.

Early access games so bugs galore and incompleteness (but it's EA you know what you're getting into).  Nothing too game breaking but it does get annoying at times. Like the enemy or enemy loot falling through the floor mentioned before. Alt+tabbing and tabbing back in disables running until you open your menu and close it again. Lots of placeholder assets in the menu so at the end game I can't tell if my components are in my inventory or not at a glance.  Some nonsensical things like Vegetable (Onion) and Onion (Onion) being separate items (they have different stats but why?). I need to scroll over all the individual items that don't have assets to figure out what it is.

End game sounded enticing, but it ended up being what you've experienced out in the game but on a slightly bigger scale with other players.  It's the same little mini-missions/puzzles to unlock recipes outside of buying from npc vendors when you are in the realm and then you finish with a boss fight.  The netcode needs work.  Definitely experienced lag, rubber banding and disconnects when playing this mode.  Voice chat is disabled currently but there is a greyed out scroll bar leading me to believe it's available later.

I want to reiterate, there is a good decent game under all of this.  I don't think it's truly worth playing right now.  Perhaps a few updates or maybe on release we'll have something much more polished.

I have been waiting for this game for 2 years.  I love the vibe, the look and the concept. However, the execution is literal crap.  It is a chore to play.  I know its early access, but please, so are several titles just out, and they are done right.  Its the little things, they will hopefully fix:
* - Storage and Inventory use.  This is elementary.  Let us use what is in a storage containers. Hobbling back and forth from box to box just to transfer items is not fun.
* - Online gameplay only.  This is a deal breaker.  I hope the rumors are true that they are going to implement single player offline play.  Being kicked from my session after texting a friend (<1 minute) is very frustrating, especially when it takes 5 minutes to get back in.
* - Gear locked areas and dungeons - Just let us try... Stop micromanaging your players. This negates the whole concept and enjoyment of exploration.

All in all, the game absolutely has potential, but only with several game format alterations.  For now, it is a frustrating no for me.  I hope to change this review in the very near future.

First off... I played it before EA and found the concept to be enchanting. I've played MANY games and love the survival games a lot. Since most of my gaming is spent in MMOs, farming sims and survival I'm used to the grind of getting resources, building things, etc.  So, based on that, I wanted something less generic. I loved the Fae atmosphere and the cards for Realms. This game offers quite a bit of ambiance while maintaining a lot of the traditional gather/grind concepts. So, if you're looking for that, this game might be worth looking into.

Now the bad: It's EA. That's right. Not everything is polished. There are missing icons, some network connectivity issues, it needs dedicated server options, offline, more of this, more of that... you get the idea. However, the Devs seem very forthcoming about things, they seem to listen to players and are working to make this game better.  So, in a world of instant gratification and gimme gimme attitude? You might not want this right now. Or you might, if you aren't a person that needs things immediately in an EA game. Give it a shot, you might like it. :/  I do!
